Graulich D. Senko J. Janka M. Matusza
2025-051_F01 2025 2025-051 Human Resources (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-051_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Insuff. description of FCT`s calculation metho. and controls in the merit process for BoM and Exec. Internal Audit identified the following weaknesses:
§ Group Controlling (FCT) lacked written specifications on the calculation logic and data quality checks for the Excel sheets used for Performance Share Plan (PSP) and Performance Bonus Plan (PBP) KPI calculations. The KPIs included the relative Total Shareholder Return (TSR), Net Income Growth, Net Revenue and EBITDA targets. Data quality check documentation requirements were also not defined.
§ The TSR calculations lacked rounding rules specifications, in addition to those already defined in the Performance Share Plan document. E.g., the TSR Model calculated the final percentile with the Excel “rounddown” formula in favour of DB1 share, which was not specified in any procedure. For Net Income calculations, the average growth in five years was instead calculated with the “roundup” formula, which was also not part of the PSP specification.
§ The Merit Review procedure contained a control step 2.2. (a four-eyes check for KPIs by HoS Group Controlling and HoS Group Reporting). For this control, there was no checklist with defined data check points. How to document this control was not defined either.
§ The SP_DBAG_MA_3.6.7.2.8.1_Merit Review process map entry mentioned in the Merit review procedure was not found in SAP GRC.		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Controlling (FCT):
§ create written specifications on the calculation logic and data quality checks for the Excel sheets used for the Performance Share Plan (PSP) and Performance Bonus Plan (PBP) KPI calculations. Control documentation rules should also be set up specifying the rounding rules in the TSR calculation (i.e. for the final percentile) and the Net Income Growth calculation (average growth in five years)
§ define the exact contents of data checks in the control step 2.2 of the Merit procedure as well as the way to document this control
§ define and document rounding rules for the TSR calculation beyond the specifications of the Performance Share Plan
§ review and update the SAP GRC Merit review process entry		 6/2/2025 10/10/2025 10/10/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Anna Glos Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Group Controlling (S) Group Controlling (FCT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficient description of Group Controlling’s calculation methodology and controls in the merit process for Board Members and executives represent a material violation of external and internal requirements. This exposes DBG to the risk of discrepancies and errors in calculation results for the variable compensation, which may lead to an adverse financial and reputational impact on the company. Mirko Huppert ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Lack of Awareness of Group / Cross Functional Processes Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No Yes No
2025-033_F01 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance Various financial industry regulations demand a consistent and coherent approach that spans the entire lifecycle of third-party relationships, from initial risk assessment and onboarding through contract management, operational oversight, incident handling, and exit strategies. An effective third-party risk management requires clear traceability of responsibilities, harmonized documentation and IT applications as well as integrated risk controls across all relevant functions and DBG legal entities.

The DBG outsourcing framework has recently been updated to include ICT third-party risk management. This extended the already complex outsourcing and third-party management processes, which were already fragmented, siloed and lacked alignment and harmonization. DBG’s third-party management activities were spread across many legal entities, departments as well as multitudinous Contract- and Business Owners. Impact could be exemplified by inconsistently applied third-party management, not aligned roles and responsibilities, inconsistent and decentralized due diligence, risk assessment and monitoring across the 1st LoD, e.g. ownership for third-party management or contract management, ineffective third-party oversight or missing data governance. Illustrative risk drivers include:
a) Multiple teams within DBG (Purchasing, Business Owners, Ecosystem Partner Risk Management, IT Strategic Provider Management) conducted due diligence, risk assessment, and monitoring activities using different tools and methodologies. This led to redundancy, inefficiency and inconsistent results. Central oversight and consolidation of inputs from different internal stakeholders were not established.
b) Lack of robust data governance for contract and third-party data resulted in inconsistent, incomplete or inaccurate entries across multiple tools and repositories for contract and third-party data. Third parties were not timely, unambiguous and reliably identifiable. Comprehensive controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of the contract inventory and other third-party data did not exist.
c) DBG legal entities did not establish roles and processes to provide coordinated management of and communication with third parties. The relationship management was set up contract based, resulting in hundreds of contract Business Owners across the organization performing duplicated tasks and actions, leading to unstructured and fragmented third-party documentation. Consequently, the missing coordination resulted in third parties like SAP and Microsoft complaining about repeated and uncoordinated information requests in 2025.
d) A detailed vendor management review of a sample of six major ICT third parties (Google, Tata, Bottomline, Equinix, NTT and Appway) revealed that DBG had not implemented a fully aligned third-party governance, risk or control framework according to the obligations laid down in contracts, including the DORA contractual annex. As DBG works with several hundred ICT third parties plus more than ten third parties supporting CIF, DBG’s internal deadline for implementation and operationalization by December 2025 might be unfeasible in this regard.
e) Although deficiencies in the operationalization of the third-party risk management frameworks were self-identified (see SII-1 below), specific support has not been received by Contract/ Business Owners. Assurance was missing that DORA third-party risk management and vendor management specific expertise were available at the Business Owners.

A full list of supporting examples from 2025-033 and 2025-026 audits’ fieldwork is included in Appendix B.

A comprehensive, end-to-end governance approach for Third-parties management is a regulatory imperative. Fragmented, unaligned and siloed processes, particularly at the 1st LoD, impact 2LoD oversight and are explicitly discouraged, as they undermine the resilience, transparency, consistency and accountability that, particularly, DORA seeks to enforce across the financial sector.		 § Define and implement the Target Operating Model (TOM) for 1LoD and 2LoD third- party management that covers current overlaps, critical gaps and dependencies
§ Define and implement the Target Operating Model (TOM) for 1LoD and 2LoD governance of third- party and contract data, considering current tools and processes.
§ Set up a plan to ensure operationalization in DBG.
§ Set up a plan for third-party and contract data clean up.		 9/30/2025 9/30/2026 9/30/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (Div) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (FFO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Particularly significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance expose the company to critical regulatory, reputational, and operational risks. Failure to fulfill regulatory requirements constitute severe regulatory non-compliance and can lead to ad-hoc regulatory examinations, financial penalties, administrative orders, remedial measures, and operational restrictions. Penalties are determined by national supervisory authorities, with fines potentially reaching up to 2% of a company's global annual turnover. In addition, lack of accountability and poor contractual and third-party data governance may lead to underestimation of risks and financial losses. Uncoordinated relationship management and communication with third parties may result in reputational damage.
A limited oversight on third-party operational resilience, robustness, and compliance with internal and external requirements, may lead to security deficiencies and operational risks remaining undetected until they materialize.		 Jens Schulte ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),PHILIPPE SEYLL(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No Yes No
2025-033_F01 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S4 Significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance Various financial industry regulations demand a consistent and coherent approach that spans the entire lifecycle of third-party relationships, from initial risk assessment and onboarding through contract management, operational oversight, incident handling, and exit strategies. An effective third-party risk management requires clear traceability of responsibilities, harmonized documentation and IT applications as well as integrated risk controls across all relevant functions and DBG legal entities.

The DBG outsourcing framework has recently been updated to include ICT third-party risk management. This extended the already complex outsourcing and third-party management processes, which were already fragmented, siloed and lacked alignment and harmonization. DBG’s third-party management activities were spread across many legal entities, departments as well as multitudinous Contract- and Business Owners. Impact could be exemplified by inconsistently applied third-party management, not aligned roles and responsibilities, inconsistent and decentralized due diligence, risk assessment and monitoring across the 1st LoD, e.g. ownership for third-party management or contract management, ineffective third-party oversight or missing data governance. Illustrative risk drivers include:
a) Multiple teams within DBG (Purchasing, Business Owners, Ecosystem Partner Risk Management, IT Strategic Provider Management) conducted due diligence, risk assessment, and monitoring activities using different tools and methodologies. This led to redundancy, inefficiency and inconsistent results. Central oversight and consolidation of inputs from different internal stakeholders were not established.
b) Lack of robust data governance for contract and third-party data resulted in inconsistent, incomplete or inaccurate entries across multiple tools and repositories for contract and third-party data. Third parties were not timely, unambiguous and reliably identifiable. Comprehensive controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of the contract inventory and other third-party data did not exist.
c) DBG legal entities did not establish roles and processes to provide coordinated management of and communication with third parties. The relationship management was set up contract based, resulting in hundreds of contract Business Owners across the organization performing duplicated tasks and actions, leading to unstructured and fragmented third-party documentation. Consequently, the missing coordination resulted in third parties like SAP and Microsoft complaining about repeated and uncoordinated information requests in 2025.
d) A detailed vendor management review of a sample of six major ICT third parties (Google, Tata, Bottomline, Equinix, NTT and Appway) revealed that DBG had not implemented a fully aligned third-party governance, risk or control framework according to the obligations laid down in contracts, including the DORA contractual annex. As DBG works with several hundred ICT third parties plus more than ten third parties supporting CIF, DBG’s internal deadline for implementation and operationalization by December 2025 might be unfeasible in this regard.
e) Although deficiencies in the operationalization of the third-party risk management frameworks were self-identified (see SII-1 below), specific support has not been received by Contract/ Business Owners. Assurance was missing that DORA third-party risk management and vendor management specific expertise were available at the Business Owners.

A full list of supporting examples from 2025-033 and 2025-026 audits’ fieldwork is included in Appendix B.

A comprehensive, end-to-end governance approach for Third-parties management is a regulatory imperative. Fragmented, unaligned and siloed processes, particularly at the 1st LoD, impact 2LoD oversight and are explicitly discouraged, as they undermine the resilience, transparency, consistency and accountability that, particularly, DORA seeks to enforce across the financial sector.		 § Set up a project, with relevant 1LoD and 2LoD representatives, to address the weaknesses identified in the third-party lifecycle management and data governance, including details from Appendix B of the Internal Audit report
§ Involve all relevant legal entities as appropriate.
§ Set up a project plan defining milestones and deliverables.		 9/30/2025 2/28/2026 2/28/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Desiree Ramirez Desiree Ramirez JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (Div) JENS SCHULTE CFO (Div) CFO (FFO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Particularly significant deficiencies in third-party lifecycle management and data governance expose the company to critical regulatory, reputational, and operational risks. Failure to fulfill regulatory requirements constitute severe regulatory non-compliance and can lead to ad-hoc regulatory examinations, financial penalties, administrative orders, remedial measures, and operational restrictions. Penalties are determined by national supervisory authorities, with fines potentially reaching up to 2% of a company's global annual turnover. In addition, lack of accountability and poor contractual and third-party data governance may lead to underestimation of risks and financial losses. Uncoordinated relationship management and communication with third parties may result in reputational damage.
A limited oversight on third-party operational resilience, robustness, and compliance with internal and external requirements, may lead to security deficiencies and operational risks remaining undetected until they materialize. 2024-048_F02 2024 2024-048 SAP Application & Vendor & Project (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-048_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S3 Inappropriate SAP vendor risk management Internal Audit noted that SAP vendor risk management was not developed to a maturity level which would be considered appropriate in view of the vendor’s importance. Contributing factors for the conclusion:
- Corporate IT performed a targeted review on SAP in 2023, identifying severe audit right limitations for the following topics: Incident and Data Breach Management, Third Party Provider Management, Malware Management and Penetration Testing.
- DBAG and SAP followed up in working sessions to align on the collaboration and joint understanding for future audits in order to receive the required information. Nevertheless, remediation actions did not result in a sustainably improved DBAG audit support. DBAG was still asked to rely on documents validated by independent certified third parties, e.g. SOC 2 audit reports.
- Corporate IT did not validate the effectiveness of allegedly improved audit support, to confirm the removal of audit right limitations. Further, appropriate risk management measures such as risk entries, risk acceptance, or further escalation were not initiated.

Although IT Security is currently strengthening the “Supplier Security Risk” process, supported by the Prevalent tool, the contract business owner’s duty to capture, assess and manage supplier risk remains untouched. Considering SAP’s refusal to provide information as outlined in 2024-048_F01, SAP vendor risk management is deemed systematically incomplete.

According to MaRisk, the internal audit function shall examine and assess in a risk-oriented and process-independent manner the effectiveness and appropriateness of the risk management system, as well as the appropriateness of all activities and processes in general, irrespective of whether or not they have been outsourced. For material outsourced activities and processes, the outsourcing contract shall specifically set out appropriate internal auditors’ rights of information and review.		 Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT (ITH) to create and implement a Corrective Action Plan along the following illustrative steps:
- Design and implement a robust SAP vendor risk management and monitoring in line with applicable policies and related regulatory requirements.
- Develop and implement the resulting SAP vendor management processes for vendor monitoring and control activities.
- Develop and implement KPIs for the vendor SAP to assess the effectiveness of the newly implemented processes on a regular basis.		 9/25/2024 12/18/2024 12/31/2025 1 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT (A) Corporate IT (ITH) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inappropriate SAP vendor risk management could lead to unacceptable vendor behaviour that in consequence breaches contractual obligations and thus violates regulatory requirements. This may cause a high potential for penalty payments, extra reporting requirements and regulatory examinations with serious adverse regulatory impact. Further, minor financial risks may arise for DBAG paying charges for contractually agreed services which are not delivered by SAP. Lars Bolanca CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Lack of Awareness of Group / Cross Functional Processes Control Des. + Control Op. 2024-048_F01 2024 2024-048 SAP Application & Vendor & Project (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-048_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S3 SAP contract breach by limitation of agreed audit rights Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) key business applications run in SAP’s Software as a Service (SaaS) cloud environment are e.g. SAP C/4 HANA (CX), SAP SuccessFactors (SFSF), SAP Business Technology Platform, Enterprise Analytics Cloud, SAP Ariba, SAP Concur or SAP Fieldglass.

Internal Audit (IA) noted that SAP did not properly support DBAG in performing audit activities (e.g. risk assessments, process inspections or control validations) although the contract with SAP granted DBAG “unrestricted audit rights”. In essence, SAP did not disclose (neither hand-over of documentation nor reading opportunity) any policy document, process, controls, tools, risk data or third-party information, which are essential for DBAG’s Third-Party Risk Management.

Specifically, SAP did not disclose the following:
1. Policies, standards, and procedures (e.g. Wiki, Confluence, or WebPage), including e.g. SAP Risk Management Policy, SAP Defensive Penetration Standard or SAP Third Party Security Annex.
2. Internal processes, including e.g. Risk Management, Incident Management or Customer Impact assessment.
3. Internal control frameworks and internal controls on processes, including e.g. Global Security Framework or controls for Risk Management.
4. Internal reporting, including e.g. KPIs on overall SAP’s compliance status, vulnerabilities, or incidents.
5. Supporting tools, including e.g. an overview of used tools and linkage to processes, security concepts or risk profiles for each tool such as Compliance Cockpit, Splunk, Brinqa or ServiceNow.
6. Risk data, including e.g. risk inventory, missing patches, vulnerability or penetration test results. SAP refused by stating “… details regarding the Risk Management topics cannot be shared as they are highly confidential information which is not shared with customers at any time, …”.
7. Engaged third parties, including e.g. overview of third parties, risk assessment of these third parties or the contractual pass-through of DBAG audit rights.

During the three-day on-site visit, SAP shared information verbally based on standardised, high-level slide decks.

As a result, IA was not in the position to examine SAP’s ICT (Information and Communications Technology) Governance and Risk Management. IA could not gain assurance whether the SAP organisation had developed a comprehensive control environment to manage ICT risks, processes, assets, and individuals. This applied to all five Cloud Security Alliance - Cloud Control Matrix control domains in scope: Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC), Business Continuity Management and Operational Resilience (BCR), Threat & Vulnerability Management (TVM), Security Incident Management, E-Discovery, & Cloud Forensics (SEF), and Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA).

As a justification, SAP pointed out a strong internal legal advice to treat the audit as a limited customer review for which such detailed requests were not allowed.

After IA triggered DBAG senior management escalation, SAP provided further information and three one-hour policy review sessions for the BCR control domain, delaying audit fieldwork by two weeks. Despite this increased cooperation, SAP did not provide these documents to IA DBAG for review, even though the documents were classified as SAP “internal” and accessible to SAP employees via SAP’s policy portal. At the end of the extended fieldwork, 14 of 41 requests had not been fulfilled at all, most others only partially and still no internal documents after the second document request. SAP also explained that further evidence could not be shared as this would provide an insider’s view of how SAP functions and the internal value SAP places on a subset of mission-critical processes.

Ineffectively established audit rights for a critical outsourcing engagement constitutes a violation of regulatory requirements to properly manage the respective third-party risks, monitor the provision of the outsourced activities, and assess the performance and quality of the services provided.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Corporate IT (ITH) to create and implement a Corrective Action Plan along the following illustrative steps:
1. Establish legal exchange between SAP and DBAG about the meaning and impact of “unrestricted audit rights” in the contract accordingly and document the result of the alignment.
2. Advise SAP to educate their organisation internally about DBAG’s “unrestricted audit rights”.
3. Perform an additional review to demonstrate that SAP is sharing and handing over appropriate information to DBAG.
All steps require solid evidence to demonstrate holistic and sustainable risk remediation.		 9/25/2024 12/18/2024 1/15/2026 1 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT (A) Corporate IT (ITH) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. SAP contract breach by limitation of agreed audit rights hindered Internal Audit to perform its duties and to form an opinion on SAP’s internal risk management and control system. Such lack of cooperation further impedes the DBAG business owner to implement an adequate vendor risk management approach and violates regulatory requirements.
Significant audit right limitation can lead to serious adverse regulatory impact such as a service termination note, extra reporting requirements or regulatory examinations (special audit pursuant to section 44 KwG). Furthermore, it represents a serious violation of internal and external provisions resulting in financial risks or adverse impact on the internal control system.		 Lars Bolanca CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Lack of Awareness of Group / Cross Functional Processes Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Yes Yes No No No No Yes
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

The identified weaknesses and some ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures are separately detailed in this report’s section 6 “Annex - Audit Observations”.
6. Annex - Audit Observations
Referencing the F01 finding raised above, the details included herewith are supporting some of its identified weaknesses and the ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures:

6.1 Incomplete requirements of ICT Governance Framework
Internal Audit noted that 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) development of the encompassing 14 ICT Guidelines aligned with the DORA risk management framework was scheduled for completion by December 2024 and progress tracked in the IT Amelioration (AMELI) program. Besides, MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist) IT control requirements are/will be gradually moved into updated or newly developed Guidelines.

-------
6.2 Alignment on arrangement of new IT Compliance setup within DBG’s legal entities
In 2023, the first IT Compliance control plan was generated on a risk-based approach and controls were executed accordingly. In 2024, a control plan was developed to execute controls on critical topics and the first DBAG IT Compliance Risk Assessment (CRAF “Compliance Risk Assessment Framework” Methodology) finalised.

At the end of Q3 2024, the following Group-wide activities were planned by DBAG Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) as outlined below:
§ Planned activities for 2025:
- At DBAG level, a revised control planning methodology was in development, and in alignment with ExR, CBF (incl. CH), CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and ECAG (incl. EFAG), reflecting a 4-year cycle (2023-26) to complete controls for all ICS L1 processes.
- New TOM “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements (Project supported by Protiviti consultant); rollout was scheduled through 2024 and will be operational beginning of 2025.
- Revise the CRAF 2.0 reflecting the DORA requirements as well.
- Enhance regulatory screening process going forward for all IT and IS related regulations.
§ For 2025, the status regarding service agreements are as follows:
- ExR, CBF (incl. CH): IT Compliance is fully outsourced to DBAG.
- ECAG (incl. EFAG): Framework and Risk Assessment are outsourced to DBAG since 1 September 2024; and controls will be jointly executed where deemed feasible. IT and IS Compliance topics were covered in its Annual Compliance Control Plans.
- CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) is currently in clarification. An outsourcing will take place, yet its frame is still under discussion. Implementation expected by 2025. 
- CFCL: although the outsourcing setup discussion is ongoing, no decision has been finalised as the agreement over the services that DBAG Compliance will be offering is in draft. The effective date is targeted for the end of Q1 2025.
-------
6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Internal Audit recommends that IT Governance Risk and Transformation (IRT):
§ completes the 1LoD detailed IT written rules (“procedures”) within the remit of IRT, i.e. for IT Run, IT Change and IT Governance process bundles in DBAG. Formalise and implement associated control governance to fulfil related 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) DORA-aligned ICT guideline requirements “process based”.
§ rolls out the procedures to all DBAG Shared and Product ITs and record their approval/decision. LEs are informed/consulted and can adopt DBAG procedure at LE discretion.
§ extends the IRT target operating model with “asset based” IT Risk Management once new second/first line delineation is established.
§ includes further process and asset-based metrics and KPIs in existing reporting and committee escalation processes.
§ takes over the ICS processes co-ordination role for DBAG IT from 2LoD i.e., to provide 1LoD – Shared and Product ITs – with guidance on how to define and execute the controls/assess risks.		 12/5/2024 12/18/2026 12/18/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Yezad Wadia Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies. Potential synergies, LE alignment and efficient prioritisation of different ICT initiatives may also not be achieved. Boris Link ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

The identified weaknesses and some ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures are separately detailed in this report’s section 6 “Annex - Audit Observations”.
6. Annex - Audit Observations
Referencing the F01 finding raised above, the details included herewith are supporting some of its identified weaknesses and the ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures:

6.1 Incomplete requirements of ICT Governance Framework
Internal Audit noted that 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) development of the encompassing 14 ICT Guidelines aligned with the DORA risk management framework was scheduled for completion by December 2024 and progress tracked in the IT Amelioration (AMELI) program. Besides, MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist) IT control requirements are/will be gradually moved into updated or newly developed Guidelines.

-------
6.2 Alignment on arrangement of new IT Compliance setup within DBG’s legal entities
In 2023, the first IT Compliance control plan was generated on a risk-based approach and controls were executed accordingly. In 2024, a control plan was developed to execute controls on critical topics and the first DBAG IT Compliance Risk Assessment (CRAF “Compliance Risk Assessment Framework” Methodology) finalised.

At the end of Q3 2024, the following Group-wide activities were planned by DBAG Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) as outlined below:
§ Planned activities for 2025:
- At DBAG level, a revised control planning methodology was in development, and in alignment with ExR, CBF (incl. CH), CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and ECAG (incl. EFAG), reflecting a 4-year cycle (2023-26) to complete controls for all ICS L1 processes.
- New TOM “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements (Project supported by Protiviti consultant); rollout was scheduled through 2024 and will be operational beginning of 2025.
- Revise the CRAF 2.0 reflecting the DORA requirements as well.
- Enhance regulatory screening process going forward for all IT and IS related regulations.
§ For 2025, the status regarding service agreements are as follows:
- ExR, CBF (incl. CH): IT Compliance is fully outsourced to DBAG.
- ECAG (incl. EFAG): Framework and Risk Assessment are outsourced to DBAG since 1 September 2024; and controls will be jointly executed where deemed feasible. IT and IS Compliance topics were covered in its Annual Compliance Control Plans.
- CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) is currently in clarification. An outsourcing will take place, yet its frame is still under discussion. Implementation expected by 2025. 
- CFCL: although the outsourcing setup discussion is ongoing, no decision has been finalised as the agreement over the services that DBAG Compliance will be offering is in draft. The effective date is targeted for the end of Q1 2025.
-------
6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Internal Audit recommends that Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT):
§ operationalises the control monitoring (as per new Target Operating Model -TOM), i.e. to check the responsibility for controls in 1LoD and completeness of controls executed by 1LoD DBAG IT.
§ completes the two new pilot assessments from H2 2024 as per new ICT Assurance methodology.
§ executes the 2025 ICT Assurance assessment cycle and planned activities as per the new methodology and perform follow-up activities (refer section 6.3).		 12/5/2024 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Thomas Kemmerer Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (Dpt) Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies. Potential synergies, LE alignment and efficient prioritisation of different ICT initiatives may also not be achieved. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.

Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance Strategy (SCG), with support of LE CCO (Chief Compliance Officer) or IT Compliance Officers, where needed:
§ designs and executes the IT Compliance Control plans.
§ executes the planned activities for 2025 (detailed in this report’s section 6.2) and operationalises the new Target Operating Model “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements, i.e. rollout, adoption, focusing on design type controls and performing reviews of ICT or IS regulations (subject to decision at the LE level).

Marco Popp ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

The identified weaknesses and some ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures are separately detailed in this report’s section 6 “Annex - Audit Observations”.
6. Annex - Audit Observations
Referencing the F01 finding raised above, the details included herewith are supporting some of its identified weaknesses and the ongoing topics’ planned mitigating measures:

6.1 Incomplete requirements of ICT Governance Framework
Internal Audit noted that 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) development of the encompassing 14 ICT Guidelines aligned with the DORA risk management framework was scheduled for completion by December 2024 and progress tracked in the IT Amelioration (AMELI) program. Besides, MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist) IT control requirements are/will be gradually moved into updated or newly developed Guidelines.

-------
6.2 Alignment on arrangement of new IT Compliance setup within DBG’s legal entities
In 2023, the first IT Compliance control plan was generated on a risk-based approach and controls were executed accordingly. In 2024, a control plan was developed to execute controls on critical topics and the first DBAG IT Compliance Risk Assessment (CRAF “Compliance Risk Assessment Framework” Methodology) finalised.

At the end of Q3 2024, the following Group-wide activities were planned by DBAG Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) as outlined below:
§ Planned activities for 2025:
- At DBAG level, a revised control planning methodology was in development, and in alignment with ExR, CBF (incl. CH), CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and ECAG (incl. EFAG), reflecting a 4-year cycle (2023-26) to complete controls for all ICS L1 processes.
- New TOM “IT Compliance and ICT Risk – Operating Model” reflecting the new DORA requirements (Project supported by Protiviti consultant); rollout was scheduled through 2024 and will be operational beginning of 2025.
- Revise the CRAF 2.0 reflecting the DORA requirements as well.
- Enhance regulatory screening process going forward for all IT and IS related regulations.
§ For 2025, the status regarding service agreements are as follows:
- ExR, CBF (incl. CH): IT Compliance is fully outsourced to DBAG.
- ECAG (incl. EFAG): Framework and Risk Assessment are outsourced to DBAG since 1 September 2024; and controls will be jointly executed where deemed feasible. IT and IS Compliance topics were covered in its Annual Compliance Control Plans.
- CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) is currently in clarification. An outsourcing will take place, yet its frame is still under discussion. Implementation expected by 2025. 
- CFCL: although the outsourcing setup discussion is ongoing, no decision has been finalised as the agreement over the services that DBAG Compliance will be offering is in draft. The effective date is targeted for the end of Q1 2025.
-------
6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Internal Audit recommends that Business Information Security (PWW) – legal entity (LE) CISOs for ExR, ECAG, EFAG:
§ establish a LE-specific operating model to ensure oversight and controlling of ICT risks and operationalise it.
§ finalise service agreements between the LEs ECAG with ExR and EFAG respectively by end of Q2 2025.

Further, in support and collaboration with Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT), update the service agreements - between ECAG and DBAG, ExR and DBAG, EFAG and DBAG - with relevant ICT elements by end of Q2 2025.

The first bullet has been adequately addressed before the issuance of the audit report.		 12/5/2024 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Yezad Wadia Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Clearing (A) Erik Tim Müller Business Information Security (U) Business Information Security (PWW) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework results in an inadequately established control environment. The delineation between DBG’s 1LoD and 2LoD did not effectively allow performing all responsibilities provided in the Information Security Policy, and effective assurance of 1LoD’s compliance with the framework. This could lead to major financial impact and serious reputational damage due to failure in identifying potential deficiencies. Potential synergies, LE alignment and efficient prioritisation of different ICT initiatives may also not be achieved. Henning Volz ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2024-063_F01 2024 2024-063 Technology Governance (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-063_F01-A06 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Incomplete ICT Risk Management framework & lack of harmonisation between DBG’s first and second LoD As identified in the CIO Strategy 2021 and the CIO division reorganisation, which was effective from Q3 2022, the closed 2022-051_F01 self-identified issue (SII)  planned to establish a consistent Group-wide IT Governance framework and function, including clear delineation of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) first (1LoD) and second (2LoD) lines of defence roles and responsibilities, by January 2024.

Internal Audit’s (IA) review of this SII noted that, although progress was made since 2022, the planned actions for IT Governance framework were incomplete. Due to responsibility shifts triggered by the January 2024 reorganisation and a new written rule structure, formalisation of the ICT Risk Management framework was prolonged. Thus, in the past years, a stable business-as-usual and sustainable state of Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) ICT Risk Management Framework and Governance had not been achieved. In detail:

1) ICT Risk Management Framework completeness
§ At the end of 2023, the development of IT Written Rules (ITWR) by 1LoD IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) was ongoing. However, the January 2024 reorganisation formally shifted responsibility to 2LoD ICT Risk Framework (KJU) for developing 14 Information Communication and Technology (ICT) Guidelines (erstwhile called “standards”) aligned with the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) risk management framework by December 2024.
§ 1LoD IRT plans to subsequently formalise the ITWR operational documentation (“procedures”) and fulfil control requirements to verify compliance. This is planned as a multi-year journey.
§ Although SII 2022-051_F01 anticipated 1LoD IRT’s alignment of the IT Governance framework with all affected Shared and Product ITs, this was not ensured since the alignment was on a best effort basis.

Moreover, the priority-oriented DORA-readiness implementation plan scheduled completion of Design (DE) and Operating Effectiveness (OE) for 7 out of 18 areas by January 2025. For the remaining eleven areas, prioritisation efforts were channeled towards achieving maturity, with DE completed by that date, and continuous improvements towards OE scheduled to last until end of 2025. The DBG Legal Entities’ DORA progress was tracked and monitored by appropriate oversight mechanisms, e.g. Steering Committees, Board presentations.

2) DBG 1LoD and 2LoD responsibilities
By end of 2023, DBG’s 2LoD lacked an IT framework and performed no IS Compliance control activities. Following the 1 January 2024 reorganisation, 2LoD defined a target “IT Compliance & ICT – Operating Model” (TOM) to include the missing activities. By June 2024, it was only aligned with DBAG, ongoing with other Legal Entities (LEs).

IA identified the following 1LoD and 2LoD roles and responsibilities gaps regarding ICT activities, as well as alignment between 2LoD functions of affected LEs:
§ After the responsibilities split/handover in Q1 2024 between 1LoD IRT and 2LoD CICTRO/CISO (ICT), co-ordination role for ICS (Internal Control Systems) in DBAG IT has been assigned to 2LoD CICTRO/CISO, as well as control monitoring and quality assurance activities. Since providing guidance on how controls are defined and executed would impact 2LoD CICTRO independence to oversee 1LoD activities, 2LoD CICTRO was aiming at coordination without providing guidance. However, a transfer of responsibility to IRT on providing guidance to 1LoD was also not initiated.
§ Pending LE CISOs (2LoD) decision to include performing oversight and controlling of IT/ICT risks by either extending their responsibilities or to assign it within other 2LoD. Agreement with DBAG CICTRO/CISO over the potential outsourcing services to follow.
§ Pending LE’s Compliance Officers’ decision on aligning with DBAG (2LoD) Group Compliance Strategy (SCG) regarding Group-wide IT Compliance setup and responsibilities, focusing on design-type controls and reviews of ICT or IS regulations. This was due to ongoing update of the new Group Compliance SDS (Service Definition Statement) and the IT Compliance services to be provided to LEs. Therefore, the agreement on the services between DBAG’s SCG and LEs, e.g. CBL (incl. CS/CI/LuxCSD) and CFCL was delayed. (For details, refer section 6.2)

3) IS Assurance plan completeness and Security Risk Management
§ Incomplete 2LoD oversight in the past years – DBAG and impacted LEs (dependent on DBAG’s coverage) IS assurance plans execution was partial due to approach changes or personnel unavailability. (For details, refer section 6.3).
§ The Ecosystem Security Risk Management (ESRM), managed via the Prevalent (AID2040) tool, did not have a sufficient solution to record affected LEs’ risk acceptance approvals. The current provision is to inform the “using” LEs about the risk/status and only provide the “owning” LE’s confirmation/acceptance evidence. This deficiency’s remediation is being tracked via IA’s open “Audit BaFin IT Outsourcing 2022” validation report Note #N10.

The above-mentioned weaknesses were caused by an inadequate governance structure. It was also impacted by personnel / organisational structure changes throughout 2024.

German and Luxembourg regulation emphasises the need for robust governance arrangements and adequate internal control mechanisms. Processes, as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels should be clearly defined and coordinated. Regulation also requires that activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines.

To note, the remediation measures for above-mentioned activities are subject to multiple team coordination and availability, including the appointment of the CICTRO/CISO personnel. Thus, submission to IA of the Corrective Action Plan (CAP) is planned by 24 January 2025.
=============

6. Annex - Audit Observations

6.3 Second LoD ICT Risk Assurance – methodology and planned activities
IA noted that, as a result of partially executed IS assurance plans in the past years, the “IS Assurance Assessment Deliverables” key performance indicators (KPI) across DBG were not achieved.

In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

As per revised methodology, effective January 2025,
§ the “non-conformity” from H2 2024 pilot and onward assessments will be tracked via AMIT tool (Component ID: 1847878, CID5168), and
§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Internal Audit recommends that Information Security (ISU) – legal entity (LE) CISOs for CBF/CH/CBL/CI/CS/LuxCSD and CFCL i.e. Post Trade ICT Risk 2LoD:
§ design a DORA-compliant operating model to be formally approved by Management with ensuring adequate budget and staffing levels.
§ operationalise the model to ensure oversight and controlling of ICT risks.
§ finalise potential additional service agreements between the LEs by end of Q2 2025.

Also, in support and collaboration with Chief ICT Risk Officer/CISO (ICT), update the service agreement between Post Trade ICT Risk 2LoD and DBAG with relevant ICT elements by end of Q2 2025.		 12/5/2024 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg Yezad Wadia Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) JEAN-MARC DI CATO Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Information Security (U) Information Security (ISU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Néjib Zaouali ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. In Q3 2024, following an updated “IS Assurance Handbook and Methodology” and formal approval by LE CISO’s in September 2024, two assessments planned for H2 2024 as pilots to the new methodology were initiated by 2LoD ICT Risk Assurance (KIU) and ongoing at the time of audit.

§ for output from previous assessments - 2023 and H1 2024 – and “improvement opportunities” from new assessments an internal Excel-based tracker is adopted for monitoring and tracking purposes.		 Internal Audit recommend that ICT Risk Framework (KJU):
§ designs and develops the 14 ICT Guidelines including MCRC (Minimum Control Requirements Checklist), and DORA-aligned IT control requirements. Recommendation closure will require approval at DBAG level and distribution of the updated Guidelines to all relevant DBG legal entities for their decision.
§ ensures the proposed new combined IS/IT requirements methodology be transitioned into the MCF (Mandatory Control Framework).		 12/5/2024 10/28/2025 10/28/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Thomas Kemmerer Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Sarah Ahmad Jahn ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des.
