2025-012_F01 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Inadequate Frankfurt data centres failover and disaster recovery testing Internal Audit (IA) identified the annual Disaster Recovery (DR) testing (for DBG data centres in Frankfurt) did not include complete full data centre failover - at least since 2022. This was visible again in DBG’s 2024 annual DR report. Thus, critical processes and relevant IT services remained untested and might not work as expected in case of a complete DC failure. The available IT Resiliency Management procedure did not include a detailed data centre failover scenario to ensure the participation of all IT product areas and their sufficient testing.

Further, no DR scenario had been defined at the time of the audit review   , to test the IT infrastructure and system capacity as part of a complete data centre failover, neither during dedicated testing window, nor during long lasting test exercise running at least all business-critical processes and services in a failover mode during regular business hours.

DORA article 25 (2) requires financial entities to test their ICT business continuity plans and assess whether they can ensure the financial entity’s critical or important functions’ continuity. Testing shall be based on test scenarios that simulate potential disruptions, including an adequate set of severe but plausible scenarios; and contain scenarios of switchover from primary ICT infrastructure to the redundant capacity, backups and redundant facilities. The Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 Articles 12, 18 and 19 define similar or further operational continuity requirements, including assessing the overall recovery capacity.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Networks, Data Center & Virtualization (ZFI) design and implement a disaster recovery (DR) plan for full data centre failover testing.    The DR plan and its testing shall, at least annually, include all IT services to recover all business processes and sufficient capacity testing.
The DR scenario testing shall include the following but not be limited to:
§ Data centre isolation to perform a full failover
§ Duration of the data centre isolation shall be aligned with requirements of the IT services		 5/28/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Networks, Data Center & Virtualizati (S) Networks, Data Center & Virtualization (ZFI) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate Frankfurt   data centres failover and disaster recovery (DR) testing may expose the company to severe IT system and service unavailability of critical and important business functions through unknown shortcomings or unanticipated dependencies, preventing a proper and timely service restoration. Further, the secondary data centre’s full production load capabilities in case of a disaster cannot be demonstrated, which may significantly impact DR measures in case they are required. The increased geopolitical instability is also leading to additional cyberthreat and physical security threat. As a consequence of operational unavailability risk, these DR plan weaknesses may lead to major financial loss and severe regulatory fines, overall resulting in material reputational damage. Eric Reding CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-012_F01 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Inadequate Frankfurt data centres failover and disaster recovery testing Internal Audit (IA) identified the annual Disaster Recovery (DR) testing (for DBG data centres in Frankfurt) did not include complete full data centre failover - at least since 2022. This was visible again in DBG’s 2024 annual DR report. Thus, critical processes and relevant IT services remained untested and might not work as expected in case of a complete DC failure. The available IT Resiliency Management procedure did not include a detailed data centre failover scenario to ensure the participation of all IT product areas and their sufficient testing.

Further, no DR scenario had been defined at the time of the audit review   , to test the IT infrastructure and system capacity as part of a complete data centre failover, neither during dedicated testing window, nor during long lasting test exercise running at least all business-critical processes and services in a failover mode during regular business hours.

DORA article 25 (2) requires financial entities to test their ICT business continuity plans and assess whether they can ensure the financial entity’s critical or important functions’ continuity. Testing shall be based on test scenarios that simulate potential disruptions, including an adequate set of severe but plausible scenarios; and contain scenarios of switchover from primary ICT infrastructure to the redundant capacity, backups and redundant facilities. The Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 Articles 12, 18 and 19 define similar or further operational continuity requirements, including assessing the overall recovery capacity.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that IT Governance & Resilience (GEM) revise the IT Resiliency Management Procedure by explicitly requiring regular execution of full data centre failover testing including mandatory participation of all shared and product IT teams. Reporting of the test participation and results of all critical applications (including relevant dependencies as outlined in P1) will follow the defined resilience governance and reporting structure. 5/28/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance & Resilience (U) Governance & Execution Management (GEM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate Frankfurt   data centres failover and disaster recovery (DR) testing may expose the company to severe IT system and service unavailability of critical and important business functions through unknown shortcomings or unanticipated dependencies, preventing a proper and timely service restoration. Further, the secondary data centre’s full production load capabilities in case of a disaster cannot be demonstrated, which may significantly impact DR measures in case they are required. The increased geopolitical instability is also leading to additional cyberthreat and physical security threat. As a consequence of operational unavailability risk, these DR plan weaknesses may lead to major financial loss and severe regulatory fines, overall resulting in material reputational damage. Nanjiao Wilhelms-Wang CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE):
- establishes adequate requirements for DBAG’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in Process Maps and Risk Control Matrices of legal entities under ZHE supervision – DBAG (except for DBAG IT).		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Group Risk Governance & ICS (U) Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Thomas Heinze ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for CBF’s, CBL’s, CH’s, CI’s and CS’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under ZFE supervision - CBF, CBL, CH, CI and CS.
- reviews Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CH, CI and CS.		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Banking AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) UDO HENKELMANN Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Controls Assurance & Monitoring (U) Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. 2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases.

Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for DBAG CIO/COO Division’s regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under IRT supervision – DBAG IT.		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Boris Link ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A05 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for ECAG’s (as a legal entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under FRB supervision – ECAG.		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (U) Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Oussama Fakih ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A06 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under KOU supervision – CFCL, CFCHK and CFCS. 		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO STEEG Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Outsourcing & Controls (U) Outsourcing & Controls (KOU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Regulatory Framework and Implementation (RGL):
- aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) and establishes adequate requirements for EFAG’s, ExR’s and Cash Market’s (as a virtual entity) regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entities under RGL supervision – EFAG, ExR and Cash Market (as a virtual entity).		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Frankfurt AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) MELANIE DANNHEIMER Trading & Clearing (Div) Cash Market (A) Eric Leupold Regulatory Framework & Implementatio (U) Regulatory Framework and Implementation (RGL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Aleksandra Golon ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A09 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Corporate (CPT):
- establishes adequate requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls and enhanced ICS Effectiveness reporting to the CAL management.
- closely aligns with Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE), working on DBG’s minimum requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls; ensures that individual legal entity requirements align with the DBG minimum requirements and regulatory specifications.
- mitigates identified issues in the Process Maps and Risk Control Matrix of legal entity under CPT supervision – CAL.		 7/4/2025 12/10/2026 12/10/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) BERNARD TANCRÉ Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Corporate (U) Corporate (CPT) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Warren Peter Morton ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F01 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Serious weaknesses in the ICS Framework and its implementation impairing the ICS Effectiveness The Internal Control System (ICS) framework is aimed at managing risks on a process level, preventing material losses, achieving Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG or Group) corporate goals/business strategy and safeguarding its continued existence. Information on the processes, risks and controls is used, among others, by second- and third-line functions.

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the ICS framework: 
- insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls, and 
- lack of correlation in risk assessment and undefined mandatory fields, which hinder execution of Quality Assurance activities.

Insufficient assurance on effectiveness of internal controls of key risk and their controls:
The Executive Boards and local ICS experts regularly informed relevant legal entity Supervisory Boards and the Audit Committees, as well as some regulatory authorities (if relevant), about the internal control system’s effectiveness. Overall ICS effectiveness confirmation was provided to boards based on:
- Process Owners’ and/or Process Operators’ self-assessments of overall control design and operating effectiveness during the sign-off phase, including for processes with high and medium risks;
- results of internal and external audits;
- local ICS experts’ Quality Assurance check results (3-year cycle).

IA noted that across all legal entities in scope of the audit 62% of internal controls were assessed as key controls. Given the high volume of key controls, only a limited assurance on its effectiveness was provided. Self-assessments represented the majority of these inputs. IA noted those were not based on any documented testing by the Process Owners/Operators. This did not ensure that, in particular, the high risks and their control effectiveness inputs were adequate.

Furthermore, also the local ICS experts’ dedicated, risk-based Quality Assurance (QA) checks included a quality review of data inserted into the ICS and an assessment of control design. However, these checks did not involve any operating effectiveness testing. Evidence of control performance was also not required. There was therefore no mandatory verification that controls were functioning as intended, hampering ability to promptly identify and address control weaknesses. For most processes with lower overall ratings (typically low and negligible risk), QA checks may be conducted less frequently (e.g. once in three years) and with limited scope, without validating either control design or operating effectiveness. Placing assurance on overall DBG or individual legal entity’s ICS adequacy and effectiveness without performing appropriate, risk-based QA activities on internal control effectiveness was considered inadequate.

Furthermore, while the ICS framework outlined a concept of “key” vs “standard” internal controls, there were no clear definitions of what a key control was and implications of classifying a control as either key or standard. 

Due to regulatory requirements, CSS entities have implemented a dedicated Risk & Control Assurance (LOD) as an independent unit, aimed to effectively assure senior management of CSS entities, that the control environment effectively manages risks or detects and remediates deficiencies. Similarly, other legal entities have established (e.g. CFCL, CFCS, CFCHK, LuxCSD) or intend to establish dedicated functions (e.g. CAL), whose responsibility includes testing the operating effectiveness of internal controls. For other legal entities where no similar functions/roles with this type of responsibility are present, no assurance can be provided about most of the ICS key controls’ adequacy and effectiveness. Additionally, CBL, CFCL and CFCS benefit from ISAE control assurance activities conducted by the external consultant, PricewaterhouseCoopers, which offer additional comfort about a qualitative control environment and validate the proper execution of 1st LoD controls. Nevertheless, considering the large number of key controls, the dedicated functions or external consultants are unable to test and validate operating effectiveness of all key controls.

IA also identified further areas for ICS framework improvement, which hindered ICS data QA activities execution for all legal entities in scope of the audit:

The current ICS framework focused on process-level individual risk assessment per single risk and did not define the correlation between a process’s risk assessment and its underlying sub-processes’ risk assessments. IA noted that in 109 cases (2% of total population), a process’s Inherent risk rating was lower than all its sub-processes’ Inherent risk ratings. On the contrary, in 801 cases (7% of total population), the process’s rating was unexplainably higher than all its sub-processes. 

IA acknowledges that the ICS framework positioned the “process risk assessment” as a purely indicative field, aimed to support individual risk assessment. It did not feed any reporting on the ICS in general or any ICS components. However, as “process risk assessment” fields were treated as purely indicative, IA noted they were not maintained adequately, resulting in same sub-processes’ Inherent risk rating inconsistencies.

The current ICS framework did not explicitly outline, which Process Map and Risk Control Matrix (RCM) fields should be treated as mandatory, which left room for different interpretations by readers, including various by ICS Experts in different Legal entities. As a result, up to 4% of all fields were left blank in Process Maps and RCMs. Three specific Process Map fields were left blank in 32% of all cases. 

Appendix B presents a comprehensive list of identified deficiencies.

Moreover, Annexes to ICS Policies of CBF, CBL, CS, CI, CH, all managed by Controls Assurance & Monitoring (ZFE), had not been reviewed since April 2022, despite their forming integral parts of the Policies and being subject to the annual review and update requirement.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires risk management and control processes ensure that material risks –including risks from outsourcing– are identified early, fully captured and adequately presented. Institutions should have an internal control system composed of rules and procedures aiming to ensure that the institutions’ objectives are reached, the resources are effectively used, and the risks are controlled. The ICS should facilitate Risk Management in challenging and supporting the business lines to implement risk management measures, ensuring that the first line of defence processes and controls are properly designed and effective. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE):
* revises the ICS framework (including the ICS Guideline) to outline minimum requirements for the regular evaluation of key internal controls by the individual legal entities’ ICS experts.
Among other, the minimum requirements should:
- define clear criteria for internal control key or standard classification;
- outline measures for maintaining consistency and alignment of key vs standard controls;
- define a specific assurance protocols/control assessments by Control Owners around key controls;
- specify existing ICS testing teams’ testing responsibilities (e.g. Risk & Control Assurance team (LOD)) around key internal controls;
- specify the mandatory fields in the different ICS components.
* specifies requirements for the legal entity ICS Experts’ ICS Effectiveness Report to management: the report shall give detail on effectiveness of key controls, including measures taken to conclude, results, identified deficiencies and mitigating actions.
* defines and communicates measures to ensure internal consistency checks on the formal quality of the documentation, in particular with regards to the redefined mandatory field of the ICS components. 		 7/4/2025 11/21/2025 11/21/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Elizaveta Veselova Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Group Risk Governance & ICS (U) Group Risk Governance and ICS (ZHE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Serious weaknesses in Internal Control System (ICS) bear the risk of ineffective risk monitoring and mitigation based on inconsistently collected data on processes, related key risks and associated key internal controls. Lack of internal control testing related especially to the key controls requirements may expose the company to inaccurate ICS effectiveness assessment and risk exposure information, which might increase the risk of inadequate conclusions by management on the overall ICS effectiveness. Furthermore, inaccurate or incomplete information on processes, risks, and controls could hinder the effectiveness of all functions using such information, including second and third line of defence functions. This represents a serious gap in internal provisions, which may result in insufficient operational risk management leading to operational errors and ultimately expose the company to major financial loss due to incorrect risk exposure determination.  Thomas Heinze ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Des. 2025-033_F02 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F02-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Third-Party Risk Management applications, Spice and the Register of Information (ROI), were not registered as applications in the APMS application inventory. Instead, they were recorded as IT components and used in the production environment to process live data.

These IT components were developed and clustered as components of the IT Application Office 365 (AID551). However, they were not defined or managed as standalone IT/ ICT assets.

IA also identified a lack of clear definition and governance for IT components as IT/ICT assets within both the 1LoD and 2LoD Frameworks. The ICT Frameworks, owned by Enterprise Architecture & Digital Innovation (ENA) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU), did not address the definition, classification, registration, or treatment of IT components and IT/ICT assets.

According to the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.0, all primary and secondary assets must be inventoried and subject to appropriate management controls. IA found that IT components were not defined as either primary or secondary assets, nor were they assigned any asset type classification.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require an up-to-date IT Application Repository that indicates the applications in use and assigns risks and responsibilities. Additionally, clear documentation and governance structures and controls around IT applications must be implemented.		 Analyse the situation regarding IT Components for Office 365 (AID551) and act according to the definition received from IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT). 9/30/2025 3/30/2026 3/30/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Daniel Hart Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Microsoft 365 Operations (U) Microsoft 365 Operations (ZFR) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components may lead to inconsistent, inaccurate and incomplete asset categorization which may result in the following shortcomings for the whole Group of having IT components that are not designed, documented, implemented, managed, assessed, or controlled according to internal written rules. Furthermore, it may lead to a lack of corresponding controls execution, management and reporting for the IT Components considered as possible IT Application. In addition, risk assessments on component-level are not performed. 
The components are not defined and are considered standalone applications with a dedicated Application ID (AID), lacking transparency on IT Applications in the Group.
Furthermore, a wrong categorization of critical production- related tools/ applications might lead to severe weaknesses in processes such as software license management, application security compliance and governance and the governance of the application portfolios
Not inventorying and managing IT/ICT assets correctly may result in serious adverse regulatory impact or serious reputational damage. It may also hinder existing external regulator's finding closures.		 Benoit Krier CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-033_F02 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F02-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Third-Party Risk Management applications, Spice and the Register of Information (ROI), were not registered as applications in the APMS application inventory. Instead, they were recorded as IT components and used in the production environment to process live data.

These IT components were developed and clustered as components of the IT Application Office 365 (AID551). However, they were not defined or managed as standalone IT/ ICT assets.

IA also identified a lack of clear definition and governance for IT components as IT/ICT assets within both the 1LoD and 2LoD Frameworks. The ICT Frameworks, owned by Enterprise Architecture & Digital Innovation (ENA) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU), did not address the definition, classification, registration, or treatment of IT components and IT/ICT assets.

According to the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.0, all primary and secondary assets must be inventoried and subject to appropriate management controls. IA found that IT components were not defined as either primary or secondary assets, nor were they assigned any asset type classification.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require an up-to-date IT Application Repository that indicates the applications in use and assigns risks and responsibilities. Additionally, clear documentation and governance structures and controls around IT applications must be implemented. Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components may lead to inconsistent, inaccurate and incomplete asset categorization which may result in the following shortcomings for the whole Group of having IT components that are not designed, documented, implemented, managed, assessed, or controlled according to internal written rules. Furthermore, it may lead to a lack of corresponding controls execution, management and reporting for the IT Components considered as possible IT Application. In addition, risk assessments on component-level are not performed. 
The components are not defined and are considered standalone applications with a dedicated Application ID (AID), lacking transparency on IT Applications in the Group.
Furthermore, a wrong categorization of critical production- related tools/ applications might lead to severe weaknesses in processes such as software license management, application security compliance and governance and the governance of the application portfolios

Aymon Delbridge CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op.
