2025-033_F02 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S3 Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Third-Party Risk Management applications, Spice and the Register of Information (ROI), were not registered as applications in the APMS application inventory. Instead, they were recorded as IT components and used in the production environment to process live data.

These IT components were developed and clustered as components of the IT Application Office 365 (AID551). However, they were not defined or managed as standalone IT/ ICT assets.

IA also identified a lack of clear definition and governance for IT components as IT/ICT assets within both the 1LoD and 2LoD Frameworks. The ICT Frameworks, owned by Enterprise Architecture & Digital Innovation (ENA) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU), did not address the definition, classification, registration, or treatment of IT components and IT/ICT assets.

According to the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.0, all primary and secondary assets must be inventoried and subject to appropriate management controls. IA found that IT components were not defined as either primary or secondary assets, nor were they assigned any asset type classification.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require an up-to-date IT Application Repository that indicates the applications in use and assigns risks and responsibilities. Additionally, clear documentation and governance structures and controls around IT applications must be implemented.		 Incorporate the definition from Enterprise Architecture & Digital Innovation (ENA) in the KJU ICT Framework/Guidelines and publish them to the 1LoD for awareness. 9/30/2025 1/23/2026 1/23/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Daniel Hart Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of definition, adequate classification and governance of IT Components may lead to inconsistent, inaccurate and incomplete asset categorization which may result in the following shortcomings for the whole Group of having IT components that are not designed, documented, implemented, managed, assessed, or controlled according to internal written rules. Furthermore, it may lead to a lack of corresponding controls execution, management and reporting for the IT Components considered as possible IT Application. In addition, risk assessments on component-level are not performed. 
The components are not defined and are considered standalone applications with a dedicated Application ID (AID), lacking transparency on IT Applications in the Group.
Furthermore, a wrong categorization of critical production- related tools/ applications might lead to severe weaknesses in processes such as software license management, application security compliance and governance and the governance of the application portfolios
Not inventorying and managing IT/ICT assets correctly may result in serious adverse regulatory impact or serious reputational damage. It may also hinder existing external regulator's finding closures.		 Sarah Ahmad Jahn CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2022-027_F12 2022 2022-027 Cyber & Information Security [DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL] 2022-027_F12-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of adherence to min. control requirements and definition of roles and responsibilities for IAM According to EMIR RTS 153 Article 4, “a CCP shall have adequate internal control mechanisms to assist the board in monitoring and assessing the adequacy and effectiveness of a its risk management policies, procedures and systems.”
Moreover, according to BaFin Supervisory Requirements for IT in Financial Institutions (BAIT) 2.2 “the management is responsible for ensuring that the regulations governing the IT structure and IT process organization are defined on the basis of the IT strategy and that they are adjusted promptly in the event of changes to activities and processes. It must be ensured that these regulations are implemented effectively.” According to CSSF Circular 20/750, point 31“Financial institutions should define, document and implement procedures for logical access control (identity and access management). These procedures should be implemented, enforced, monitored and periodically reviewed. The procedures should also include controls for monitoring anomalies”

The unit Identity & Access Management (ICA) created the Identity and Access Management Guideline V1.3.2. The aim of this guideline is to define an IAM framework and access handling for DBG. The guideline distinguishes between responsibilities for each IAM topic depending on the onboarding status to SailPoint IIQ (AID760) of the target applications (e.g. in most cases Group Security is accountable/responsible if the asset is onboarded, respectively the asset owner is accountable/responsible if the asset is not onboarded).

Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the control environment of the 1st line of defence (LoD):
§ Lack of clarity of responsibility to adhere to information security standards issued by Information Security Framework & Governance (ISFG) on topics such as Identity and Access Management (IAM).
§ Lack of clear definition of roles and responsibilities for execution and monitoring of the above-mentioned control requirements.

As a result of the above-mentioned weaknesses in the control environment, Internal Audit detected several cases where asset owners may not have fully met their responsibilities and this was not identified by the current first line control approach, neither in ICA nor in the affected Product IT teams:
§ Reconciliation: aim of the reconciliation is to check if authorisation managed/approved in IIQ correctly reflect the actually assigned authorisation in the target systems. Nevertheless, depending on the connector between IIQ and target application, IIQ may not be able to directly analyse the assigned authorisation within the target application. For example, with the Onboard Administrator Active Directory (OAAD) connector, IIQ is only able to reconcile based on the assigned Active Directory workgroups, whereas additional authorisation directly assigned within the target application would not be identified. A control to detect such bypasses is not established.
§ Usage of central IAM IIQ processes: the onboarding of a target application to IIQ is supported by ICA. After the successful onboarding, the central IAM processes provided by IIQ itself (e.g. provisioning request, recertification etc.) have to be used for/by the target application. Nevertheless, a control (e.g. plausibility check) is not required and not established to monitor if the asset owner of the target application indeed uses the IAM processes provided by IIQ.
Internal Audit noted at least one productive business application which was onboarded for several months without having assigned any users to the onboarded authorisations.
Onboarding status of this business application has been reset during the audit. New planned onboarding finalisation target is February 2023.
§ Completeness of authorisations: as part of the onboarding process, all available target application authorisation are implemented in IIQ. Nevertheless, no central IAM control (e.g. plausibility check) existed to monitor authorisation added to the target application after onboarding, and not published to IIQ. Internal Audit noted that, for the business application C7 (AID021), a mismatch existed between the onboarded IIQ roles and roles actually available in C7. Internal Audit further noted procedures did not require such control be established.
This was due to a change management process omission (no IIQ update for C7) upon implementing ECC roles in C7 subsequent to the initial C7 onboarding to IIQ in September 2019.
The annual C7 risk assessment process (RAP-3570) started in parallel to our audit, with due date 13 December 2022. It identified the missing ECC roles/business users onboarding to IIQ as a risk and started mitigation activities (completion planned by 30 June 2023). Therefore, Internal Audit issued no additional recommendation. An exceptional risk ticket has been created (ISRM-92912).		 Internal Audit recommends IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) to implement oversight and quality assurance measures to ensure the implementation of the Identity and Access Management requirements that will address the weaknesses in the above-mentioned description.
Depending on the outcome of recommendation 2022-027_F12-A01, ownership and due date of this recommendation may be changed to align with the newly defined owner and related corrective action plan after framework definition.		 12/22/2022 6/10/2024 12/31/2025 1 CBL Luxembourg,CBL Singapore Branch,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Karl Ulber Anna Stadlinger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Peter Heidkamp IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of adherence to minimum control requirements and definition of roles and responsibilities for IAM in first Line of Defence represents a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the information security framework. This could lead to regulatory risks (e.g. BAIT 6.5) as well as operational risks (such as the detailed deficiencies identified above, which may in turn result in incorrect or obsolete access rights remaining undetected, facilitating misuse or operational incidents). Peter Heidkamp CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MICHAEL SCHMIRLER(CS Luxembourg),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),THEODOR WEIMER(Group IT Audit),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Singapore Branch) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Yes Yes No No No No Yes
2024-051_F08 2024 2024-051 Corporate Governance (DBAG, ECAG) 2024-051_F08-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of and inconsistencies in risk strategies Internal Audit (IA) noted that EFAG risk strategy, that shall serve as basis for risk management framework and support for EFAG business strategy, was in draft and not yet approved by EFAG Executive Board.
Moreover, IA noted inconsistencies in Business Risk assessments, based on review of the following EFAG and ECAG strategies:
▪
2024 Eurex Corporate Strategy (EFAG Business Strategy) and draft Eurex Frankfurt AG Risk Strategy - In capacity as Exchange Operator for Eurex Deutschland (ED), version 1 (draft EFAG Risk Strategy)
▪
Eurex Clearing Business Strategy 2024 (ECAG Business Strategy) and Eurex Clearing Risk Strategy, version 4.2 (ECAG Risk Strategy)
Namely, in both draft EFAG and approved ECAG Risk Strategy, Business Risk was assessed as not applicable. The assessment resulted from the annual Risk Inventory process and was based on implemented Group risk quantification approach, Risk Appetite Framework and Value-at-Risk (VaR) model. However, this was not in line with the risk assessments available in respective EFAG Business Strategy and ECAG Business Strategy, outlining the Business Risks (Regulatory and Macroeconomic risks) as material.
IA learned that risk assessment in business strategies follows “gross” approach, meaning that material risks are those that negatively impact entity’s financial targets prior to considering operating agreements and transfer of revenues to shareholders. However, no clear rationale for deviations in materiality assessments was provided in strategic and process documents.
Identified issue was caused by incorrect interpretation of regulatory requirements.
In line with external and internal provisions, management must implement appropriate arrangements and systems to identify all significant risks to its operation, and to put in place effective measures to mitigate those risks. Risk strategies should be consistent with business strategies and provide support in reaching strategic goals by identifying, assessing and managing resulting risks.		 Internal Audit recommends that Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) aligns the risk strategy with ECAG business strategy by providing justification, in sufficient level of details, for ECAG Business Strategy risk assessment results and any deviations between business strategy and risk strategy.  12/13/2024 6/15/2025 12/31/2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Ana Kosela Iryna Neurath THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Clearing (A) Erik Tim Müller Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of and inconsistencies in risk strategies may lead to inadequate identification and management of main risks impacting strategic goals and success of the business strategies. This can lead to material financial and operational losses and represents a breach of regulatory and internal requirements. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Unawareness/ Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No Yes No No
2024-043_F01 2024 2024-043 Project Controlling (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-043_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening The existing Project Portfolio Management (PPM) functions for ECAG and EFAG within the Strategy & Initiatives team (ZDS) should be strengthened. At the time of the audit, ZDS performed only a high-level project monitoring. ZDS included projects in the portfolio that met the financial materiality threshold of €5 million. For EFAG no projects qualified during the audited period and therefore no monitoring took place. For ECAG, the monitoring took place via the monthly jour-fixe meeting in which Clarity one-pagers for each monitored project and the portfolio risk heatmap were collated by ECAG PPM and a brief status update was given verbally in the meeting by each project manager. ECAG PPM also checked for the existence of key project documents. However, ZDS did not perform any controlling functions, only monitoring. Only one individual from each entity was responsible for executing this project-level monitoring. 

Further, there was no budget controlling process in place for projects. ZDS only monitored on the basis of a Key Risk indicator (KRI) to determine if an overall project portfolio budget overrun of more than 5% had occurred. For EFAG this KRI monitoring process was not documented. There was no controlling process in place to identify, analyse variances, evaluate their impact, ensure corrective actions were taken and escalate large variances or discrepancies that could not be resolved. Neither was there a process to forecast future costs and potential over/underruns, nor to perform headroom analyses.

The main benefits of an empowered PPM function were not realised. The authority was absent to ensure strategic alignment, optimise resource allocation, assess and manage portfolio risks and provide a structured framework for project management. Specifically, the following important PPM functions were missing from the mandate: 
 - Strategic alignment: align projects with an organisation's strategic objectives and business goals and ensure that resources are allocated to projects that contribute most to the company's overall strategy and vision.
 - Efficient resource allocation: provide visibility into resource availability and utilisation to prevent overburdening of staff and ensure the right people are assigned to the right tasks.
 - Portfolio risk management: implement a comprehensive risk management approach at the portfolio level to identify risks that could impact multiple projects or the entire portfolio and assess interdependencies and cumulative risks across projects.
 - Governance structure: establish a clear governance framework that defines roles, responsibilities and processes to facilitate transparent and consistent project management processes across the portfolio.

Internal Audit identified the root cause of the above identified weaknesses as an inadequate governance structure.

German and European regulation as well as internal policies require a suitable and transparent organisational structure and adequate internal governance. Internal documentation should include, but not be limited to, a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Accounting standards require businesses to maintain accurate financial records, to faithfully represent the effects of transactions and prepare an analysis of expenses. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) update the ECAG Project Portfolio Management (PPM) framework to:
 - implement and document a project budget controlling process for ECAG
 - deliberate with legal entity and department senior and executive management on the appropriate mandate for the PPM function for ECAG, considering the benefits of an empowered PPM
 - implement and document any changes to the PPM mandate agreed with management 		 11/19/2024 6/13/2025 12/31/2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Robert Pardikes Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Trading & Clearing Strategy / Chie (Dpt) Eric Leupold Strategy & Initiatives (U) Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening, as the current approach could lead to suboptimised project delivery, increased risk of project failures, inefficient use of organisational resources and reduced ability to maximise business value from the project portfolio. These risks could lead to material adverse regulatory impact, material reputational damage and minor financial impact.  Thomas Koivu MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Yes Yes No Yes No No No
2024-043_F01 2024 2024-043 Project Controlling (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-043_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening The existing Project Portfolio Management (PPM) functions for ECAG and EFAG within the Strategy & Initiatives team (ZDS) should be strengthened. At the time of the audit, ZDS performed only a high-level project monitoring. ZDS included projects in the portfolio that met the financial materiality threshold of €5 million. For EFAG no projects qualified during the audited period and therefore no monitoring took place. For ECAG, the monitoring took place via the monthly jour-fixe meeting in which Clarity one-pagers for each monitored project and the portfolio risk heatmap were collated by ECAG PPM and a brief status update was given verbally in the meeting by each project manager. ECAG PPM also checked for the existence of key project documents. However, ZDS did not perform any controlling functions, only monitoring. Only one individual from each entity was responsible for executing this project-level monitoring. 

Further, there was no budget controlling process in place for projects. ZDS only monitored on the basis of a Key Risk indicator (KRI) to determine if an overall project portfolio budget overrun of more than 5% had occurred. For EFAG this KRI monitoring process was not documented. There was no controlling process in place to identify, analyse variances, evaluate their impact, ensure corrective actions were taken and escalate large variances or discrepancies that could not be resolved. Neither was there a process to forecast future costs and potential over/underruns, nor to perform headroom analyses.

The main benefits of an empowered PPM function were not realised. The authority was absent to ensure strategic alignment, optimise resource allocation, assess and manage portfolio risks and provide a structured framework for project management. Specifically, the following important PPM functions were missing from the mandate: 
 - Strategic alignment: align projects with an organisation's strategic objectives and business goals and ensure that resources are allocated to projects that contribute most to the company's overall strategy and vision.
 - Efficient resource allocation: provide visibility into resource availability and utilisation to prevent overburdening of staff and ensure the right people are assigned to the right tasks.
 - Portfolio risk management: implement a comprehensive risk management approach at the portfolio level to identify risks that could impact multiple projects or the entire portfolio and assess interdependencies and cumulative risks across projects.
 - Governance structure: establish a clear governance framework that defines roles, responsibilities and processes to facilitate transparent and consistent project management processes across the portfolio.

Internal Audit identified the root cause of the above identified weaknesses as an inadequate governance structure.

German and European regulation as well as internal policies require a suitable and transparent organisational structure and adequate internal governance. Internal documentation should include, but not be limited to, a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Accounting standards require businesses to maintain accurate financial records, to faithfully represent the effects of transactions and prepare an analysis of expenses. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) update the EFAG Project Portfolio Management (PPM) framework to:
 - implement and document a project budget controlling process for EFAG projects
 - deliberate with legal entity and department senior and executive management on the appropriate mandate for the PPM function for EFAG, considering the benefits of an empowered PPM
 - implement and document any changes to the PPM mandate agreed with management 		 11/19/2024 6/13/2025 12/31/2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Frankfurt AG Gianluca Tripepi Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) ROBBERT BOOIJ Trading & Clearing (Div) Trading & Clearing Strategy / Chie (Dpt) Eric Leupold Strategy & Initiatives (U) Strategy & Initiatives (ZDS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Eurex Project Portfolio Management function requires strengthening, as the current approach could lead to suboptimised project delivery, increased risk of project failures, inefficient use of organisational resources and reduced ability to maximise business value from the project portfolio. These risks could lead to material adverse regulatory impact, material reputational damage and minor financial impact.  Thomas Koivu MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Control Des. 2024-041_F01 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of oversight & considerations for backup replication performance in applications hosted on GCP Internal Audit identified that :
The internal written rules did not specify requirements for cloud-hosted applications’ backup replication to on-premise or to other Cloud Service Provider (CSP) environments.
Specifically:
▪ In cases where critical data was hosted in the cloud, an oversight control was missing to enforce the replication of backups to on-premise or to another CSP.
▪ Out of the ten sampled applications, two applications (one “Critical”, and one “Minor”) did not have backup replication on-premise or to
another CSP.
▪ The “Critical” application Terraform Enterprise (AID768) only had partial on-premise backups (Infrastructure as Code of the
applications was stored in GitHub, which had an on-premise backup, as well as the setup of Terraform enterprise itself).

The above-mentioned deficiencies were caused by the absence of clear guidelines and criteria pertaining to cloud backup strategy.

Germany and Luxembourg regulation require that supplier redundancies are adequately considered and implemented.		 Internal Audit recommends IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) to establish suitable metrics and monitoring measures to identify and manage deviations from above requirements/criteria. 12/6/2024 4/30/2026 4/30/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro Shravankumar Mohankumar GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of considerations and oversight over the performance of cloud backup replications could result in critical cloud data not being backed up on-premises or to another CSP, resulting in unrecoverable data loss in case of a complete CSP failure. This in turn, could result in material violation of external provisions and regulatory requirements. It is acknowledged that a complete outage of a CSP is unlikely as CSPs are designed with very high levels of redundancies and resilience.  Boris Link ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KIEßLING ANJA(European Energy Exchange),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Unawareness/ Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No Yes No No
2024-041_F01 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of oversight & considerations for backup replication performance in applications hosted on GCP Internal Audit identified that :
The internal written rules did not specify requirements for cloud-hosted applications’ backup replication to on-premise or to other Cloud Service Provider (CSP) environments.
Specifically:
▪ In cases where critical data was hosted in the cloud, an oversight control was missing to enforce the replication of backups to on-premise or to another CSP.
▪ Out of the ten sampled applications, two applications (one “Critical”, and one “Minor”) did not have backup replication on-premise or to
another CSP.
▪ The “Critical” application Terraform Enterprise (AID768) only had partial on-premise backups (Infrastructure as Code of the
applications was stored in GitHub, which had an on-premise backup, as well as the setup of Terraform enterprise itself).

The above-mentioned deficiencies were caused by the absence of clear guidelines and criteria pertaining to cloud backup strategy.

Germany and Luxembourg regulation require that supplier redundancies are adequately considered and implemented.		 Internal Audit recommends Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) to implement suitable technical solutions, that provide capability to allow application owners to replicate cloud data backups on-premises or to another CSP. 12/6/2024 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro Shravankumar Mohankumar GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Technology Officer (A) Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Lack of considerations and oversight over the performance of cloud backup replications could result in critical cloud data not being backed up on-premises or to another CSP, resulting in unrecoverable data loss in case of a complete CSP failure. This in turn, could result in material violation of external provisions and regulatory requirements. It is acknowledged that a complete outage of a CSP is unlikely as CSPs are designed with very high levels of redundancies and resilience.  Sebastian Wedeniwski ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KIEßLING ANJA(European Energy Exchange),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Unawareness/ Unclarity of Reg. 2024-041_F02 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F02-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Missing guidance for requirements to  perform penetration tests prior to cloud application go-live Internal Audit identified that seven out of ten sampled applications had not undergone a penetration test prior to going live on Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Section 3.1 of Vulnerability Management Standard v4.0 mandated that penetration tests of all IT Applications and
Infrastructure assets must be conducted upfront before initial go-live, and whenever security relevant changes are released into production.
Security-relevant changes were broadly defined as “any change to a system configuration, information content or functionality, which has the potential to change the information security risk status”. The underlying infrastructure change would fall under this definition, even when applications were only “lift-and-shifted” without functional changes to the application code.

Factors that have contributed to this finding include:
▪ Unclear guidance from Group Security (ZZA) as to whether and under which conditions penetration tests would be required for “lift
and shift” migrations.
▪ Misunderstanding that penetration tests would only be required upon application changes, not infrastructure changes, and consequently assumption that previous penetration tests on the application within the last 12 months would still be valid.
▪ Assumption that Google Cloud Platform Penetration Testing (which was executed once a year) would be sufficient to address the
infrastructure changes.
▪ Assumption that the need for penetration testing would be identified or advised by the Security cross-stream or through the Major Change Process.

German and Luxembourg regulation as noted below require that applications are subject to penetration testing to ensure identification of
vulnerabilities. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Cyber Protection & Automation (IFB), in liaison with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT), analyse and establish clear criteria for performing penetration tests and amend as necessary the written rules as a long-term measure. Specifically, it should be ensured that the requirements are sufficiently specific if a differentiation between application penetration testing, and platform penetration testing is intended. Potential requirement exemptions (e.g. for “lift and shift” migrations) need to be clearly defined and delineated to prevent misinterpretation. 12/6/2024 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro Shravankumar Mohankumar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Cyber Protection & Automation (S) Cyber Protection & Automation (IFB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation Missing guidance for requirements to perform penetration tests prior to cloud application go-live could result in penetration tests not being performed. Hence vulnerabilities introduced during the migration process or in the cloud infrastructure setup could remain undetected and unmitigated. This could result in material violation of internal and external provisions and regulatory requirements.  Sibylle Hick CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Unawareness/ Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2024-041_F03 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of a funded action plan to remediate MS Azure related Self-Identified Issues Eight Self-Identified Issues (SII), related to deficiencies within DBG’s MS Azure environment as reported in the 2023-020 “MS Azure – Central Services, Security in the Cloud and Vendor Management” audit, were expected to be addressed as part of the Hyperion Program. A detailed implementation plan should had been in place by October 2023. The severity ratings of the SIIs were one S3, six S2 and one S1.

Internal Audit recognized that the Hyperion Program had meanwhile been restricted exclusively to Google Cloud. As a result, limited progress had been made in relation to Azure. Particularly, Azure IAM, PAM and Cyber Protection-related SIIs with severity S2 had been put on hold.

Though no concrete Secure Landing Zone implementation plans, or budgetary provisions were available at the time of the audit, tentative
high-level plans were created upon IA request. IA acknowledges the SIIs had a due date of December 2025 but was unable to opine on the feasibility due to the lack of detailed plans.
The Hyperion project's exclusive focus on GCP has caused the SIIs and associated deficiencies for Microsoft Azure to remain unresolved.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation as noted below require that adequate and robust security controls are in place to secure the cloud workloads. 		 Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer (ZFJ) to collaborate with Group Security (ZZA) to ensure adequate closure of the SIIs noted in 2023-020 report. 12/6/2024 1/31/2026 1/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Shravankumar Mohankumar Shravankumar Mohankumar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of a funded action plan to remediate MS Azure related SIIs may result in delays in the remediation of the identified deficiencies
pertaining to absence of preventive, detective and runtime security features for workloads onboarded to the Azure Cloud Estate. This could manifest in a weakened Azure Cloud security posture, potentially resulting in a material violation of applicable internal and external regulatory requirements. 		 Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Control Des. + Control Op. 2024-041_F03 2024 2024-041 Project Hyperion (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-041_F03-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of a funded action plan to remediate MS Azure related Self-Identified Issues Eight Self-Identified Issues (SII), related to deficiencies within DBG’s MS Azure environment as reported in the 2023-020 “MS Azure – Central Services, Security in the Cloud and Vendor Management” audit, were expected to be addressed as part of the Hyperion Program. A detailed implementation plan should had been in place by October 2023. The severity ratings of the SIIs were one S3, six S2 and one S1.

Internal Audit recognized that the Hyperion Program had meanwhile been restricted exclusively to Google Cloud. As a result, limited progress had been made in relation to Azure. Particularly, Azure IAM, PAM and Cyber Protection-related SIIs with severity S2 had been put on hold.

Though no concrete Secure Landing Zone implementation plans, or budgetary provisions were available at the time of the audit, tentative
high-level plans were created upon IA request. IA acknowledges the SIIs had a due date of December 2025 but was unable to opine on the feasibility due to the lack of detailed plans.
The Hyperion project's exclusive focus on GCP has caused the SIIs and associated deficiencies for Microsoft Azure to remain unresolved.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation as noted below require that adequate and robust security controls are in place to secure the cloud workloads. 		 Internal Audit recommends Group Security (ZZA) to collaborate with
Chief Cloud Officer (ZFJ) to ensure adequate closure of the SIIs noted
in 2023-020 report.		 12/6/2024 1/31/2026 1/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Shravankumar Mohankumar Shravankumar Mohankumar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Group Security (Dpt) Group Security (ZZA) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and

2024-056_F03 2024 2024-056 Physical security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2024-056_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Non-compliance with encryption policy requirements for CCTV data transmission Internal Audit (IA) noted that the communication between the video cameras and the Closed-Circuit Television (CCTV) servers hosting the Honeywell Digital Video Manager (DVM) software was not encrypted.

 

IA identified the root cause of the identified issue as human error/omission.

 

The DBG CISO Technological Security Standard requires the encryption of data during transmission within the internal network, especially for information classified as “strictly confidential” or “confidential”.

 

Article 36 of the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management requires the encryption of data at rest and in transit in accordance with the data classification. In Luxembourg, compliance with these EBA guidelines is enforced by the CSSF, while in Germany, the BaFin has incorporated them into their regulatory framework through the Banking Supervisory Requirements for IT (BAIT), based on the Minimum Requirements for Risk Management (MaRisk). 		 Internal Audit recommends that Physical Security (FSE) implements encryption protocols for data in transit between the CCTV cameras and the DVM servers.  12/17/2024 6/12/2026 6/12/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Xavier Karthaeuser Xavier Karthaeuser CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Non-compliance with encryption policy requirements for CCTV data transmission may expose the company to several risks, including:

risk of non-compliance with internal and external provisions

risk of interception by unauthorised parties and access to sensitive footage, potentially exposing private information about individuals (Personally Identifiable Information)

This may result in a material adverse regulatory impact, minor financial impact or material reputational damage. 		 David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Human Error/ Omission Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No No No Yes
2024-056_F05 2024 2024-056 Physical security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2024-056_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Outdated and incomplete Physical Security documentation Internal Audit (IA) noted that several internal documents related to Physical Security were outdated and did not reflect the transfer of Threat Intelligence and Travel Risk Management from Physical Security (FSE) to Cyber Defense (CBD) as of 1 March 2023:

DBG’s Physical Security Standard, Section 4.4 contained still "Intelligence & Travel Risk Management" although last updated in October 2023.

All intra-group outsourcing agreements for Physical Security services still included FSE’s responsibility for “Intelligence and Travel Risk Management” in chapter 3 Detailed Service Description.

The Threat Intelligence and Travel Risk Management processes were still part of FSE's Risk and Control Matrix (RCM) and Process Map.

 

Furthermore, IA noted that the Process Manual Physical Access Control, last reviewed in March 2023, was outdated. The processes described were still based on the Multifunctional Operating Centre (MOC) system which was linked to Hydra but not to the Honeywell EBI system. Hydra was only operational at Hausen1; all other locations have transitioned to Honeywell.

 

Additionally, IA observed that the Process Handbook for Visitor Management lacked several critical topics required by the Physical Security Standard (specifically in the section on Physical Site Security & Event Risk Management – Reception Services):

The Handbook did not specify the need for receptionist staff to register status changes (e.g., checked-in/checked-out) in the Proxyclick application, which was essential for tracking visitors within the building.

The Handbook did not clarify the receptionists' responsibility to inform visitors about the security requirements and emergency procedures indicated on the back of their badges.

The receptionists were unaware that the emergency procedures were indicated on the back of the visitor badges.

The Handbook failed to address the escorting requirements for DBG data centre server rooms.

 

Also, the Handbook did not include procedures for handling visitors from law enforcement authorities (e.g., those with search warrants). The Handbook should either incorporate the Guideline for Official Searches procedure developed by Group Legal (GCA) or provide a link to it.

 

Furthermore, although the Physical Security procedures (i.e., the Process Handbook on Technical Security, the Specific Procedures on site “The Square” and the Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube”) outlined several steps and processes for managing non-functioning cameras, they did not explicitly detail a specific process for analysing the risks associated to camera downtimes. A procedure for identifying and implementing risk mitigating controls during such downtimes was not defined.

 

In addition, several key topics related to visitor management, specifically blacklist procedures and entry/accompany regulations, were not addressed in the procedure titled Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube”.

 

Finally, during the 2024-079 CFCL Cork Branch audit, Internal Audit identified a finding relevant to all DBG legal entities: the Process Manual Physical Access Control did not document the existing process for offboarding external contractors.

 

IA identified the root cause of the identified issues as human error/omission, and lack of awareness of group/cross functional processes.

 

External and internal provisions require the institution to ensure that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines (e.g., manuals, work instructions or workflow descriptions), and that the guidelines are swiftly amended in the event of changes to the activities and processes. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Physical Security (FSE):

updates the Physical Security Standard, intra-group outsourcing agreements, Risk and Control Matrix (RCM), and Process Map to reflect the transfer of responsibilities to Cyber Defense (CBD)

revises the Process Manual Physical Access Control to reflect the current procedures based on the Honeywell EBI system and ensures that it accurately describes the processes in use across all locations

revises the Process Handbook for Visitor Management to include guidelines for receptionist staff to register status changes, requirements for informing visitors about security protocols and emergency procedures (as indicated on the back of their badges), guidelines for escorting visitors in the DBG data center server rooms, information on handling law enforcement authorities, including the Guideline for Official Searches developed by Group Legal, or a link to it, ensuring this guideline is integrated into the Physical Security process

updates the Physical Security procedures for assessing the risks associated with non-functioning cameras as well as the risk mitigation strategies during camera downtime. This should include criteria for evaluating the potential impact on security, safety and operational continuity

revises the procedure Besondere Dienstanweisung für den Objektschutz und Empfangsdienst in der Liegenschaft der “The Cube” to include comprehensive guidelines on blacklist procedures and entry/accompany regulations. These guidelines should align with best practices

updates the Process Manual Physical Access Control to document the offboarding process for external contractors 		 12/17/2024 12/12/2025 12/12/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Denise Weigelt Xavier Karthaeuser CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Outdated and incomplete Physical Security documentation bears the risk of operational errors and inefficiencies (e.g., inconsistent visitor handling or insufficient handling of surveillance interruptions, potentially compromising the security of the premises during periods when cameras are non-functional) resulting from unclear defined roles and responsibilities as well as non-compliance with regulations.

This may result in a material adverse regulatory impact, minor financial impact or material reputational damage. 		 David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Human Error/ Omission Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No No Yes
2024-065_F07 2024 2024-065 Compliance (incl. AML & CTF) (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-065_F07-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Conflict of Interests (CoI) framework Internal Audit (IA) noted that the Employee Compliance Assessment Tool application (ECAT), (AID700) managed by Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG), distinguished between an employee’s personal outside business interests (Personal CoI) and Conflicts of Interests (CoI) related to business activities (Corporate CoI). In both cases, the CoIs had to be disclosed by a DBG individual in the Employee Compliance Portal (ECP). Personal CoIs are associated to individuals, whereas Corporate CoIs were linked to an entity or organisation.

Besides, IA identified the 1st LoD insufficient awareness on the process specifics and lack of line managers’ pre-approval process for Corporate CoIs. As of November 2024, Corporate conflict assessment was not performed by the line manager, but only by ZJG as independent 2LoD. For secondary employment (personal CoI), where the assessment also includes a review by the line manager as well as HR, before ZJG performs a conflict assessment.

IA identified, during previous audits and reviews, the following issues that were directly addressed to the owners of the CoIs:
§ different personal CoIs may trigger one transversal CoI at the activity level (reorganisation of Clearstream Group Credit activities). IA also did not observe any additional analysis to identify any connections between these transversal cases.
§ cases where the concerned persons did not notify interests entailing (potential) CoIs to ZJG (e.g. potential conflicts in relation to the Credit Crisis Management Team).

The main root cause identified for the above-mentioned cases was a lack of awareness, adherence to the Policy and processes in place.

Additionally, IA observed that the current ECP setup only allows CoI-related information to be linked to individual names and not specific roles in case of Corporate CoI.

The identified issues were mainly caused by inadequate controls, technical restrictions in the Employee Compliance Portal, as well as complexity and volume of operations.

In line with European, German and Luxembourg regulations, the CoI framework shall outline procedures for identifying, assessing, managing and mitigating potential CoI to prevent unjustified consequences for the institution, counterparties and customers. Moreover, the framework shall outline the reporting and escalation procedures withing the institution. Staff members must be able promptly inform and involve their senior managers if they encounter a CoI.		 Internal Audit recommends that Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG) enhance the Conflict of Interests (CoI) framework by:
§ incorporating practical examples on Corporate CoIs as part of the regular Group Compliance training
§ extending the requirement for Line Manager pre-approval of CoIs to additional groups/sub-categories of interests that do not contain private information but may impact the direct work environment
§ involving line managers in the periodic review of CoIs impacting their business line
§ assessing the technical feasibility of linking CoI related information to a specific role, ensuring the previous CoIs are retained in the event of a Line Manager change		 12/16/2024 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,ISS-STOXX GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Nadezda Savchenkova Vladan Simunovic HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT Governance, People & Culture (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Employee & Securities Compliance (U) Employee & Securities Compliance (ZJG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation, provided that sufficient resources and technical solutions supporting the procedural changes are available. Weaknesses in the Conflict of Interests` (CoI) framework bear the risk of incomplete CoI registers reported to regulators. This could lead to material violation of external and internal provisions and could expose DBG to extra regulatory examinations, limited reputational damage and a minor financial loss. Katja Röhle ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),ERIK TIM MÜLLER(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK PRASSE(ISS-STOXX GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure Control Des. + Control Op. 2024-077_F01 2024 2024-077 Identity and Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, ECC, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-077_F01-A02 Recommendation Open S2 Insufficient Governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain During a review of the DBG Active Directory (AD) Groups, which is used to manage network resources and provides centralised authentication and authorisation, Internal Audit (IA) noted that:
§ Guidelines to ensure the consistent rollout of access management, procedures among the AD Groups were missing.
§ AD groups within OAAD were inadequately managed. IA noted that from the 60474 known AD Groups managed by IT SecOps,
- 11159 (18%) did not have a designated owner.
- of these 11159 ADs, 8547 (14%) were not onboarded to CyberArk or IIQ and 1114 of them are potentially PAM relevant.
- 1483 (2.5%) AD Groups were being populated and in use. Affected applications included, among others, Artifactory (AID283), Blueprism (AID425), ESET Easy Protect (AID959), O365 (AID551), MTS.nom (AID530), Jenkins (AID286), Fortify (AID985).

IA noted Project Luna is in progress and aims to streamline the Domain Forest structure and create guidelines for management of Active Directories. Review of the governance of active directories showed no evidence of severe issues due to the lack of governance.

Insufficient Governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain was attributed to Inadequate Governance Structure.

In line with the German and Luxembourg regulations and internal requirements, organisations are required to implement strong access management controls over elevated system access entitlements (e.g., Administrator Accounts). An entity shall use standardised processes and controls to effectively support access control tasks. Also, user access rights concept shall ensure that users are assigned access rights according to the need-to-know and least privileged principles. Adequate controls and processes should be in place to ensure enforcement of access revocation or adjustments in case a user moves within the organisation due to an organisational shift or transfer		 Internal Audit recommends that Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ reviews the existing ADs objects in OAAD and identify the correct owners and applications
§ removes the regional office AD directories
§ migrates technical accounts to the new AD design
§ migrates groups to new AD design		 12/18/2024 5/15/2026 5/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Kevin Gregory Floro Akhilesh Dhancholia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Inn (U) Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficient governance of AD Groups under OAAD Domain may:
§ lead to granting access to users who no longer need it, increasing the risk of unauthorised access.
§ result in a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the Information Security Framework.
This could lead to extra reporting requirements and regulatory examinations as well as operational risks, for example, obsolete access rights remaining undetected due to inadequate/ineffective recertification processes which could be misused to perform unauthorised activities.		 Geoffrey Saint-Alary CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. 2024-078_F02 2024 2024-078 Privileged Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-078_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Lack of processing controls and escalation mechanism for Privileged Account Inventory The Privileged Account Inventory (PAI, AID928) was implemented to ensure and measure proper onboarding to CyberArk (AID756) as well as compliance with internal and external requirements for privileged accounts.

PAI is based on two major input sources: Configuration Management Database (CMDB) data for relevant IT-assets within Deutsche Börse Group (servers, databases, storage and network assets) as well as the information from respective IT-asset owners with privileged accounts for those assets. PAI then compares e.g. if all reported privileged accounts from the asset owners are onboarded to CyberArk.

Via inspection of CMDB input data processing within PAI, Internal Audit noted:
§ Input controls: no controls were established to review the error log and correct errors within PAI. Between 1 September and 21 October 2024, the log recorded 132 errors overall regarding, e.g. empty asset owners input data or inadequate input data formatting. PAI errors were only corrected based on IT-asset owners’ feedback on the PAI report for privileged account onboarding.
§ Escalation mechanism: the privileged account onboarding PAI report is sent out to the IT-asset owners bi-weekly. In addition, the product-level non-compliance status is presented to the Digital Security Committee. Per December 2024, 3,77% of active privileged accounts in production environments (5.000 out of 132.600) were not onboarded to CyberArk as well as no information risk for each of the 5.000 accounts was created. In addition, 200 out of the 5.000 accounts were inventoried within PAI more than 12 months ago. Furthermore, so far, no documented process to follow up on IT-asset owners’ feedback on non-compliant privileged accounts was implemented. CBL TISO raised a feature request to track and monitor such non-compliance instances via a ticketing system including escalation mechanism in case of missing/delayed the asset owners’ feedback.

The root cause was inadequate governance structure and inadequate / missing controls with regards to PAI.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations and internal rules require institutions to secure the usage of privileged accounts.		 Internal Audit recommends Identity & Access Management (ICA) to implement a tracking and monitoring process including escalation mechanism for the follow-up on non-compliant privileged accounts. 12/18/2024 10/31/2025 10/31/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Karl Ulber Volker Scheer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Identity & Access Management (U) Identity & Access Management (ICA) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. A lack of processing controls and escalation mechanism for the Privileged Account Inventory may lead to an incomplete and inaccurate reporting on privileged accounts’ compliance status. Therefore, such privileged accounts might not be monitored and could be misused. This might lead to minor financial impact and material breach of internal and external provisions. Furthermore, it may result in material adverse regulatory impact, such as material potential for extra reporting requirements and/or regulatory examinations. Carsten Kreuz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. 2024-078_F04 2024 2024-078 Privileged Access Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-078_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Not strict enough 2LoD Information Security requirements for Tier 1 privileged accounts The 2LoD Information Security Standard “Identity and Access Management V4.0” defined requirements for the handling of privileged accounts according to their tier level.

Internal Audit noted that the Tier 1 control requirements are not strict enough, specifically for video session recording (ID 77.1.1), password obfuscation (ID 77.1.2) and threat analysis (ID 77.1.3). All three control requirements were only required for Tier 0 accounts based on the 2LoD Information Security’s IAM standard (note: at least the 1LoD “PAM guideline V1.3” already required the stricter control requirements for Tier 1 accounts).

The root cause was the inadequate governance structure for the alignment of the fixed written rules.		 Internal Audit recommend that ICT Risk Framework (KJU) adjust the information security standard “Identity & Access Management” for the three Tier 1 control requirements 17.1.1, 17.1.2 and 17.1.3 analogous Tier 0. 12/18/2024 12/12/2025 12/12/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Karl Ulber Volker Scheer GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Not strict enough 2nd LoD Information Security requirements for Tier 1 privileged accounts may lead to insecurely handling Tier 1 privileged accounts. This might lead to minor financial impact and material breach of internal and external provisions. Furthermore, it may result in material adverse regulatory impact, such as material potential for extra reporting requirements and/or regulatory examinations. Sarah Ahmad Jahn DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG),WOLFGANG EHOLZER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2024-018_F05 2024 2024-018 CCAG Microsoft Azure & M365 (GITA, DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-018_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in Microsoft M365 Security Incident Management, E-Discovery and Cloud Forensics Internal Audit (IA) noted for Microsoft M365 Security Response Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) the following weaknesses:
1. Contained inconsistent terminology (e.g. referencing process actors). (SEF-01-01)
2. Lack of an overarching RACI matrix for roles and responsibilities. (SEF-01-01)
3. Contained non-traceable references to sections and other documents. (SEF-01-01)
4. Did not include sufficient details on key concepts such as incident closure criteria, application of incident prioritisation factors or response strategies based on compromise scenarios. (SEF-01-01)
5. Did not mention in the SOP all used metrics, e.g. not TTE (Time to Engage) metrics or TTPIR (Time to Post Incident Review). (SEF-01-01)
6. Did not include incident classification types, e.g. APT or Engineering Bug (SEF-01-01)
7. Inconsistent incident severity definitions in comparison to those used in the incident tracking system, for example 2-Urgent Alert in SOP and 2-Medium in the tool (SEF-06-01)

Further, the following SEF effectiveness deficiencies were identified:
8. Post-Incident Reviews (PIR) were either conducted and closed before the incidents were mitigated or closed or a complete PIR was not conducted, although the incident ticket was marked as having a PIR; instead, only a privacy Root Cause Analysis (RCA) was done, which did not include proper lessons learned or actual post-incident activities. (SEF-03-02)
9. Metrics to track the time between breach declaration and customer notification were not identified. Incorrect values to track ‘Time to acknowledge’ and missing values to track ‘Time to declare’ were presented in the dashboards. (SEF-05-01)
10. Information about four GDPR-notifiable incidents (~22% of the total population of 18 GDPR notifiable incidents) was communicated past the SLA   of 72 hours (ranging from 73 hours to 352   hours). (SEF-05-01)
11. Time limits (e.g., SLAs, targets, thresholds) were not established for the timeliness of breach declaration once customer impact was confirmed. (SEF-07-01)

The identified items were likely caused by a lack of awareness by the Microsoft process owners of financial institutions’ regulatory demands.

External provisions require that the institution shall appropriately manage the risks associated with outsourcing and shall monitor the provision of the outsourced activities and processes in a due and proper manner.
In case of identified IT risks, appropriate monitoring and management processes shall be set up.		 Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) to assess the measures as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response (appendix 6.3). Particularly to:
1-Assess the documents as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response. Specifically, to verify that the Security Response SOP has been updated to clarify inconsistencies outlined in the finding description.
2-Verify results of Microsoft Security Future Initiative (SFI) to ensure alignment between incident management and communication process.

In case of not fully remediated risks, GAL might consider risk measures to manage the residual risk. 		 3/26/2025 4/15/2026 4/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Yigit Gullu Oliver Wolff CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT Cloud Operations (Dpt) Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in M365 Security Incident Management, E-Discovery and Cloud Forensics may hinder the efficiency and timeliness of incident response. Consequently, this may lead to increased exposure of customer data and affect operational stability. Deficiencies in the traceability of security incident records and related cases pose risks to potential forensic efforts and the effective mitigation of incidents if significant dependencies are not identified timely. These weaknesses represent a material breach of external requirements.   François Leveling CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) External Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-009_F02 2025 2025-009 ETD Processing (ECAG) 2025-009_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Insufficiently documented controls using Checklists Internal Audit (IA) noted insufficiently documented controls and steps done within:
§ The Supervision of Eurex Listed Foreign Exchange (FX) Continues Linked Settlement (CLS) subprocess, on population of 14 months:
- In Checklists for 5 months (16%), tasks were not fully marked as complete.
- In Checklist for 1 month (5%) did not contain 2 signatures as required by Organizational 4EP via Checklist (C4EP) rule.

§ The Month Settlement – Manual Settlement & Maintenance subprocess, on population of 44 checklists:
- 7 Checklists (36%) did not contain 2 signatures as required by C4EP rule.
- On 2 Checklists (7%), tasks were not marked as complete.
- 37 Checklists (84%) did not contain supporting documents.

§ Korea Stock Exchange (KRX) Member Technical Default subprocess, Checklist template used contained ex-employee and outdated Accounting Germany Unit contact reference.

Internal business procedures 7.2.2.2.02 Front Month Settlement – Manual Settlement & Maintenance, 7.2.2.4.1 Supervision of Eurex Listed FX CLS and 7.2.2.2.5 KRX Member Technical Default subprocess defined usage of checklists for subprocess execution accuracy. Additionally, update the Checklists used in the 7.2.2.2.5 KRX Member Technical Default subprocess, by correcting the reference contacts. 3/21/2025 11/14/2025 11/14/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij ETD Clearing Operations (U) ETD Clearing Operations (FRL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficiently documented controls using Checklists bears the risk of inability to prove control efficiency.  This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions and could have material adverse regulatory impact in terms of regulatory examinations in case control performance could not be completely proved. 2025-020_F01 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Ineffective purchasing processes and controls The audit of the Purchasing process revealed a range of weaknesses related to inconsistencies in process and control design, gaps in control execution and process inefficiencies. These issues mostly affect core purchasing processes including the Source-to-Contract, Purchase-to-Pay and Car Fleet Management processes. Minor gaps were noted in the Supplier Management process. Internal Audit (IA) noted that purchasing process documentation lacks overall clarity, completeness and accuracy, further impacting operational consistency and effectiveness.

IA noted the following key issues related to control design and operating effectiveness:

§ Weaknesses in the control framework related to inconsistent frequency and allocation of controls in the Purchasing Manual, SAP GRC ICS and control documentation, leading to misalignment with actual practices. The majority of controls were executed at least twice, ad hoc and periodically as “compliance check”. Further, clear guidelines for sample-based purchasing controls including responsibilities, segregation of duties and follow-up activities, were lacking. This approach, combined with a high volume of purchasing operations, limited process efficiency.
§ Unclear instructions on specific process steps and control applicability in different purchasing tools, dispersed across the Purchasing Manual and related tool-specific guidelines. This led to misunderstanding of the process flow and associated controls.
§ Other minor deficiencies in the Purchasing Manual regarding inaccurate and outdated flow-charts, unclear descriptions of contract call-offs applicability, goods receipt confirmation and inaccuracies concerning access right checks conducted for internally managed catalogues. Inaccuracies related to Supplier Governance Committee existing for ECAG, CBF, Eurex Repo, and DBAG, but not Clearstream Holding. Also, there were gaps in SAP GRC ICS as the Car Fleet Management process was not included in the Process Map and there were no entries for issue management and escalation, relating to supplier management.
§ Inadequate controls over Waivers of Competitive Bid (Bid Waiver) as Corporate Purchasing (FPU) did not ensure completeness and accuracy of all Bid Waiver requests prior to approval. In addition, there was a lack of automated controls disabling submission of incomplete digital Bid Waiver request forms and ensuring approval solely by Board Members in specific cases.
§ Limited effectiveness of Source-to-Contract and Purchase-to-Pay process caused by lack of operational consistency, missing process and control documentation. On a sample of 18 Purchase Orders with 24 transactions IA Identified gaps related to lack of sourcing documentation in one case, unclear rules regarding quantitative evaluations of bids and savings calculation. Also, one control over Purchase Order Modifications was not implemented.
Lastly, IA noted that only one fully trained FTE possessed the necessary expertise to perform complex data analytics and reporting tasks. There was no risk identified in relation to the continuation of the core purchasing processes, however, this lead to Internal Audit experiencing delays in receiving the requested data and performing timely audit testing. This resource constraint further highlights the need for increased knowledge transfer and resource resilience in FPU.
Overall, redundant and repetitive controls created confusion, with negative impact on the control environment, process efficiency and availability of accurate audit evidence.
In line with external and internal provisions, an institution should maintain adequate arrangements, safeguards and controls to ensure an effective internal control system and risk management. Business activities must be conducted based on up-to-date written procedures, with clearly defined roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls. Moreover, control activities need to be defined, documented and presented in a way that is understandable by third parties.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate Purchasing (FPU):
§ undertake a comprehensive review and streamlining of the end-to-end purchasing process and control framework. The objective should be simplification and clarification of the process execution ensuring that necessary controls are applied, while eliminating duplication and inefficiencies. Specifically, IA recommends that FPU holistically reviews and updates the process and control framework, including SAP GRC ICS, with focus on identification of key controls, frequency of implementation, adequate segregation of duties and remediation measures.
§ ensure that all controls are implemented as designed with sufficient audit trail
§ implement appropriate automated controls to ensure that bid waivers are approved based on complete and accurate information and with necessary Board Member approvals, in line with the process requirements
§ reduce key person dependency by training team members, and documenting work instructions regarding data analytics and related reporting tasks
§ correct the identified deficiencies and inaccuracies in the Purchasing Manual		 4/25/2025 3/27/2026 3/27/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ourania Androulaki Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Corporate Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Ineffective purchasing processes and controls increase the risk of noncompliance with procurement rules, material operational errors and inefficiencies. The lack of proper documentation, justifications and segregation of duties further reduces transparency in purchasing decisions, limits auditability and weakens internal oversight.  Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Inadequate Process and/or Controls Control Env. + Des.
