§ Inconsistent control frequency between relevant credit card procedures and SAP GRC ICS.
§ Lack of record keeping and audit trail on approved and revoked credit cards prior to new process implementation and prior to AirPlus Portal (AID2144) update and migration.
§ Lack of and gaps in control execution including lack of audit trail on performed ad hoc and periodic controls.

Further, IA noted that data on credit cards in the AirPlus Portal was incomplete and inaccurate. Specifically, the population of active and revoked credit cards for the period under review was lacking data on several active credit cards identified in control evidence. In addition, IA identified a card holder that did not register in AirPlus Portal as the card was issued during the portal migration.		 Internal Audit recommends that General & IT Purchasing (FIG):
§ review and align controls frequency in credit card procedures and SAP GRC ICS
§ perform all controls as defined in relevant credit cards procedures
§ ensure sufficient audit trail and complete records on all credit cards, process execution and implemented controls
§ ensure complete and accurate data on all credit cards in relevant tool		 4/25/2025 3/16/2026 3/16/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ana Kosela Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer General & IT Purchasing (U) General & IT Purchasing (FIG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. 2025-020_F03 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F03-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate governance over Third Party Management (TPM) framework agreements There was no defined or documented framework specifying the conditions under which Third Party Management (TPM) framework agreements for professional services should be established. Guidance available in the Purchasing Manual inadequately addressed the governance of these agreements leading to inconsistent practices in the initiation, approval and monitoring. A framework agreement sets out the general terms and conditions which apply to subsequent individual contracts and program agreements.

In particular, Internal Audit noted the following:
§ Description of the Framework Purchase Order (PO) buying channel in the Purchasing Manual was inaccurate and unclear, particularly regarding ownership, exemptions, and the sign-off process.
§ The supplier identification and selection criteria as well as triggers for concluding a TPM framework agreement were not formally set out.
§ Inadequate segregation of duties as Corporate Purchasing (FPU) performed a dual role acting as both the Business Owner (BO) of TPM framework agreements and as support function ensuring compliance with the purchasing procedures. In addition, there were no clear authorisation rules requiring line management involvement, leading to inconsistencies in framework agreements sign-off and insufficient management oversight.
§ There was no defined and established independent monitoring of these agreements and risks stemming from FPUs dual role

German, and Luxembourg regulations and guidance require an institution to maintain robust internal governance and risk management systems. This includes ensuring proper segregation of duties and establishing clear criteria for triggering specific agreements to enhance operational transparency. 		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate Purchasing (FPU) establish appropriate governance over TPM framework agreements. In particular, IA recommends that FPU:
§ update the Framework PO buying channel description to accurately reflect applicability, exemptions and ownership of framework agreements
§ define clear criteria, conditions and triggers for supplier identification and conclusion of framework agreements
§ standardise roles and responsibilities for initiation, review and authorisation of framework agreements with mandatory line management involvement
§ ensure independent oversight over framework agreements with related individual contracts and program agreements, by regular status reporting to senior management		 4/25/2025 11/20/2025 11/20/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ana Kosela Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Corporate Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate governance over TPM framework agreements can result in inconsistent and non-compliant procurement practices and insufficient oversight. Together with lack of segregation of duties, inadequate governance may lead to biased decision-making, limited objectivity and transparency when evaluating agreements. Ultimately, this may hinder DBG’s ability to effectively monitor procurement spend and manage supplier agreements and relationships.  Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Env. + Des. 2025-020_F04 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) In 2021, the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) was established as an advisory body for the selection of supplier relationships and review of supplier risks for Corporate Purchasing and the corresponding Terms of Reference (ToR) for DBAG, CBF, ECAG and ExR were prepared. These were last updated in the context of the introduction of the Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (LkSG) effective January 2023. No specific internal requirements for voluntary committees exist.
As Committee members, the Terms of Reference (ToR) defines several function takers of first and second Lines of Defense (LoD) in Chapter 6.1. Each Committee member has one vote and thus has a direct influence on supplier onboarding decisions. Internal Audit is nominated as a non-voting guest on a permanent basis. Overall guests have no voting rights.

Internal Audit noticed that the ToR for the SGC was lacking:
§ clear policies and mechanisms to avoid conflicts of interest
§ a regular rotation of committee members
§ verification and disclosure of members regarding direct financial or personal interests in the supplier
In addition, the distribution/participants list for the Legal entity specific Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) was outdated and did not comply with the defined function takers of first and second LoD (e.g. the Human Rights Officer as responsible under LkSG for monitoring risk management within the company was not part of any of the distribution list for DBAG, CBF, ECAG or ExR).

The DBG Business Code of Conduct defines DBG's conduct and ethical principles. As "tone at the top", they form the benchmark for entrepreneurial decisions and entrepreneurial action. Together, with internal compliance guidelines, particularly the DBG Policy on Conflicts of Interest, the expectations of the behavior of all managers and employees as well as business practices are addressed to ensure compliance with the values and principles of the DBG.  		 Internal Audit recommend that Supplier Governance & Control (SGC) review and update the Terms of Reference for Supplier Governance Committee with regards to the identified deficiencies and include:
§ clear policies and mechanisms to avoid conflicts of interest to ensure that decisions are made in the best interest of the company
§ a regulation to promote the independence of the Committee through the possibility of a regular and gradual rotation of the voting members or their representatives, for example, every 3-4 years to minimise the likelihood of long-term conflicts of interest
§ a regulation to regular/annually obtain self-disclosures from members regarding direct financial or personal interests in the supplier and prompt disclosure to ensure the objectivity and fairness of the committee and to preserve the integrity of supplier relationships
In addition, to review and update the distribution/participants list for the LE-specific SGCs and to monitor and question long-term representation of nominated function holders with voting rights.		 4/25/2025 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 Clearstream Banking AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH Deutsche Börse AG Sandra Schwarz Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Supplier Governance & Control (U) Supplier Governance & Control (SGC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the Terms of Reference (ToR) for the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) can lead to conflicts of interest, resulting in inefficient supplier decisions, higher costs, and lower quality of goods or services. This may cause mistrust and tensions within the SGC and internally if decisions are perceived as unfair. Additionally, it could expose DBG to material reputational risk if violations of the Business Code of Conduct become public, impairing trust and potentially leading to loss of business relationships with minor financial impact. Lars Juretzko GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-020_F05 2025 2025-020 Purchasing (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-020_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lacking definition and action for identified supplier issues or incidents The Purchasing Manual contained mitigating actions based on the risk score for identified issues or incidents with a supplier. If the risk score was yellow, a remote audit should be conducted.

Internal Audit noted that this remote audit requirement was not fulfilled. The reporting for the second half of 2024 contained five suppliers with a yellow risk score and no related remote audits had been conducted.

In addition, the Purchasing Manual stated that the Supplier Governance Committee (SGC) decides about measures for red risk scores. SGC exists for ECAG, CBF, Eurex Repo, and DBAG. IA noted that for all other legal entities without an SGC, the procedure related to red risk scores was not defined.

In this context, Corporate Purchasing (FPU) represented that so far, a red classification had never occurred.

In line with German and Luxembourg regulation and DBG policy, business activities must be conducted based on organizational guidelines. They should include a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and controls. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Supplier Governance & Control (SGC):
§ define in the Purchasing Manual the required measures for red risk scores for legal entities without an SGC.
§ apply the measures as defined for the suppliers with yellow and red risk scores. This could imply changing the existing definitions (e.g., remote audits for yellow risk scores) and/or defining a reporting procedure in case of non-compliance		 4/25/2025 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Randi Montgomery Petya Dimitrova Pencheva GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Supplier Governance & Control (U) Supplier Governance & Control (SGC unit) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lacking definition and action for identified supplier issues or incidents represent a minor breach of regulatory requirements and violations of internal and external provisions. Unclearly defined roles and responsibilities and failure to conduct defined mitigating action may lead to inadequate handling of issues and/or incidents. Examples are that certain required individuals are not involved, or nobody takes responsibility and action.  Lars Juretzko ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. 2024-019_F01 2024 2024-019 CCAG Google (GITA, DBAG, ECAG,CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-019_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes Internal Audit (IA) identified the following gaps within Google’s Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA) process, specifically in the supply chain inventory and supply chain risk management processes.

1. Disclosure of sub-sub-processors
The review has shown that Google does not proactively notify customers regarding identified sub-processing activities beyond the first level of (sub ) processors engaged by Google. Google customers, as data controllers, need to ensure that, in the whole supply chain, only those processors that provide sufficient guarantee to meet the GDPR requirements will process data. Restricting customer information violates external provisions such as GDPR and Google’s own Cloud Data Processing Addendum (CDPA) requiring disclosure to data controllers, the entire chain of sub-processors.  
Google did not perform an analysis of whether a service provider acts as a sub-processor in line with GDPR and all underlying levels of sub-processing. This requires the same quality of information before the provider gets access to customer data as for the first level of sub-processing. If the provider was not identified as processor in line with GDPR, the need to share information still should have been aligned with the general contractual arrangements for nonmaterial vendors and subcontractors.

2. Incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies
The review of vendor exit strategies identified documentation completeness shortcomings for four out of five vendor categories, namely Cloud Support, Chronicle, Colocation, Security Guards. E.g. some exit strategies mainly covered non-stressed scenarios, but stressed scenarios were not sufficiently addressed. This impacted the description of the team's resiliency strategy to ensure no disruption to business activities, as well as the documentation of continuity processes to ensure service quality to Google customers. Additionally, the description of alternative solutions/transition plans in stressed scenarios and compliance requirements for exiting a material vendor were found insufficient.

For three out of the four exit strategies with identified shortcomings, the necessary updates have been completed during the audit fieldwork and have been provided to CCAG auditors. Only the update of the exit strategy for Colocation remained outstanding: the stressed exit scenario needed to be reflected within the document.

The root cause was attributed to a lack of governance and guidance during the process execution for de-centralised process activities.

EU, German and Luxembourg regulation requires institutions to have an overview and control over the data processing and involved parties including the strategies to terminate any vendor relationship.		 Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) either to implement internal controls to mitigate the risks identified for missing disclosure of sub-sub-processors or to require Google to implement mitigating controls such as outlined in Google’s response (see Appendix A). Alternatively, risk acceptance can be evaluated and requested following DBG’s procedures. 3/6/2025 9/30/2025 3/31/2026 1 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes could result in increased risk for information security. Consequently, this could lead to major operational risk, minor financial loss and/or minor reputational loss. Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness of Group / Cross Functional Processes Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2024-019_F01 2024 2024-019 CCAG Google (GITA, DBAG, ECAG,CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-019_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes Internal Audit (IA) identified the following gaps within Google’s Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability (STA) process, specifically in the supply chain inventory and supply chain risk management processes.

1. Disclosure of sub-sub-processors
The review has shown that Google does not proactively notify customers regarding identified sub-processing activities beyond the first level of (sub ) processors engaged by Google. Google customers, as data controllers, need to ensure that, in the whole supply chain, only those processors that provide sufficient guarantee to meet the GDPR requirements will process data. Restricting customer information violates external provisions such as GDPR and Google’s own Cloud Data Processing Addendum (CDPA) requiring disclosure to data controllers, the entire chain of sub-processors.  
Google did not perform an analysis of whether a service provider acts as a sub-processor in line with GDPR and all underlying levels of sub-processing. This requires the same quality of information before the provider gets access to customer data as for the first level of sub-processing. If the provider was not identified as processor in line with GDPR, the need to share information still should have been aligned with the general contractual arrangements for nonmaterial vendors and subcontractors.

2. Incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies
The review of vendor exit strategies identified documentation completeness shortcomings for four out of five vendor categories, namely Cloud Support, Chronicle, Colocation, Security Guards. E.g. some exit strategies mainly covered non-stressed scenarios, but stressed scenarios were not sufficiently addressed. This impacted the description of the team's resiliency strategy to ensure no disruption to business activities, as well as the documentation of continuity processes to ensure service quality to Google customers. Additionally, the description of alternative solutions/transition plans in stressed scenarios and compliance requirements for exiting a material vendor were found insufficient.

For three out of the four exit strategies with identified shortcomings, the necessary updates have been completed during the audit fieldwork and have been provided to CCAG auditors. Only the update of the exit strategy for Colocation remained outstanding: the stressed exit scenario needed to be reflected within the document.

The root cause was attributed to a lack of governance and guidance during the process execution for de-centralised process activities.

EU, German and Luxembourg regulation requires institutions to have an overview and control over the data processing and involved parties including the strategies to terminate any vendor relationship.		 Internal Audit recommends Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) either to implement internal controls to mitigate the risks identified through the incomplete documentation of vendor exit strategies or to require Google to implement mitigating controls such as outlined in Google’s response (see Appendix A). Alternatively, risk acceptance can be evaluated and requested following DBG’s procedures. 3/6/2025 9/30/2025 1/15/2026 1 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG André Scholz André Scholz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrast (Dpt) Chief Cloud Officer / Core Infrastructure (ZFJ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Google’s supply chain management processes could result in increased risk for information security. Consequently, this could lead to major operational risk, minor financial loss and/or minor reputational loss. Michael Girg CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Lack of Awareness of Group / Cross Functional Processes Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-006_F01 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the Document – Business Development Process  Description As part of the preparation phase, Internal Audit (IA) obtained the outdated Document – Business Development Process Description, version 1.7. This version was already audited as part of the 2023-001 Product/Service Development audit identifying process description weaknesses as documented in finding 2023-001_F02. Additionally, OTC Product & Clearing Business Development (ZDY) initially showed a lack of awareness of responsibility for the process description again during this audit. ZDY then provided IA with Document – Business Development Process Description, version 1.8. This version was only partially dated indicating incompleteness of the process document review.

 

Based on version 1.8 provided, IA noted the following weaknesses:

There was a lack of evidence that version 1.8 was approved by the Head of Unit ZDY.

ZDY did not perform an annual review of the process description since submission of the process document to IA as part of the follow-up of 2023-001_F02 where version 1.8 was provided. Consequently, the process document was not up-to-date including outdated references to units and section names as well as the organisational chart. Additionally, IA noted the use of imprecise terminology whereas sections and units were referred to as an entity.

The procedure stated that initiatives were submitted to ZDY via a business requirement request form. However, there were other options such as emails, meetings and Committee input that were omitted from the procedure.

ZDY did not have central storage place within the unit for the process description where it would be available to all ZDY employees, nor was the updated version available in the ECAG Manual.

As part of the Eurex reorganisation, the unit ZDY was dissolved. The responsibility of the Business Development process was taken over by Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC).  		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) to assign clear roles and responsibilities within the Business Development process and corresponding process documentation.
Additionally, IA recommends DEC to assess potential impacts on the process following the reorganisation and document the Business Development process accordingly. IA recommends DEC e.g. to create or review and update the Document – Business Development Process Description, particularly to:
- Create or update the process description where necessary including, but not limited to, a description of how the business requirements are collected and documented, references to units and sections involved as well as the up-to-date organisational chart
- use precise terminology with regards to stakeholders involved in the process
- ensure an annual review is performed regularly 
- obtain approval of the updated version by at least the responsible Head of Section and respective approval documentation
- retain annual review and approval documentation for audit purposes
IA also recommends DEC to make the up-to-date process description available in a central place, namely the ECAG Manual. 		 5/21/2025 11/19/2025 11/19/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Derivatives Clearing Development (U) Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. 
Weaknesses in the Document – Business Development Process Description represent a material breach of regulatory requirements and internal provisions. It could impede on transparency and thus result in misunderstandings, processing errors and/or inadequately conducted tasks.  		 Efthimia Kefalea JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness of Own Process Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes Yes No No No
2025-010_F01 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate Oversight of Decentralized ECAG Ad Hoc Regulatory Reporting CCP Regulation (CCD), the process owner for Ad-hoc Reporting to regulators, was directly responsible for submitting various reports based on ad-hoc trigger events occurring within the company. However, given the expansive regulatory reporting requirements encompassing various topics and trigger events, many teams outside DDO were directly responsible for submitting ad-hoc reports to regulators pertaining to their area of responsibility. Accordingly, Internal Audit (IA) noted inadequate oversight and monitoring of the ad hoc reporting elements to be submitted to the regulators by stakeholders outside of Regulation & Compliance (DDO). That is, CCD was not involved in any ad hoc reporting performed outside of DDO and accordingly did not track if the person/unit responsible for the submission (as indicated in the Annex I of the process description) was complying with their duty.
Moreover, IA raised a similar finding 2023-011_F01 previously highlighting inadequate oversight, prompting CCD to implement a control framework. This framework included controls to ensure stakeholders’ awareness of their reporting obligations, and an escalation process in case of non-compliance with the framework. However, during the current review, IA noted that the “Monitoring and Escalation” chapter was removed from the latest 2.11.5 Process Description Ad-Hoc Reporting procedure. Consequently, the steps for monitoring, tracking and escalation in case of identified failed or late reporting were not documented and performed during 2023 and 2024.
Lastly, CCD did not perform the semi-annual control designed to review the assigned responsibilities for ad-hoc reporting, confirm the awareness of responsible stakeholders and ensure up-to-datedness of Annex I maintained to list the events that trigger ad-hoc reporting requirements for Eurex Clearing in 2024.
European and German regulation mandate robust governance structures, within CCPs and financial institutions, including clear organisational structures, defined responsibilities, and effective compliance monitoring programs to ensure adherence to its regulatory obligations. These regulations aim to ensure the detection and prevention of noncompliance with regulatory obligations. Specifically, a robust compliance function must implement and monitor procedures for adherence to applicable internal and external requirements.		 Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ perform a comprehensive assessment of relevant regulations and inherent risks concerning the currently missing complete overview of all ad hoc regulatory reporting, in which CCP Regulation is not involved as neither information owner nor information transmitter
§ receive a formal approval on the assessment and the resulting approach from the Board/Management
§ based on the assessment, if required, amend the process and controls (including documentation), as necessary, to ensure compliance and mitigation of the identified risks
§ ensure execution of the established semi-annual control on assigned responsibilities for ad-hoc reporting and awareness of the responsible stakeholders		 5/16/2025 10/17/2025 10/17/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. CCP Regulation (CCD), the process owner for Ad-hoc Reporting to regulators, was directly responsible for submitting various reports based on ad-hoc trigger events occurring within the company. However, given the expansive regulatory reporting requirements encompassing various topics and trigger events, many teams outside DDO were directly responsible for submitting ad-hoc reports to regulators pertaining to their area of responsibility. Accordingly, Internal Audit (IA) noted inadequate oversight and monitoring of the ad hoc reporting elements to be submitted to the regulators by stakeholders outside of Regulation & Compliance (DDO). That is, CCD was not involved in any ad hoc reporting performed outside of DDO and accordingly did not track if the person/unit responsible for the submission (as indicated in the Annex I of the process description) was complying with their duty.

Moreover, IA raised a similar finding 2023-011_F01 previously highlighting inadequate oversight, prompting CCD to implement a control framework. This framework included controls to ensure stakeholders’ awareness of their reporting obligations, and an escalation process in case of non-compliance with the framework. However, during the current review, IA noted that the “Monitoring and Escalation” chapter was removed from the latest 2.11.5 Process Description Ad-Hoc Reporting procedure. Consequently, the steps for monitoring, tracking and escalation in case of identified failed or late reporting were not documented and performed during 2023 and 2024.

Lastly, CCD did not perform the semi-annual control designed to review the assigned responsibilities for ad-hoc reporting, confirm the awareness of responsible stakeholders and ensure up-to-datedness of Annex I maintained to list the events that trigger ad-hoc reporting requirements for Eurex Clearing in 2024.

European and German regulation mandate robust governance structures, within CCPs and financial institutions, including clear organisational structures, defined responsibilities, and effective compliance monitoring programs to ensure adherence to its regulatory obligations. These regulations aim to ensure the detection and prevention of non-compliance with regulatory obligations. Specifically, a robust compliance function must implement and monitor procedures for adherence to applicable internal and external requirements.		 Jenny Poschmann MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Governance Structure Control Environment Yes No No Yes No No No
2025-010_F02 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the MAS Reporting process During the review, Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Reporting process:
▪ The validity of responsibilities assigned within the MAS template “Annex 1 – RCG SAR template Responsibilities” could not be verified due to absence of a formal tracking mechanism for the assigned responsibilities of the respective units or business areas.
▪ The evidence of the validation control performed, on the information provided by the involved areas to ensure accuracy, consistency with Eurex Frankfurt AG’s similar report to MAS, and alignment with the reports formerly submitted to MAS was not documented.
▪ The business procedure mandated the inclusion of the functional email ccp-regulation@eurex.com in cc of the submission email for MAS Reports. However, the functional email was not included in cc in the submission email of 2024.
European and German regulation require that business activities are
conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete
and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define roles,
responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up
systematically		 Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ implement a formal tracking mechanism to document and monitor responsibilities assigned with the MAS reporting process. This mechanism should clearly define roles and responsibilities for each section of the report, ensuring complete coverage and accountability.
§ develop and implement documented process steps for validating data within the MAS reporting process. Additionally, ensure that the validity control is documented.
§ reinforce adherence to the established business procedure, specifically ensuring that ccp-regulation@eurex.com email address is included in the cc of all MAS report submission emails		 5/16/2025 2/9/2027 2/9/2027 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. During the review, Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Reporting process:
§ The validity of responsibilities assigned within the MAS template “Annex 1 – RCG SAR template Responsibilities” could not be verified due to absence of a formal tracking mechanism for the assigned responsibilities of the respective units or business areas.
§ The evidence of the validation control performed, on the information provided by the involved areas to ensure accuracy, consistency with Eurex Frankfurt AG’s similar report to MAS, and alignment with the reports formerly submitted to MAS was not documented.
§ The business procedure mandated the inclusion of the functional email ccp-regulation@eurex.com in cc of the submission email for MAS Reports. However, the functional email was not included in cc in the submission email of 2024.

European and German regulation require that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically.		 Jenny Poschmann MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Process and/or Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes Yes No No No
2025-010_F03 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the GRC Risk Control Matrix for CCP Regulation Internal Audit (IA) noted weaknesses in the GRC Risk Control Matrix (RCM) for CCP Regulation (CCD) relating to the completeness of documented controls and the accuracy of inherent risk assessments.
Certain controls performed were not captured in the GRC Risk Control Matrix, such as:
▪ For ad hoc reporting, the following controls were not captured:
- Regular review performed by CCP Regulation (CCD), along with the review of the respective Annex on a quarterly basis.
- Every six months, CCP Regulation (CCD) carries out query to obtain confirmation that the stakeholders are aware of the respective reporting obligations, and that the required process steps are included in their business descriptions.
- Every two years, CCP Regulation (CCD) conducts meeting with the responsible stakeholders to raise general awareness of the process and to identify and remediate any shortcomings.
▪ For MAS reporting, the following controls were not captured:
- Control performed by involved areas by validating the content provided as well as ensuring consistency with the answers provided by Eurex Frankfurt AG within their similar report to the MAS and with the reports formerly provided to MAS.
- Review of final version of the MAS report by the colleagues responsible for the regular communication towards the MAS (Director Head of Business Development and Sales APAC & Middle East and Regulatory Legal), as well as by the CEO of Eurex Clearing.
- The final MAS report is signed by the CEO, CCO and when relevant, by another board member of Eurex Clearing.
Furthermore, the GRC RCM reflected the inherent likelihood for the subprocess “Jurisdiction” (SP_ECAG_CO_16.4.2_Jurisdictions) as “Once a year”. However, during the review of the Clearing Service
Extension process, IA noted that this process was not performed with this frequency and was only executed when Eurex Clearing extended its business to other jurisdictions. As this did not occur annually, the inherent risk assessment was rendered inaccurate.
German regulations and internal provisions require that the risks and controls are adequately identified and systematically documented.		 Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ ensure that all controls pertaining to the ad hoc regulatory reporting and MAS reporting are sufficiently captured in the GRC Risk Control Matrix (RCM)
§ reassess the inherent likelihood and accordingly update the RCM entry for “SP_ECAG_CO_16.4.2_Jurisdictions”		 5/16/2025 10/17/2025 10/17/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Internal Audit (IA) noted weaknesses in the GRC Risk Control Matrix (RCM) for CCP Regulation (CCD) relating to the completeness of documented controls and the accuracy of inherent risk assessments.

Certain controls performed were not captured in the GRC Risk Control Matrix, such as:
§ For ad hoc reporting, the following controls were not captured:
- Regular review performed by CCP Regulation (CCD), along with the review of the respective Annex on a quarterly basis.
- Every six months, CCP Regulation (CCD) carries out query to obtain confirmation that the stakeholders are aware of the respective reporting obligations, and that the required process steps are included in their business descriptions.
- Every two years, CCP Regulation (CCD) conducts meeting with the responsible stakeholders to raise general awareness of the process and to identify and remediate any shortcomings.
§ For MAS reporting, the following controls were not captured:
- Control performed by involved areas by validating the content provided as well as ensuring consistency with the answers provided by Eurex Frankfurt AG within their similar report to the MAS and with the reports formerly provided to MAS.
- Review of final version of the MAS report by the colleagues responsible for the regular communication towards the MAS (Director Head of Business Development and Sales APAC & Middle East and Regulatory Legal), as well as by the CEO of Eurex Clearing.
- The final MAS report is signed by the CEO, CCO and when relevant, by another board member of Eurex Clearing.

Furthermore, the GRC RCM reflected the inherent likelihood for the subprocess “Jurisdiction” (SP_ECAG_CO_16.4.2_Jurisdictions) as “Once a year”. However, during the review of the Clearing Service Extension process, IA noted that this process was not performed with this frequency and was only executed when Eurex Clearing extended its business to other jurisdictions. As this did not occur annually, the inherent risk assessment was rendered inaccurate.

German regulations and internal provisions require that the risks and controls are adequately identified and systematically documented.		 Jenny Poschmann MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No Yes No No No
2025-012_F02 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls Internal Audit’s (IA) March 2025 inspections and walkthrough of the Frankfurt Rödelheim/Germany NTT and Contern/Luxembourg Verizon data centres (DCs), assisted by Data Centre Management (ICV), identified the following physical security and access control deficiencies:

§ DBG DC room video monitoring – The DCs’ closed-circuit television (CCTV) video monitoring of the DBG-rented DC rooms only covered entry and exit points. Other DC room areas were not CCTV-monitored, creating blind areas particularly for the critical IT infrastructure aisles with business-critical data. These DC rooms are technical rooms facilitating operation of DBG’s IT infrastructure. Any unescorted and escorted person could cause intentional or unintentional damage to unmonitored ICT systems. IA was informed the same video monitoring approach was in place in all DBG DCs, including those not inspected (Equinix in Frankfurt Seckbach/Germany and CBL-owned in Kirchberg/Luxembourg).

§ NTT DC video monitoring – NTT’s video monitoring covered the entry and exit doors, gates and the direct fence areas. NTT did not cover the generators, fire suppression, uninterruptible power supply (UPS), and air-conditioning systems critical areas. The auditors observed onsite that these critical infrastructure components were also left without further monitoring during maintenance activity. NTT confirmed the compliance to their common standards which would include CCTV monitoring and escorting of maintenance work, which remained in contradiction to the auditors’ observations.

§ DC pool-badge (visitor) management process – DBG’s NTT DC physical security concept for authorised staff relied on three-step authentication: electronic key (badge), unique pin-code and biometric authentication (hand scan). However, for Physical Security (FSE)-issued pool-badges, used for third-party access to secure areas, the pin-code was written directly on each badge for life-time usage. Further, these pool-badges were active permanently and under NTT custody. Therefore, the established pool-badge management process between Data Centre Management (ICV) and NTT would not prevent unauthorized badge usage. The pool-badge usage did not generate any alarm or notification, and NTT shared the usage report once per month. Regular data correlation between access requests and badge reader log data was not performed as a mitigation measure.

§ Anti-ram protection – The NTT DC area perimeter and physical barrier inspection identified a vulnerability resulting from the neighbouring area, a car park and garages close to DC rooms. The NTT DC was built very close to the neighbouring area, only leaving 3-4 metres between the building and the fence, allowing no further safeguard distance. As a result, instead of e.g. concrete barriers, pollards or rocks to stop vehicles, the only protection was a simple metal chain-link fence. IA’s interview of NTT confirmed their risk assessment did not include this area. NTT confirmed later they did not see the need for anti-ram protection in the absence of related incidents in the past and would only install such protections for DIN EN 50600 certified DCs, which DBG had not required.

DORA article 28 and the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management (EBA/GL/2019/04) ask financial institutions identify and manage their ICT and security risks. The ICT function(s) should manage all risks identified within the financial institution’s risk appetite limits and in compliance with external and internal requirements. Policies, procedures and controls shall limit physical or logical access to information assets and ICT assets.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Physical Security (FSE) mitigate the data centre physical security risk by:
§ setting up video monitoring for each DBG data centre suites’ aisle at the Frankfurt Seckbach and Rödelheim, Luxembourg Kirchberg and Contern locations, and include it in the existing CCTV system		 5/28/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lasha Shishniashvili Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Physical Security (U) Physical Security (FSE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls raise concerns about the integrity and availability of critical organisational services in case of physical security threats. Resulting vulnerabilities increase the likelihood of IT service disruptions, data loss, and service outages. Such incidents could lead to significant financial losses, regulatory penalties, and severe reputational damage. David Krüger CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-012_F02 2025 2025-012 Data Center and Disaster Recovery (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-012_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls Internal Audit’s (IA) March 2025 inspections and walkthrough of the Frankfurt Rödelheim/Germany NTT and Contern/Luxembourg Verizon data centres (DCs), assisted by Data Centre Management (ICV), identified the following physical security and access control deficiencies:

§ DBG DC room video monitoring – The DCs’ closed-circuit television (CCTV) video monitoring of the DBG-rented DC rooms only covered entry and exit points. Other DC room areas were not CCTV-monitored, creating blind areas particularly for the critical IT infrastructure aisles with business-critical data. These DC rooms are technical rooms facilitating operation of DBG’s IT infrastructure. Any unescorted and escorted person could cause intentional or unintentional damage to unmonitored ICT systems. IA was informed the same video monitoring approach was in place in all DBG DCs, including those not inspected (Equinix in Frankfurt Seckbach/Germany and CBL-owned in Kirchberg/Luxembourg).

§ NTT DC video monitoring – NTT’s video monitoring covered the entry and exit doors, gates and the direct fence areas. NTT did not cover the generators, fire suppression, uninterruptible power supply (UPS), and air-conditioning systems critical areas. The auditors observed onsite that these critical infrastructure components were also left without further monitoring during maintenance activity. NTT confirmed the compliance to their common standards which would include CCTV monitoring and escorting of maintenance work, which remained in contradiction to the auditors’ observations.

§ DC pool-badge (visitor) management process – DBG’s NTT DC physical security concept for authorised staff relied on three-step authentication: electronic key (badge), unique pin-code and biometric authentication (hand scan). However, for Physical Security (FSE)-issued pool-badges, used for third-party access to secure areas, the pin-code was written directly on each badge for life-time usage. Further, these pool-badges were active permanently and under NTT custody. Therefore, the established pool-badge management process between Data Centre Management (ICV) and NTT would not prevent unauthorized badge usage. The pool-badge usage did not generate any alarm or notification, and NTT shared the usage report once per month. Regular data correlation between access requests and badge reader log data was not performed as a mitigation measure.

§ Anti-ram protection – The NTT DC area perimeter and physical barrier inspection identified a vulnerability resulting from the neighbouring area, a car park and garages close to DC rooms. The NTT DC was built very close to the neighbouring area, only leaving 3-4 metres between the building and the fence, allowing no further safeguard distance. As a result, instead of e.g. concrete barriers, pollards or rocks to stop vehicles, the only protection was a simple metal chain-link fence. IA’s interview of NTT confirmed their risk assessment did not include this area. NTT confirmed later they did not see the need for anti-ram protection in the absence of related incidents in the past and would only install such protections for DIN EN 50600 certified DCs, which DBG had not required.

DORA article 28 and the EBA Guidelines on ICT and security risk management (EBA/GL/2019/04) ask financial institutions identify and manage their ICT and security risks. The ICT function(s) should manage all risks identified within the financial institution’s risk appetite limits and in compliance with external and internal requirements. Policies, procedures and controls shall limit physical or logical access to information assets and ICT assets.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Data Centre Management (ICV) mitigate the identified NTT data centre’s DBG area security risks, including:
§ defining a secure procedure to manage the NTT data centre Frankfurt Rödelheim visitor badges, reducing the identified risk in liasion with Physical Security (FSE)
§ align with the NTT data centre provider on options to mitigate the data centre area’s risk of terrorism and physical attack from the unprotected neighbouring areas, and take a risk-based decision on mitigation
§ align with the NTT data centre provider on options to implement video monitoring of all critical exterior areas including generators, fire suppression systems, UPS systems, and air-conditioning systems and take a risk-based decision on mitigation
§ obtain formal risk acceptance for risks that will not be mitigated		 5/28/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Lasha Shishniashvili Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Data Centre Management (U) Data Centre Management (ICV) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate and missing DBG data centre physical security controls raise concerns about the integrity and availability of critical organisational services in case of physical security threats. Resulting vulnerabilities increase the likelihood of IT service disruptions, data loss, and service outages. Such incidents could lead to significant financial losses, regulatory penalties, and severe reputational damage. Dominik Matzanke CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inconsistent/Inadequate Management Decisions Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-016_F01 2025 2025-016 Default Management (ECAG) 2025-016_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in Default Management test plan Internal Audit (IA) observed that the Credit Risk & Default Management (DCZ) team independently determined the scope of the annual default management test plan. Given the nature of the default management process, many teams within the company are involved in the process in various capacities, particularly in the liquidation of the inherited portfolio, such as executing and settling trade instructions. Since the default of a clearing member is an uncommon event, many of the corresponding procedures triggered only in a default event have not been executed or tested. Without this coordination, operational readiness in case of a clearing member default cannot be ensured. 

 

EU regulations mandate that central counterparties regularly conduct simulations (tests) of clearing member default scenarios. These tests are crucial to ensure the CCP’s and its clearing members’ operational readiness, identify bottlenecks and improve procedures for liquidating defaulted portfolios. 		 Internal Audit recommends that the yearly test plan is circulated to the process owners of all processes related to Default Management. The process owners’ review should be integrated into the approval of the annual test plan and ensure that all processes related to the Default Management process, i.e., all process considered as interface processes according to the most up-to-date DMP checklists , should be included in scope of the test plan on a regular basis. 6/18/2025 3/13/2026 3/13/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Robert Pardikes Robert Pardikes THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Credit Risk & Default Management (S) Credit Risk & Default Management (DCZ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Weaknesses in Default Management test plan could lead to inadequate operational readiness in the event of a clearing member default due to undetected operational weaknesses resulting in uncoordinated or delayed responses during an actual default event. The identified weakness could result in minor financial and material adverse regulatory impact.  Hannes Hauenschild DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Internal Audit recommends that AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to design and implement written rules for “High-Risk” use cases.  6/4/2025 6/15/2026 6/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Anvay Walavalkar Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Internal Audit recommends that ICT Risk Framework (KJU) creates and implements the ICT Risk AI guideline based on identified risks related to AI and trigger the following processes in cooperation with respect to departments  6/4/2025 3/15/2026 3/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Sarah Ahmad Jahn CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-025_F01 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F01-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Gaps in the AI Governance Framework Deutsche Börse Group (DBG) has named Artificial intelligence (AI) as a key driver of digital leadership as part of its Horizon 2026 strategy. DBG aims to transition from the status of Observer to Practitioner of AI. It has created a Governance Framework around AI to achieve this objective and to be compliant to internal and external regulatory requirements.

 

The current AI Governance Framework included the following shortcomings:

 

Missing procedures for High-Risk AI Systems:The guideline on IT Compliance, Artificial Intelligence and Segregation of Duties required the creation of ‘additional procedures’ for High-Risk AI use cases. These ‘additional procedures’ had not been designed or documented so far. The AI Use Case Inventory in JIRA did not present any use case classified as “High-Risk” according to risk assessment performed. Furthermore, our test noted that classifying a use case as “High-Risk” triggered a notification to the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and put the use case in an “Approval block”, although not rejecting it.

The ICT Risk Framework was not adapted to include AI-related risks. Risks arising from the use of AI were not analysed, identified and captured in the framework. Respective ICT guidelines and ICT procedures were not established to estimate and mitigate the ICT AI risks. As a result, these risks were not considered within risk assessments of the systems with AI Usage.

 

The Material Change Committee for DBAG (MCC) and Material Change Working Group (MCWG) for CBL, CBF, CFCL (hereinafter referred to as the Material Change Committees) have been tasked with ensuring adequate governance regarding material changes including proposed AI use cases. As part of the decision-making in the Material Change Process, the AI CoE has acted as the 1LOD Control Function providing advice to the Material Change Committees regarding risks and efficacy of the proposed control measures with respect to AI use cases. Although a documented AI Governance Framework and defined roles were in place, no criteria were documented beyond the AI Use Case Inventory questionnaire to guide the AI CoE’s assessment of proposed AI use cases, to allow suitable challenge by the Material Change Commitees, and consequently to ensure adherence to the necessary guardrails and principles of the EU AI Act in line with DBG’s risk appetite. The Material Change Guideline for DBG did not describe the role of the AI COE control function in the MCP process for AI related changes.

 

 

According to EU AI Act and DBG written rules, require organization to develop and implement robust AI governance structure and AI Literacy. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance (SCG) 

 

Define clear criteria and / or provide additional trainings as applicable, which act as the basis for the AI Center of Excellence (CoE) and Material Change Committee (MCC) / Material Change Working Group (MCWG), to provide them with the notions to challenge the assessments on the AI use cases, thereby ensuring the necessary guardrails are consistently applied during AI use case implementation.

Amend the Material Change Guideline to define Key tasks and responsibilities of AI Centre of Excellence as a control function in the MCP Process 		 6/4/2025 11/14/2025 11/14/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Shravankumar Mohankumar Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT Governance, People & Culture (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Group Compliance Strategy (S) Group Compliance (SCG) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Lack of clearly defined AI Governance Framework can lead to operational failures, loss of trust, privacy and ethical issues, and non-compliance with the regulatory requirements. Absence of documented criteria and guidance for the AI CoE and MCC may impede their decision-making process in terms of compliance and consistency.  Marco Popp CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PAULUN TOBIAS(European Energy Exchange),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),REITZ PETER(European Energy Exchange),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-025_F02 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate Inventory and Classification of AI use cases Internal Audit recommends AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to review and update the AI System Management Process and the AI Use Case Inventory to ensure alignment between the documented process, the system’s attributes, and relevant internal and external requirements. This should include but not be limited to:

Re-assessing all AI use cases previously evaluated based on the shortened list of questions.

Defining and implementing a control to verify the accuracy of each use case’s classification. 

Defining all implemented attributes within the AI Use Case Inventory to eliminate ambiguity and ensure consistent data capture by use case submitters.

Implementing and enforcing all mandatory attributes within the system as necessary during the process, e.g. when the Use Case is submitted to the MCC and/or once the use case is adopted “In Production” or put in place effective controls to prevent incomplete data.

Establishing clear governance and maintenance procedures for the AI Use Case Inventory, including regular reviews and updates by process owners and system maintainers, to ensure ongoing alignment of the inventory with evolving requirements and to address any future discrepancies. 		 Internal Audit recommends AI Center of Excellence (ACE) to review and update the AI System Management Process and the AI Use Case Inventory to ensure alignment between the documented process, the system’s attributes, and relevant internal and external requirements. This should include but not be limited to:

Re-assessing all AI use cases previously evaluated based on the shortened list of questions.

Defining and implementing a control to verify the accuracy of each use case’s classification. 

Defining all implemented attributes within the AI Use Case Inventory to eliminate ambiguity and ensure consistent data capture by use case submitters.

Implementing and enforcing all mandatory attributes within the system as necessary during the process, e.g. when the Use Case is submitted to the MCC and/or once the use case is adopted “In Production” or put in place effective controls to prevent incomplete data.

Establishing clear governance and maintenance procedures for the AI Use Case Inventory, including regular reviews and updates by process owners and system maintainers, to ensure ongoing alignment of the inventory with evolving requirements and to address any future discrepancies. 		 6/4/2025 3/15/2026 3/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Fabrice Emanuel Campas Moreira Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation  The JIRA-based AI Use Case Inventory tool serves as a repository for AI use cases and provides the functionality to classify them. The classification relies on a questionnaire (Red Flag Check) designed to evaluate the risk level of each use case according to the EU AI Act. 

 

The audit revealed the existence of two different questionnaires within the JIRA tool: an older, shorter version with only two use case categories (prohibited and high-risk) and a newer, longer version with four categories (prohibited, high-risk, General Purpose AI [GPAI] and GPAI with system risk). In addition to the different set of categories, the high-risk use case characteristics were expanded with further questions. 

 

Many use cases (up to AIUC-54), some of which are already in production, were classified using the shorter questionnaire. However, the shorter version did not cover all relevant categories (e.g. GPAI) or the characteristics of specific use case categories defined in the EU AI Act. Despite the changes in the classification questionnaire, existing use cases were not reassessed. Furthermore, controls were missing to verify the accuracy of the use case classification. 

 

The AI Use Case Inventory tool utilised in the AI Use Case Initiation[3], a sub-process of the AI System Management Process[4], contained attributes that were not defined within the user documentation linked in the process documentation (specifically in the AI Use Case Inventory attributes appendix). The user documentation was outdated and marked mandatory attributes that were not enforced by the system or by defined controls. This can be exemplified by the sub-process Check AI UC information for completion, which relied on accurate and complete information for its assessment.

 

According to the EU AI Act text note 26 as of June 13, 2024, organisations shall establish, implement, and maintain a risk management system adequately. To introduce a proportionate and effective set of binding rules for AI systems, a clearly defined risk-based approach should be followed.  		 Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-025_F03 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F03-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incompleteness in the AI system management process Internal Audit recommends that the AI Center of Excellence (ACE) update the AI System Management Process. The following steps should be implemented regarding the AI-related inventories:

The AI Initiation Process requires approved and implemented AI Use Cases to be part of APMS.

If necessary, implement the AI System Change form.

Update status of AI Use Cases in order to measure KPIs, as described in the AI System Management Process.

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 Internal Audit recommends that the AI Center of Excellence (ACE) update the AI System Management Process. The following steps should be implemented regarding the AI-related inventories:

The AI Initiation Process requires approved and implemented AI Use Cases to be part of APMS.

If necessary, implement the AI System Change form.

Update status of AI Use Cases in order to measure KPIs, as described in the AI System Management Process.

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 6/4/2025 11/14/2025 11/14/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski AI Center of Excellence (U) AI Center of Excellence (ACE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incompleteness in the AI system management process, and in particular the lack of clear rules for system flagging as AI Usage can lead to misunderstanding and as a result, to incorrect handling of components using AI and inadvertent omission of crucial process steps. It could further lead to an under- or overestimation of the overall risks for DBG.  Melinda Bajai CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Inadequate Governance Structure Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-025_F03 2025 2025-025 Special Audit on AI (DBAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-025_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incompleteness in the AI system management process Internal Audit recommends that the AI Center of Excellence (ACE) update the AI System Management Process. The following steps should be implemented regarding the AI-related inventories:

The AI Initiation Process requires approved and implemented AI Use Cases to be part of APMS.

If necessary, implement the AI System Change form.

Update status of AI Use Cases in order to measure KPIs, as described in the AI System Management Process.

Include the AI use case change process into AI System Change Process. 		 Internal Audit recommends that IT Core Process Design and Operations (ÜPÜ) update the Application Portfolio Management System User Manual based on the following points:

The application owner/business owner should initiate the AI use case lifecycle process upon identifying AI embedded in the application. 

The logical or technical connection between JIRA and APMS must be described and published to users. 		 6/4/2025 11/14/2025 11/14/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Olga Braitsev Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Core Process Governance (U) IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.
