2025-029_F04 2025 2025-029 Payment Services (ECAG) 2025-029_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Missing control evidence for onboarding of J.P. Morgan Internal Audit (IA) noted missing control evidence for the onboarding of J.P. Morgan Chase Bank N.A. – London Branch. The absence of this documentation, potentially due to archival issues related to the transfer of ownership from ETD Clearing Design (ECD) to Cash & Securities Clearing Design (SSU), prevented verification of a complete and compliant onboarding process.

Specifically, the following control evidence could not be provided during the audit:
§ Evidence of four-eyes principle applied to J.P. Morgan’s response to Eurex Clearing’s Request for Proposal
§ Eurex Clearing Executive Board approval on selection of the bank
§ Signed settlement bank agreement between Eurex Clearing A.G. and J.P. Morgan Chase Bank N.A. – London Branch
§
European and German regulations require that business activities are conducted based on organizational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Cash & Securities Clearing Design (SSU) to:
§ provide outstanding evidence for the onboarding of JP Morgan, as requested during the audit, to facilitate closure of this finding
§ implement a formal, documented procedure for the consistent collection, review, and archival of all required onboarding documentation for new payment and correspondent banks
§ establish a clear process for the transfer of ownership and documentation responsibilities during process transitions, such as handovers		 6/30/2025 9/15/2025 10/17/2025 1 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Cash & Securities Clearing Design (U) Cash & Securities Clearing Design (SSU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Missing control evidence for onboarding of J.P. Morgan suggests a potential breakdown in control verification. This may lead to material violation of internal and external provisions, such as minor regulatory breaches. Stefan Gasper JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No No Yes No
2025-031_F02 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) is designed to serve as a central inventory of all relevant applications used across DBG and its subsidiaries.

Internal Audit noted that the inventory was incomplete:
§ CUBE Reg-Track is an external web interface owned by Reg-Room LLC and used across DBG entities through associated software licenses to identify and monitor applicable regulations as part of the Legal Inventory process. It was not captured in APMS as a standalone application. Consequently, the ownership, governance for oversight purposes, criticality assessment and information classification were not defined.
§ RegMon (AID886) did not contain in the Legal Entity pane the “Using” legal entity Clearstream Banking S.A. (CBL), despite the use of the application by CBL. Additionally, LuxCSD S.A., and Clearstream International S.A. (CI) were using RegMon through CBL. At the time of the audit, only German-based entities were listed.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets.		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Compliance Oversight (COG), in consultation with IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) and ICT Risk Framework (KJU):
§ ensure that all external web interfaces   used within the scope of DBAG Compliance Legal Inventory-related processes, including CUBE Reg-Track, are captured in APMS
§ in its role of Business Owner, support the review and update of the legal entity pane in APMS to accurately reflect all entities actively using RegMon (AID886)		 6/25/2025 11/17/2025 11/17/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Johan Luc Palix Randi Montgomery HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT Governance, People & Culture (Div) Chief Compliance Officer (A) Marc Peter Klein Group Compliance Oversight (S) Group Compliance Oversight (COG) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) may expose the company to inaccurate IT asset tracking, reduced visibility over regulatory-relevant tools, and weakened governance over application ownership and accountability. This could lead to minor financial losses and material reputational, regulatory and internal provisions, resulting from compliance gaps, operational inefficiencies, and auditability issues. Miriam Schmitz ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Yes Yes No Yes No No No
2025-031_F02 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) is designed to serve as a central inventory of all relevant applications used across DBG and its subsidiaries.

Internal Audit noted that the inventory was incomplete:
§ CUBE Reg-Track is an external web interface owned by Reg-Room LLC and used across DBG entities through associated software licenses to identify and monitor applicable regulations as part of the Legal Inventory process. It was not captured in APMS as a standalone application. Consequently, the ownership, governance for oversight purposes, criticality assessment and information classification were not defined.
§ RegMon (AID886) did not contain in the Legal Entity pane the “Using” legal entity Clearstream Banking S.A. (CBL), despite the use of the application by CBL. Additionally, LuxCSD S.A., and Clearstream International S.A. (CI) were using RegMon through CBL. At the time of the audit, only German-based entities were listed.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets.		 Internal Audit recommends that Regulatory Compliance (RTY), with the support of Group Compliance Oversight (COG), update the Legal Entity pane   in APMS to accurately reflect the use of RegMon by the CBL legal entity (including LuxCSD and CI).  6/25/2025 11/17/2025 11/17/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg Johan Luc Palix Randi Montgomery HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Regulatory Compliance (U) Regulatory Compliance (RTY) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Incomplete inventory of two applications in DBG’s Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) may expose the company to inaccurate IT asset tracking, reduced visibility over regulatory-relevant tools, and weakened governance over application ownership and accountability. This could lead to minor financial losses and material reputational, regulatory and internal provisions, resulting from compliance gaps, operational inefficiencies, and auditability issues. Laura Mendez Rodriguez ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Control Des. 2025-031_F05 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in controls related to the creation of the annual reporting to the CFTC Since December 2018, Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG) has been permitted to clear futures commission merchant customer positions as well as continue clearing proprietary positions for US Clearing Members. For this purpose, annually, the US Chief Compliance Officer (US CCO) is required to prepare and sign a written report that covers the most recently completed fiscal year of ECAG. This ECAG Year End Derivatives Clearing Organization (DCO) Annual Report (Annual Report) is designed to ensure compliance with Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) Regulation 39.10(c)(3) and filed with the CFTC.

Among the duties of the US CCO is reviewing the DCO’s compliance with the Core Principles set forth in section 5b of the Dodd-Frank Act, and the CFTC’s regulations thereunder. Further, it is CCP Compliance’s responsibility to detect any risk of failure by ECAG and its employees to comply with applicable laws and regulations.

The filed Annual Report 2024 contained reference to relevant policy/procedure documents designed to ensure compliance with each DCO Core Principle and corresponding CFTC regulation. For each policy or procedure, there was a brief description, mention of the responsible person(s) and the latest version.

For facilitating work around the Annual Report and for internal tracking purposes, the US CCO had created a SharePoint folder for collecting copies of the latest relevant policy/procedure documents as mentioned in the Annual Report 2024. Moreover, there was an internal checklist listing in each tab one DCO Core Principle and the following entry fields:
§ the related policy/procedure documents designed to ensure compliance
§ responsible person(s) for these documents
§ a certification requirement (either ensuring compliance or stating areas for improvement)

Prior  to finalizing the Annual Report 2024, the US CCO sent an email to a distribution list requiring the upload of most recent version of policies/procedures and that the responsible person for a policy/procedure in the provided excel sheet write that the policy/procedure was effective in ensuring compliance with that Core Principle and, if applicable, accompanying CFTC rule, or if not, why not. The internal certification requirement was repeated in the checklist, which stated: Please certify and initial or state areas for improvement.

Based on sampling, Internal Audit noted several entries in the checklist that did not explicitly fulfil the above-mentioned certification requirement. Instead, there were the following entries:
§ some contained only the name of a document
§ some contained the information that a document was valid
§ some made reference to specific pages and contents of The IT Strategy 2024 relating to CFTC Rules
§ some lines stated annual review finalized - no areas for improvement identified for continued compliance (only editorial changes)

In addition, the following inaccuracies were identified related to the filed Annual Report 2024:
§ There was a mention of Eurex Clearing AG Policy and Procedure for Reporting to the CFTC in the Annual Report 2024, although this document was obsolete.
§ The filed Annual Report 2024 referred to v1.8 of the Eurex Clearing DCO Compliance Manual. The cover page of this Manual, as provided to IA, stated v2.0, whereas the further pages stated v1.5.
§ The person responsible for DBG IT Service Continuity Management Guideline was not the same in the Annual Report 2024 as in the checklist.
§ The physical security policy was removed from the Annual Report 2024, however, it was provided and also contained in the checklist.

Moreover, SAP Governance, Risk and Compliance Internal Control System (GRC ICS) contained no risk entry related to policies/procedures not being compliant with CFTC requirements. This was despite the existence of a key control related to the certifications, as described above. Further, there was a mismatch in GRC ICS mainly between risk, control and evidence.

German regulation and DBG policy require that financial institutions implement an effective Internal Control System and the Supervisory Board to monitor the effectiveness of the ICS.		 Internal Audit recommends that CCP Compliance (CPC):
§ ensure strict adherence to the internally requested certification requirement, including a procedure for the handling of exceptions
§ introduce a 4EP control on the accuracy of the contents of the annual report, in particular section 2.1 DCO Core Principle compliance chart
§ in GRC ICS, include entries for the existing key control related to internal certifications and make corrections to the documented risk, control and evidence to remove the mismatch		 6/25/2025 3/23/2026 3/23/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Compliance (U) CCP Compliance (CPC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in controls related to the creation of the annual reporting to the CFTC may undermine DCO’s compliance with rules and regulations. The partial absence of the internally requested explicit certification that existing policy/procedure documents are effective in ensuring compliance with certain rules and regulations may indicate instances of non-compliance. The weaknesses represent a material gap in internal provisions and may have a material adverse regulatory impact. Key controls not contained in GRC ICS may not be designed and/or performed adequately. Bianca Sahrholz MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes Yes No No No
2025-031_F06 2025 2025-031 General Compliance Audit (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-031_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses related to internal outsourcing relationships Internal Audit identified that:
§ no signed version of the ECAG (supplier) – DBAG (customer) SDS for Compliance Services effective 1 January 2024 was available
§ the Compliance section of the ECAG process map contained the following weakness: The outsourcing and insourcer fields were not reflecting the related outsourcing relationships, which existed between on the one hand ECAG and on the other hand DBAG, EFAG and DBS Inc., respectively

European and German regulation require robust governance arrangements including clear organizational structures with well-defined lines of responsibility. In case of outsourcings, the outsourcer remains fully responsible for any outsourced activities. Internal requirements state that each third-party service needs to be based on a written contract that specifies the services and details specific arrangements such as rules and modalities for sub-contracting.		 Internal Audit recommends that CCP Compliance (CPC):
§ finalize an SDS between ECAG (supplier) – DBAG (customer) SDS for Compliance Services, and make required arrangements that consider that the related services became effective as of 1 January 2024
§ make amendments to the ECAG process map to properly reflect the existing outsourcing arrangements

The last bullet of the recommendation has been adequately addressed before the issuance of the audit report.		 6/25/2025 12/10/2025 12/10/2025 0 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Compliance (U) CCP Compliance (CPC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses related to internal outsourcing relationships represent a minor breach of regulatory requirements and non-compliance with internal policies. This may lead to deviations in service quality and/or erroneous intercompany billing with minor financial impact. Bianca Sahrholz HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes Yes No No No
2025-034_F02 2025 2025-034 Securities Processing (ECAG) 2025-034_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Insufficiently documented controls within Securities Processing process Internal Audit (IA) noted insufficiently documented controls and steps
done within:
§ Regarding the C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up subprocess, on the 5 months sample:
- In 1 tested month, step 7 was not fully performed on entering the details of all ECAXX cash movements in the Daily Cash Reco Reporting Sheet (Cash Reco daily reporting.xlsx) although check was assessed as completed in Checklist. The excel file was updated during audit with missing information in the sheet Sonstige Cash-Details.
- In 1 tested month, step 10 to inform relevant departments about the extraordinary settlement was not fully performed, although check was assessed as completed in Checklist. Namely, Eurex COO & CRO were not informed. The risk is partially mitigated as they were informed at later stage when DMP requested the activation of ECAXX.

§ Regarding the Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction subprocess, on the population of 5 cases:
- In 2 tested cases, step 3 member notifications were prepared and sent based on outdated notification templates (outdated contacts on the template). Risk is mitigated as template is no longer in use.

§ Regarding the Cash Settlement Equities subprocess, on the 5 months sample:
- In all 5 tested months, calculation of Cash Settlement amount signed, Announcement of Cash Settlement to CM and Cash Settlement Fee recording was not documented under Organizational 4 eyes-principle, although it was designed.
§ Regarding the Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling subprocess, on sample of 3 quarters:
- In 2 tested quarters, Checklist tasks were not fully marked as complete.

Internal business procedures 7.2.5.3.3 C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up defined excel sheet and tabs to be updated and , relevant departments to be informed. 7.2.1.3.12 Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction defined notification templated to be used. 7.2.1.1.7 Cash Settlement Equities defined organizational 4 eyes-principle controls to be followed, 7.2.1.2.6 Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling defined usage of checklists for subprocess execution accuracy.		 Internal Audit recommends that Securities Clearing Operations (ZQY) perform controls based on the designed 7.2.5.3.3 C7 SCS Balance Check – Imbalance Clean-Up, 7.2.1.3.12 Coupon Compensation – Net-Gross Tax Correction, 7.2.1.1.7 Cash Settlement Equities and 7.2.1.2.6 Eurex Fixed Income Futures expiry handling subprocesses. 6/17/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Securities Clearing Operations (U) Securities Clearing Operations (ZQY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficiently documented controls within Securities Processing process bears the risk of inability to prove control efficiency. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions and could have material adverse regulatory impact in terms of regulatory examinations in case control performance could not be completely proved. Nadezhda Ermakova JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No No Yes No
2025-048_F01 2025 2025-048 IT Network Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-048_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete configuration of compliance checks in SolarWinds For the SolarWinds Orion4 (AID974), which checks network device configurations against the baseline, Internal Audit identified incomplete configuration of compliance checks as well as incomplete definition in the underlying baseline, namely:

The Network Security baseline for all network devices was last updated in December 2023 and therefore was outdated. The baseline-owner, Vulnerability Management (VLM), has already planned a review and update.

Mandatory (M) and Best Practices (BP) baselines for CheckPoint GAIA5 (GAIA baseline, chapter 5.1) were defined in the baseline document. According to auditee, IT Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) was not requested by the baseline owner to implement the SolarWinds’s PROD-compliance check for CheckPoint GAIA.

Some baseline requirements related to password expiration, e.g. FWCP1.5, FWCP1.7, were not implemented. According to auditee, the implementation would have caused operational issues.

Certain GAIA-related baselines were not marked as M or BP at all. Exceptions (GAIA baseline requirements not implemented) were not raised and therefore not managed as a risk.

The baseline did not clearly define and distinguish between “must”, “should”, “optional” and “best practice”.

According to the baseline, “all the criteria must be met, and a clear justification for any exceptions will have to be provided. This applied both to Mandatory criteria and to criteria marked as Best Practice”. BP baselines were understood only as optional, not implemented and not documented as an exception.

Even though some BP baselines were listed in the SolarWinds PROD-rules as a compliance-rule, the rule was empty and set as placeholder. This applied to several network assets listed in the Baseline document, such as CheckPoint, Cisco ASR, Cisco FTD, Hirschman Switch, Metamako Switch.

In the timeframe of the audit-closure, Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) removed all empty or placeholder rules in production.

A four-eyes control, implemented to remediate the S2 finding “2021-044_F02” in “2021-044 IT Infrastructure audit”, was designed, implemented, and operated by Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) as ‘Rule Implementer’ and involved the ‘Baseline Owner’ as counterpart. The control was only executed once by all parties involved. By now the process is implemented manually without automated interfaces.

Even though firewalls operating on GAIA-OS6 were not integrated in the compliance checks, baseline requirements were generally considered and implemented on production devices.

IA’s sample testing noted minor implementation deviations to baseline FWCP3.13 (Firewall_secure_settings), which could have been identified when properly integrated in the configuration compliance check. For example, device csffbu19-fo is set to issue an alert when disk is below 3000MB (local storage), and device cxfkxxd8 is set for an alert when disk is below 5% of local storage.

 

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require that organizations implement and maintain effective, continuous compliance monitoring controls – such as properly configured tools like SolarWinds – to detect, report, and respond to security and policy violations in a timely manner. 		 Based on the revised baseline document to be established in action A01, Internal Audit (IA) recommends that Corporate IT Tools (ZFL)
§ Implement requirements as per revised Baseline, in particular requirements focusing on CheckPoint devices.
§ Ensure the four-eyes control is performed as designed.		 6/25/2025 10/31/2025 10/31/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Frank Ackermann Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Infrastructure Service Tools (U) Corporate IT Tools (ZFL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Incomplete configuration of compliance checks in SolarWinds may lead to undetected policy violations and delayed response to security issues, increasing the risk of non-compliance and operational exposure, resulting in:

Minor breach of regulatory requirements (e.g. non-existent description/ documentation of processes and/ or control environment)

Incomplete or non-compliant security configurations and hardening settings of applications and underlying network devices protecting ICT assets

Not meeting regulatory and internal requirements. 		 Ralf Wießner CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

The following CIF-relevant processes without BCP were identified per Legal Entity:
§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Internal Audit recommends that Business Continuity Management (ZHI)
§ Updates the current BCM framework for DBAG, EFAG and ExR and amend relevant processes and procedures to clarify the handling of essential, necessary or desirable CIF-relevant processes and how they should be considered and treated in terms of business continuity.
§ Ensure that the relevant processes under CIF have a BCP in place or assess and document the root cause for the deviation  resulting from the Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and the CIF classification.		 7/4/2025 11/10/2025 11/10/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Iryna Neurath Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer Business Continuity Management (U) Business Continuity Management (ZHI) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Misalignment of Critical or Important Functions identified with processes requiring Business Continuity Plan coverage and incomplete BCM framework may lead to non-compliance with regulations, which may further lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage and regulatory scrutiny. Additionally, the potential lack of appropriate business continuity measures might expose the organisation to business continuity risks. As Internal Audit did not assess the identified processes without a BCP as critical, their absence does not pose a significant risk to the organisation’s continuity objectives.  Kiriaki Chatzianastasiou ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No Yes No No
2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

The following CIF-relevant processes without BCP were identified per Legal Entity:
§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Internal Audit recommends that Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB):
§ Updates the current BCM framework for ECAG and amend relevant processes and procedures to clarify the handling of essential, necessary or desirable CIF-relevant processes and how they should be considered and treated in terms of business continuity.
§ Ensure that the relevant processes under CIF have a BCP in place or assess and document the root cause for the deviation resulting from the Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and the CIF classification.		 7/4/2025 11/10/2025 11/10/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Eurex Clearing AG Iryna Neurath Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (U) Non-Financial Risk, ICS & BCM (FRB) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Misalignment of Critical or Important Functions identified with processes requiring Business Continuity Plan coverage and incomplete BCM framework may lead to non-compliance with regulations, which may further lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage and regulatory scrutiny. Additionally, the potential lack of appropriate business continuity measures might expose the organisation to business continuity risks. As Internal Audit did not assess the identified processes without a BCP as critical, their absence does not pose a significant risk to the organisation’s continuity objectives.  Oussama Fakih ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

The following CIF-relevant processes without BCP were identified per Legal Entity:
§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Internal Audit recommends that NFR & Operational Resilience (ORN)
§ Update the current BCM framework documentation and amend relevant processes and procedures to clarify the handling of CIF-relevant processes and how they should be considered and treated in terms of business continuity
§ Annually review the list of relevant processes under CIFs without a BCP and assess the root cause for the deviation resulting from the Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and the CIF classification and perform re-assessments, if assessed necessary
§ Inform the Legal entity DORA projects about the discrepancy in order to take potential corrective actions		 7/4/2025 11/10/2025 11/10/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Iryna Neurath Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO STEEG Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll NFR & Operational Resilience (U) NFR & Operational Resilience (ORN) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Misalignment of Critical or Important Functions identified with processes requiring Business Continuity Plan coverage and incomplete BCM framework may lead to non-compliance with regulations, which may further lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage and regulatory scrutiny. Additionally, the potential lack of appropriate business continuity measures might expose the organisation to business continuity risks. As Internal Audit did not assess the identified processes without a BCP as critical, their absence does not pose a significant risk to the organisation’s continuity objectives.  Karla Sanchez Ibarra ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-024_F02 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F02-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Misalignment of CIFs identified with processes requiring BCP coverage and incomplete BCM framework. Internal Audit (IA) compared for consistency the processes in the Critical or Important Functions (CIF) repository established by ICT Risk under the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), and their Business Impact Analysis (BIA) criticality.

Across all in-scope legal entities, 70 out of the total 280 CIF-relevant processes have only been assessed in their latest BIA as either essential, necessary or desirable. For DBAG, EFAG, ExR, ECAG and CFCL essential, necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place. For CBF and CBL necessary or desirable processes, no Business Continuity Plans (BCP) were in place in line with current Business Continuity Management (BCM) guidelines.

The following CIF-relevant processes without BCP were identified per Legal Entity:
§ DBAG - 3 processes (2 essential and 1 necessary; closed during the audit)
§ EFAG - 2 processes (1 essential and 1 desirable)
§ ExR - 4 processes (2 essential, 1 desirable and 1 necessary)
§ ECAG - 8 processes (5 essential, 1 desirable and 2 necessary)
§ CBF - 17 processes (11 desirable and 6 necessary)
§ CBL - 26 processes (9 desirable and 17 necessary)
§ CFCL - 10 processes (4 essential, 4 desirable and 2 necessary)

Internal Audit noted that no BCPs were established for the above CIF-relevant processes as the BCP requirement is based, according to the BCM Framework documentation, on the BIA criticality which entails the Recovery Time Objective (RTO). However, DORA Article 11 paragraph 2(a) mandates that financial entities shall ensure the continuity of their CIFs “through dedicated, appropriate and documented arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms”.

IA noted a lack of clarity in the BCM framework documentation, regarding CIF-relevant processes in terms of business continuity, including clarifying how to document the business continuity approach for CIF-relevant processes without a BCP. The BCM framework was consequently not updated to completely reflect DORA’s continuity requirements that came into force on 17 January 2025. Moreover, the CIF Identification Procedure has not offered any further clarification for inclusion and documentation regarding CIF relevant processes and considerations given during the CIF identification process		 Internal Audit recommends that Business Continuity Management (BMA)
§ updates the current BCM framework documentation and amends relevant processes and procedures to clarify the handling of CIF-relevant processes and how they should be considered and treated in terms of business continuity
§ annually reviews the list of relevant processes under CIFs without a BCP and ensures the latest Business Impact Analysis (BIA) supports any deviation and reperforms the BIA, if assessed necessary
§ informs the legal entity DORA projects about the discrepancy in order to take potential corrective actions		 7/4/2025 11/10/2025 11/10/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD CBL Luxembourg Iryna Neurath Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) JEAN-MARC DI CATO Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Business Continuity Management (U) Business Continuity Management (BMA) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Misalignment of Critical or Important Functions identified with processes requiring Business Continuity Plan coverage and incomplete BCM framework may lead to non-compliance with regulations, which may further lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage and regulatory scrutiny. Additionally, the potential lack of appropriate business continuity measures might expose the organisation to business continuity risks. As Internal Audit did not assess the identified processes without a BCP as critical, their absence does not pose a significant risk to the organisation’s continuity objectives.  François Viljoen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-024_F04 2025 2025-024 Special Audit on general controls (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-024_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weakness in controls for timely termination and recertification of external employees Internal Audit (IA) identified weaknesses in the external employees’ identity and access management’s request and change processes regarding timely offboarding and termination in SAP Mini-master and recertification of external employees.

SAP S/4HANA (AID489) Human Capital Management (HCM) module’s Mini-master process is used to manage on- and offboarding data for external employees. During an external employee’s onboarding, the “valid until” date field is populated in SAP Mini-master. Once this date is reached, SailPoint IIQ (AID760) automatically blocks both physical and system access.

However, when the contract ends or if an external employee leaves earlier than expected, termination must be manually initiated in SAP Mini-master by entering the new effective leave date. Termination ensures the employee is marked as “inactive”, and their access is blocked in a timely manner. IA noted that due to delays by line managers, 263 external employees who had already left before 2024 were only terminated in SAP Mini-master in 2024.

IA acknowledges that the following controls were in place:
§ a "Dead Man Lock" is automatically applied to deactivate user accounts after 28 days of inactivity.
§ a quarterly awareness information campaign is published through DBG communication channels (e.g. Intranet, Viva Engage), and End User Trainings are provided on SAP Mini-master system maintenance.
§ a new initiative is being introduced, which will result in automatic termination of the Mini-master record when the “valid until” date arrives.
However, this initiative does not cover scenarios where an external employee leaves before the “valid until” date. In such cases, manual termination is still required.

Furthermore, IA identified recertification process weaknesses. Based on the “contact person” data field, SAP Mini-master sent regularly, in the middle of the month, an automated notification to the respective contact persons/ordering party (line or project managers) to recertify active external employees or initiate offboarding. If the contact person took no action, two more notifications were sent before the month end, with the line manager in copy of the final reminder. However, Purchasing (FPU) had no additional controls in place if recertification was not conducted even after these notifications.

In line with European, German, Luxembourg regulation and internal requirements, an entity should establish controls to identify and manage unauthorised user access to the applications.		 Internal Audit recommends that Purchasing (FPU) establish additional controls to ensure:
§ timely offboarding and termination in SAP Mini-master
§ recertification of external employees by respective line managers		 7/4/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Trupti Thakur Elizaveta Veselova GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Purchasing (S) Purchasing (FPU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Delay in termination of external employees may:
§ lead to former external employees retaining access after leaving the organisation, potentially enabling them to still access IT systems and misuse their access rights for unauthorised activity.
§ result in a material violation of internal and external provisions related to the Information Security framework.		 Stefan Schwind ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),PHILIP BROWN(CBL Luxembourg),PHILIPPE SEYLL(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No Yes No
2025-032_F01 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inconsistences in Risk Management governance documents after reorganization Prior to the reorganization of the Risk Management Department, the Risk Analytics unit was responsible for subprocesses related to Credit Risk, Concentration Risk, and Wrong-Way Risk monitoring. Following the departmental restructuring effective 1 January 2025, these responsibilities were redistributed between the Reporting & Quality Data Management (RDQ) team and the Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) unit.
However, Internal Audit (IA) noted that the updated roles and responsibilities resulting from this reorganization have not been reflected in key governance documents, including:
§ Exposure, Entity, Aggregation & Classification Concept
§ Credit Risk Concept
§ Additionally Monitored Risk Framework
Despite the absence of updated documentation, IA did not identify any deficiencies in the execution or performance of the relevant subprocesses during the review period.
 
As per internal and external requirements, the roles and responsibilities of the organization should be clearly established.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) unit to initiate a formal review and update of all affected governance documents—specifically the Exposure, Entity, Aggregation & Classification Concept, Credit Risk Concept, and Additionally Monitored Risk Framework. These updates must incorporate the revised roles and responsibilities resulting from the departmental reorganization that took effect on 1 January 2025, ensuring that the documentation accurately reflects the current operational structure.  7/31/2025 11/7/2025 11/7/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Credit Risk Management & Governance (U) Credit Risk Management & Governance (DMD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/implemented the recommendation.  Inconsistencies in Risk Management governance documents after reorganization can lead to operational errors, ineffective risk oversight, miscommunication, and non-compliance with internal policies or regulatory expectations.  Vincent Prepin DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities Control Env. + Control Des. Eff. Yes Yes No No Yes No No
2025-032_F02 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate process controls for credit rating triggers Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the additional risk monitoring process and identified 13 credit rating-related triggers that occur on an ad hoc basis. The 13 identified triggers span across onboarding, rating changes, counterpart terminations, mergers, and data quality updates. Each trigger initiates a specific task by Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to ensure that internal credit ratings are accurate, current, and properly reflected in the CESAR system. These triggers are critical for ensuring timely and accurate updates to reference data, which directly impact risk assessments. The review highlighted the following gaps in the current process design and control environment:
§ Lack of centralized oversight: There is no centralized mechanism to monitor the status or progress of actions taken, resulting in limited transparency and control over process execution. Additionally, responsibilities are assigned only at the unit level, with no individual accountability for specific triggers.
§ Absence of Structured Documentation: Actions taken in response to triggers are not consistently recorded. Without a formal documentation framework, audit trail integrity is compromised, and the ability to trace or reconstruct activities—especially in cases of staff turnover or downstream errors—is hindered.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to implement a centralized oversight mechanism to monitor and track the status and completion of credit rating-related triggers, ensuring timely and consistent execution. Additionally, a structured documentation process should be established to record all actions taken in response to these triggers, supporting traceability and auditability.  7/31/2025 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Reporting & Data Quality Management (U) Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/implemented the recommendation.  Inadequate process controls for credit rating triggers—due to lack of centralized oversight and structured documentation—may lead to delayed or inaccurate risk data updates. This increases the risk of regulatory non-compliance, financial misstatements, and material reputational damage, particularly if incorrect data informs key risk decisions or is reported externally  Peter Linß DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2025-037_F02 2025 2025-037 Corporate Tax (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-037_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in Corporate Tax services outsourcing agreements and KPI reports Internal Audit (IA) assessed 16 Service Definition Statements (SDS) and Intra Service Definition Statements for the legal entities in scope of this audit. The assessment identified several deficiencies in the outsourcing agreements related to Corporate Tax services:
§ Eight SDS  contained incorrect references to the Tax Service Catalogue, which outlines and specifies the outsourced tax services.
§ Five SDS  were incomplete and inaccurate concerning the sub-outsourcing of tax services from DBAG to Clearstream Services (CS) for Luxembourg legal entities. The referenced 'Outsourcing Hub' was not consistently reflected across all relevant outsourcing agreements. IA also identified missing annexes and an unclear scope definition for the Luxembourg entities.
§ Financial Reporting was an agreed-upon service between several Luxembourg entities (CI, CBL, LuxCSD, and CS) and DBAG. However, this service was not reflected in the downstream SDS between DBAG and Clearstream Services (CS), resulting in a break in the documented outsourcing chain.

Additionally, IA identified weaknesses in the Key Performance Indicator (KPI) reports for Corporate Tax services. Specifically, the reports were incomplete in relation to the services defined in the SDS, and discrepancies were noted between the defined KPI metrics and the actual reported figures. For example, while the SDS specified a KPI target of 1 (reflecting the number of annual reports), a KPI of 300 was reported to the outsourcing legal entity.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations and guidance require that outsourcing arrangements be formalized through a service contract. These contracts must be complete, up to date, and accurately reflect all the services agreed upon between the outsourcing legal entity and the service provider. In addition, outsourced services must be subject to robust risk monitoring and management mechanisms to ensure regulatory compliance and maintain operational resilience.		 Internal Audit recommends that Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW):
§ Review and update all existing outsourcing agreements to ensure complete and correct representation of agreed Corporate Tax services in line with the Tax Service Catalogue.
§ Review and update all outsourcing contracts with regard to correct representation of tax services sub-outsourcing from DBAG to Clearstream Services (CS) for Luxembourg legal entities.
§ Revise the outsourcing agreement between CS and DBAG to ensure accurate representation of financial reporting responsibilities.
§ Review and align KPI reports with the KPIs defined in the respective outsourcing agreements.
§ Verify and correct the KPI reporting metrics to ensure consistency with contractual definitions.		 8/28/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Elena Krause Elena Krause GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (U) Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in Corporate Tax services outsourcing agreements and KPI reports represent a material violation of external provisions and internal policies. This may lead to deviations in service quality or erroneous intercompany billing with minor financial impact and minor regulatory sanctions. Marc Seedorf ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG) Lack of Awareness Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-037_F03 2025 2025-037 Corporate Tax (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-037_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the transfer pricing process Internal Audit identified several weaknesses in the transfer pricing process:
§ The Transfer Pricing Policy, last revised in August 2024, had not incorporated the new requirements regarding the transaction matrix and the expanded tax documentation obligations effective from January 1, 2025.
§ The Excel-based tracking list covered only Master and Local Files—mandatory documentation for tax audits—but did not include the transaction matrix, which became a required element as of January 1, 2025, with retroactive applicability to unaudited fiscal years.
§ Procedure 5.1 Transfer Pricing Documentation_v2.1, last updated in November 2024 did not reference the mandatory preparation, scope and documentation of the transaction matrix. In addition, there was no separate description with detailed information for the transaction matrix development process or for the scope of the legal entities concerned.
§ Sample evidence for process step and key control A9 Peer Review (linked to A8 Spot Check), as required by Organizational Policy chapter 3.3.1.2, was not available for the audit period.

According to internal and external provisions, require that business activities be conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to date description of processes that clearly defines relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically and requires a prompt amendment of the guidelines in the event of changes.		 Internal Audit recommends that Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW)
§ Review and update DBG’s Transfer Pricing Policy regarding the obligatory introduction and scope of the transaction matrix as well as the increased tax documentation duties, valid from 1 January 2025
§ Define a separate procedure for the creation process of the transaction matrix including responsibilities, timing, data sources, relevant transfer pricing information, controls, etc.
§ Expand the existing Excel tracking overview for local and master file preparation to also include the status of the transaction matrix.
§ Ensure immediately proper documentation of process step A9 Peer Review as defined.		 8/28/2025 10/23/2025 10/23/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sandra Schwarz Elena Krause GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (U) Tax Legal & Transfer Pricing (ZGW) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the transfer pricing process can expose DBG to minor financial, operational, regulatory, and reputational risks. These risks may arise from insufficient documentation, lack of oversight, inadequate risk assessments, or non-compliance with evolving internal and external requirements and can have a direct impact on the compliance, efficiency and tax position of the DBG companies concerned. Marc Seedorf ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-042_F04 2025 2025-042 Trading (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-042_F04-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 ECAG audit limitations for outsourced services  Derivatives Trading Operations (DTO), as part of Eurex Frankfurt AG (EFAG), performed processes both on behalf of Eurex Deutschland (ED) under public law and for EFAG as the exchange operator under private law.
Under contracts MA-002016-2020 (Daily Support and Product Data Maintenance Risk Services) and MA-001894-2020 (Daily Settlement Price Determination services), EFAG provided operational services to Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG). These outsourcing contracts also provided IA ECAG with unlimited audit rights.

Internal Audit (IA) observed that these services included activities that were also marked as carried out on behalf of ED under public law, such as the settlement process. IA ECAG did not have a general mandate to audit those service components governed by public law, as access is generally restricted by ED as a public exchange. The current situation does not fully reflect the contractually agreed audit rights without a specific mandate of ED.		 Internal Audit recommends Clearing Delivery & Control (DDF) to:
- assess the associated risks in collaboration with the insourcing party considering relevant governance decisions on audit rights from the insourcer’s side. Evaluate whether these decisions affect the existing contractual framework and prepare a set of actionable options for presentation to the ECAG Executive Board
- implement measures to remediate audit limitations following the decision of the ECAG Executive Board (for example, adjusting the underlying service contract)		 8/19/2025 7/16/2026 7/16/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Praveen Venkatachalam Andreas Seifert THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Clearing Delivery & Control (S) Clearing Delivery & Control (DDF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Audit restrictions could occur in future audits if this mandate is not granted by ED as it exceptionally was for 2025, potentially limiting IA ECAG’s ability to exercise effective oversight over the full scope of outsourced services. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions related to auditability and oversight responsibilities. It may also lead to significant regulatory impact and reputational damage. Markus Holecz JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Lack of Awareness Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No Yes No

2025-046_F01 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F01-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices Internal Audit (IA) noted a weakness in the control framework over duplicate invoices. Those with a purchase order (PO) were subject to a three-way match in SAP, acting as a preventive control to block potential duplicate or erroneous payments. However, non-PO invoices relied solely on embedded system rules functioning as a detective control. The rules flagged potential duplicates, but did not prevent them at source.

IA analyzed all invoices processed in VIM for the period under review using data analytics to flag entries which matched across different records and identified two instances (both below EUR 2K) where duplicate invoices were processed and paid, demonstrating that current controls over non-PO invoices were not sufficiently robust.

In line with external and internal provisions, management should maintain and enhance adequate and effective internal control mechanisms and risk management practices to address such risks.		 Internal Audit recommends that Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) provide refresher training to all staff involved in the invoice processing and approval workflow. The training should cover updated procedures, the importance of adhering to established controls (including duplicate payments checks), and any recent process changes or enhancements. 8/15/2025 12/16/2025 12/16/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ourania Androulaki Denise Weigelt GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Pr (U) Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices expose the company to the risk of material operational errors and financial losses due to duplicate or erroneous payments. This can also result in additional effort for reversals and reconciliations, impacting the efficiency of the company’s operations. Martin Kotula ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-046_F01 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices Internal Audit (IA) noted a weakness in the control framework over duplicate invoices. Those with a purchase order (PO) were subject to a three-way match in SAP, acting as a preventive control to block potential duplicate or erroneous payments. However, non-PO invoices relied solely on embedded system rules functioning as a detective control. The rules flagged potential duplicates, but did not prevent them at source.

IA analyzed all invoices processed in VIM for the period under review using data analytics to flag entries which matched across different records and identified two instances (both below EUR 2K) where duplicate invoices were processed and paid, demonstrating that current controls over non-PO invoices were not sufficiently robust.

In line with external and internal provisions, management should maintain and enhance adequate and effective internal control mechanisms and risk management practices to address such risks.		 Internal Audit recommends that Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) extend the current quarterly duplicate payment control (C_DBAG_MA_3.9.1_Duplicate payment check) to ensure that duplicate invoice checks are not limited to specific systems (e.g. Concur) or invoice types (PO) but include all invoices. This should leverage data analytics to systematically compare invoice reference numbers, amounts, vendors and currencies across the full invoice population, enabling timely identification and remediation of duplicate payments. ZCE should also update the Vendor Invoice Management procedure and ICS GRC control descriptions to align with the enhanced control design and objective. 8/15/2025 11/25/2025 11/25/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ourania Androulaki Denise Weigelt GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Pr (U) Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in the control of duplicate invoices expose the company to the risk of material operational errors and financial losses due to duplicate or erroneous payments. This can also result in additional effort for reversals and reconciliations, impacting the efficiency of the company’s operations. Martin Kotula ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-046_F02 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Incomplete Facility Management Frankfurt asset database Internal Audit (IA) noted that the tool Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) utilized to manage assets was incomplete: the Excel file did not comply with the DBG Asset Management Policy as it lacked mandatory information necessary to reconcile assets against the SAP S4 database for the Asset Inventory year-end process.

Specifically, IA’s data analytics on FMF’s total 11,533-asset inventory identified the following:
§ 3,899 cases had no company code, only an asset number.
§ 2,723 cases had neither a company code nor an asset number.
§ 3,538 cases belonged to the outdated company code “0000”.

Accounting Germany (FTD) relied on FMF’s data for the annual asset inventory preparation. This involved checking whether the SAP S4 assets under FMF responsibility were “in use”, “disposed”, and/or “transferred”. IA compared the FTD final inventory count with FMF inventory records and found that only 251 out of FMF’s 11,533 recorded assets matched FTD’s inventory.

IA acknowledges that several past changes, e.g. purchase order input generating the SAP Asset Number; SAP S4 migration; no SAP S4 to FMF database system link, made it difficult to maintain the FMF inventory and align with the DBG Asset Management Policy requirements.

In accordance with the International Accounting Standards (IAS) and the German Commercial Code (HGB), companies are required to disclose tangible assets, including inventories, in the financial statements. To ensure their accuracy and reliability, a physical inventory count must be conducted.		 Internal Audit recommends that Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF):
§ clean up the current FMF database to ensure compliance with the DBG Asset Management Policy requirements and match the SAP Asset Number with the unique FMF identifier
§ reconcile the FMF database assets against SAP S/4 and communicate the results whether the assets are “disposed”, “in use”, or “transferred to another company code” to Accounting Germany (FTD)
§ in case of identified gaps, investigate together with FTD to understand the rationale behind the noted differences. Upon review, update the internal Excel file accordingly for future reference 		 8/15/2025 1/16/2026 1/16/2026 0 Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Deutsche Börse AG Alba Kajtazi Denise Weigelt GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Purchasing & Facility Management (Dpt) Kai Fischer Facility Management Frankfurt (U) Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete Facility Management Frankfurt (FMF) asset management database may expose the company to operational risk due to incomplete and inaccurate asset information in the financial ledger. Therefore, it could lead to over- or underestimated balance sheet positions and result in material financial or reputational damage. Stephan Schmidt DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG) Obsolete - Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No No Yes No
2025-033_F03 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F03-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks Internal Audit (IA) identified that the ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not sufficiently monitor the risks related to ICT service providers and overall risk exposure. ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not define risk appetite thresholds or establish monitoring activities related to ICT vendor concentration risk, leading to potential non-compliance with the organization's risk appetite.

In addition, there was a lack of ICT risk reporting mechanisms for ICT third-party risks. The ICT risk management framework did not specify how these risks should be communicated to the Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO, and there was no evidence of these risks being incorporated into the DBAG or Group Risk reporting.

Finally, it was not clearly defined how the existing ICT risk assessment framework, which focuses on ICT assets, considers ICT third-party service providers. The only document describing the framework specifically for ICT service providers was not reviewed by the ICT Risk Officer / CISO. Additionally, the Information Security Policy v1.7 has not been updated since December 2023 and has not been officially decommissioned from the policy database for several legal entities.

Regulation requires ICT functions have appropriate processes and controls to ensure all risks are identified, analyzed, measured, monitored, managed, reported, and kept within the financial institution's risk appetite. The management body should set clear roles and responsibilities for effective risk management, including ICT risks.		 § Conducts a workshop with Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) and Third-Party Risk Management (ROM) to identify potential of further clarification in ICT Guidelines on how to apply existing risk assessment framework to ICT third- party service providers.
§ Perform an update of ICT Guidelines based on the conducted workshop, if necessary		 9/30/2025 8/7/2026 8/7/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Natalia Saltanovich Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Deficiencies in monitoring and reporting of ICT third party risks represent material violation of external and internal provisions, which can result in operational ambiguity, unforeseen risks and blind spots for overall security posture. Without complete risk monitoring and accurate reporting, identified risks might not be properly addressed. Lack of appropriate ICT third-party risk management may also lead to reputational damage. Sarah Ahmad Jahn BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Inadequate Roles & Responsibilities Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No

ICT Risk Officer / CISO did not define risk appetite thresholds or establish monitoring activities related to ICT vendor concentration risk, leading to potential non-compliance with the organization's risk appetite.

In addition, there was a lack of ICT risk reporting mechanisms for ICT third-party risks. The ICT risk management framework did not specify how these risks should be communicated to the Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO, and there was no evidence of these risks being incorporated into the DBAG or Group Risk reporting.

Finally, it was not clearly defined how the existing ICT risk assessment framework, which focuses on ICT assets, considers ICT third-party service providers. The only document describing the framework specifically for ICT service providers was not reviewed by the ICT Risk Officer / CISO. Additionally, the Information Security Policy v1.7 has not been updated since December 2023 and has not been officially decommissioned from the policy database for several legal entities.

Regulation requires ICT functions have appropriate processes and controls to ensure all risks are identified, analyzed, measured, monitored, managed, reported, and kept within the financial institution's risk appetite. The management body should set clear roles and responsibilities for effective risk management, including ICT risks.		 § Define thresholds to monitor compliance with DOR Strategy and Outsourcing and Third-Party Risk Management Strategy v1.0.
§ Define reporting lines and frequency for third- party ICT risk reporting.
§ Integrate identified ICT third- party risks into Chief ICT Risk Officer / CISO (ICT) reporting.
§ Monitor the overall risk exposure, particularly related to the accepted residual risks of ICT third- parties.
§ Align with Third Party Risk Management (ROM) regarding roles and responsibilities on reporting of concentration risk.		 9/30/2025 12/31/2025 12/31/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Natalia Saltanovich Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Monitoring & Reporting (U) ICT Risk Monitoring & Reporting (IRR) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.
