2025-033_F04 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of methodology for exit plan testing for ICT services supporting CIF. The Exit Management Concept is a Group-level concept designed and owned by Third Party Risk Management (ROM) to ensure maintenance of business continuity in the event of exiting current outsourcing arrangements and/or ICT services supporting critical and important functions (CIFs).

Internal Audit (IA) identified that the Exit Management Concept lacked a methodology for conducting exit plan testing for ICT services supporting CIF’s:
§ The testing steps and scenarios were not defined, hindering effective assessment of exit plan resilience and demonstrable DORA compliance.
§ The concept mentioned the tests were conducted by means of ‘tabletop testing’ but did not define roles and responsibilities for conducting, reviewing, and approving tests and test results.
§ IA’s inquiry noted ‘updated exit plan’ was considered the test outcome, with no defined success criteria or documented results.
§ No defined storage location for documenting testing activities (steps, outcomes, reviews). This hindered access to test results, analysis of testing effectiveness, and weakened the audit trail.

As per Article 28(8) under Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA), exit plans concerning ICT services supporting CIF’s need to be ‘sufficiently tested and reviewed periodically’.		 Create a Group-wide exit plan testing methodology that, at a minimum, defines testing steps and scenarios, allocates roles and responsibilities, specifies testing outcomes and follow-up actions, and outlines the process for documenting and storing testing results. 9/30/2025 2/15/2026 2/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sakshi Shanavaspur Ashok Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of methodology for exit plan testing increases the risk of inadequate testing, exposing to regulatory scrutiny and hindering the ability to identify and remediate weaknesses in exit plans. This could lead to business disruption, non-compliance with DORA requirements and financial losses if an actual exit is required. Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No Yes No
2025-033_F05 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Outdated written rules used for Ecosystem Partner risk assessments Internal Audit (IA) identified that the current and latest version of the internal written rules, developed and published by ICT Risk Framework (KJU) in January 2025, were not incorporated in the Prevalent application (AID2040). Therefore, supplier risk assessments were based on the outdated IS Standards from 2024.

Further, DORA-specific terms such as Critical and Important Functions (CIF) were not integrated in the Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management assessments.

During the audit timeframe, ICT Risk Framework (KJU) transferred the current company demands and control requirements in the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF) v5.0, released in May 2025. By the end of fieldwork, the latest MCF was, however, not yet incorporated in Prevalent. Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) confirmed operationalization would begin in Q4 2025.

European regulations require that organizations implement and maintain effective compliance monitoring controls and risk assessments.		 Integrate and operationalize the latest and current written rules in Prevalent and introduce DORA-specific terms such as Critical and Important Functions (CIF). 9/30/2025 1/16/2026 1/16/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH Deutsche Börse AG Frank Ackermann Desiree Ramirez CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Mana (U) Ecosystem Partner Security Risk Management (EPS) agrees with the finding and the first part of the recommendation. The recommendation regarding CIFs is to the extent possible already implemented at EPS. Outdated written rules used for ecosystem partner risk assessments lead to incomplete risk management and oversight, resulting in minor (non-public) sanctions or a minor breach of regulatory requirements. Prevalent did not support document labels such as ‘public’, ‘internal’ or ‘confidential’.

This contradicted Prevalent’s ISO27001 certification applicability statement and confirmation that Prevalent’s ISMS meets the objective “To limit access to information and information processing facilities”.

2025-033_F08 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of a Sirion issue management framework and procedure Sirion (AID2129) was introduced as the Group-wide contract lifecycle management system during the audit period, superseding SAP CLM (AID214).

Internal Audit noted that there was no:
§ framework and procedure for managing incidents or bugs in Sirion, detailing e.g. how issues are prioritized, how issues are allocated to IT supporters, how long the team has to respond, etc.
§ formal approval/control to ensure all issues reported via the mailbox/ other applicable channels are transferred to the internal tracking list
§ comprehensive analysis performed e.g., on the basis of the issue overview such as response time tracking, particularly from Sirion, or repeated issues that reflect the service quality delivered from Sirion and consistency checks

European, German and Luxembourg regulation require robust governance arrangements including clear organisational structures with well-defined lines of responsibility.		 § Establish a Sirion issue management framework and procedure, including -but not limited to- clearly assigned ownership and accountability for issue management activities, and defining how issues are prioritized, logged, assigned, tracked and resolved by means of a definition concept supported by clear workflows created in the chosen tool.
§ Implement a control to ensure all issues reported via the mailbox and other applicable channels are transferred to the internal tracking list, in case a ticket tool is chosen but not effective until the target date by documenting the control and/or providing a procedure for transferring the issues to the tool supported by operational effectiveness evidence of the ticket tool.
§ Perform a comprehensive analysis and establish team internal key performance indicators (KPIs) such as tracking of response times, repeated issues that reflect the service quality delivered from Sirion and consistency checks by definition of KPIs and their internal reporting.

Assess and document which ticket management system is appropriate to ensure completeness and correctness of issue management including an evaluation of the risks via documented evaluation and decision taken including the reasoning.		 9/30/2025 12/17/2025 12/17/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Jessica Dominey Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Contract Support & Tooling (U) Contract Support & Tooling (FPO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of a Sirion issue management framework and procedure represents a material violation of external and internal provisions. That may lead to weak or inconsistent controls over issue tracking and remediation and thus increasing the likelihood of errors and inefficiencies with potential financial losses. Teodora Paul ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Env. + Control Des. 2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Review the content of the CFCL Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 9/30/2025 1/14/2026 1/14/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Clearstream Fund CentreSA Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO STEEG Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Fund Services (A) Philippe Seyll Outsourcing & Controls (U) Outsourcing & Controls (KOU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Adriaan Bemelmans ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Review the content of the LuxCSD Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 9/30/2025 1/14/2026 1/14/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD LUXCSD Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) MARCO CALIGARIS Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Corporate and Outsourcing Monitoring (U) Corporate and Outsourcing Monitoring (XMZ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Carolyn Linnevers ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A03 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Review the content of the DBAG/EFAG Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 9/30/2025 1/14/2026 1/14/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A04 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Review the content of the CBL/CEU/CI/CS/CH Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed.

IA acknowledges that the recommendation was partially addressed at the time of audit report issuance, particularly in relation to the process breakdown.		 9/30/2025 1/14/2026 1/14/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Clearstream Banking AG Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) UDO HENKELMANN Post Trading (Div) Clearstream Securities Services (A) Samuel Riley Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ZFF) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Gianna Kore ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-033_F11 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F11-A05 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Differences in strategic documentation granularity across entities Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy documents of the in-scope entities. These documents, while independently owned and maintained, were expected to align in content and granularity regarding the EU’s Digital & Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and its Regulatory Technical Requirements (RTS). However, IA noted inconsistencies:

§ All entity strategy documents referenced the relevant IT-related ESMA Guidelines provisions (ESMA50-164-4285), except CFCL (as the same is explicitly mentioned in the CSSF Circular 22/806 and was hence not considered as a missing reference from a CFCL perspective). However, in a context where requirements are shared and consistent across entities, structure and content should be aligned. Also, LuxCSD’s strategy document is to be updated to include any further amendments required following the approval of the final version of the DOR Strategy.
§ Only the CFCL, EFAG, ExR, and DBAG document 'Version Record' sections included both the responsible function and document approval details. CBL, CBF, CI, CS, and CH have since addressed the gaps.
§ CFCL, CBL, CBF, CI, CS, CH, and LuxCSD provided a detailed breakdown of their processes, categorizing them into bundles and assigning each a classification (Methodology, Processing, or Support). The remaining entities referenced the four broad process areas (Management, Control, Core, and Support) but did not include the same level of detailed mapping, instead directing readers to the Process Map for further information.
§ Most strategies except LuxCSD’s explicitly mentioned the quarterly performance review frequency for regulatory-relevant outsourced services and ICT services supporting Critical or Important Functions (CIF’s). While the LuxCSD Service Delivery Statements (SDSs) may drive a different control frequency, the document should mention it.

Additionally, the strategy documents did not explicitly link to the concentration risk arising from multiple CIFs relying on a single supplier or closely connected providers. They did not clearly define exit planning accountability in outsourcing arrangements, particularly those involving CIFs, nor did they specify sub-outsourcing arrangement approval and oversight accountability. The documents integrated cloud services within the broader outsourcing framework but did not establish cloud computing as a distinct risk domain (except for CFCL who had a specific cloud chapter) or assign governance responsibility for managing cloud-specific risks. They also did not explicitly reference the need for enhanced due diligence specific to Cloud Service Providers (CSPs), despite their critical role in supporting key ICT functions. Lastly, the strategy documents did not clearly articulate how CIF identification influenced outsourcing decisions, risk assessments, or the application of enhanced controls.		 Review the content of the ExR Outsourcing & Third-Party Risk Strategy document and incorporate the missing elements to enhance clarity where needed. 9/30/2025 1/14/2026 1/14/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Eurex Repo GmbH Simone Blasi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) FRANK ODENDALL Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Funding & Financing Products & Marke (U) Funding & Financing Products & Markets (DVS) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Unharmonized strategic documentation across entities in relation to DORA and RTS requirements poses the risks of regulatory non-compliance under DORA and RTS requirements, while also undermining consistent ICT risk management, centralized oversight, and operational resilience across the organization. This may lead to regulatory breaches and financial penalties.  Frank Odendall ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Environment Yes No No No No Yes No
2025-033_F12 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F12-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of ICT-specific questions in pre-assessment questionnaire for non-IT business process initiativ Internal Audit noted that, while there were established controls in place for the pre-assessment by Outsourcing Coordinators (OC), there was a gap in the pre-assessment process for services categorized as business process (BPO) non-IT. Specifically, the pre-assessment questionnaire (PAQ) lacked targeted ICT-related questions to ensure that the requested service was independent form ICT systems or infrastructures.

The initial classification of services is determined by the Service Requestor (SR) during the PAQ process. For BPO (non-IT), reliance is placed on information from the service description, product group, and ICT category defined in the pre-assessment master data. However, there were no additional targeted ICT questions within the PAQ workflow for this service, such as “Does this service involve software“ or “data processing cloud storage”, or “remote access to the outsourcer system?”, to substantiate that the service was non-IT related in nature.

Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) mandates financial institution to clearly identify and manage Information and Communication Technology (ICT) dependencies to ensure digital operational resilience.		 Update the Pre Assessment Questionnaire (PRA) for non-IT Business Processes initiative to include targeted ICT-related questions. 9/30/2025 4/15/2026 4/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Alba Kajtazi Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of ICT-specific questions in pre-assessment questionnaire for non-IT business process initiative presents the risk of misclassification, whereby ICT-reliant services could be incorrectly treated as non-ICT. Consequently, such services may circumvent ICT risk assessments, leading to potential minor non-compliance with DORA requirements. Additionally, high volume of assessment and manual controls from Outsourcing Coordinators (OC) makes the process prone to human error.  Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No Yes No
2025-045_F01 2025 2025-045 Cyber- and Information Security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-045_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Deficiency in Cryptography Key Management documentation, Process Governance for multiple application Internal Audit recommends that Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ classify and update the “Audit Document” and the contents of the SAO SharePoint site according to the DBG Written Rules Framework Guideline
§ determine the key relevance of the internal documentation (working instructions, procedures) and its possible shared usage, to consider transferring them into DBG’s official IT written rules database in coordination with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT)		 Internal Audit recommends that Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO):
§ classify and update the “Audit Document” and the contents of the SAO SharePoint site according to the DBG Written Rules Framework Guideline
§ determine the key relevance of the internal documentation (working instructions, procedures) and its possible shared usage, to consider transferring them into DBG’s official IT written rules database in coordination with IT Governance, Risk and Transformation (IRT)		 9/8/2025 4/24/2026 4/24/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Kevin Gregory Floro Yezad Wadia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Security IT - Digitise, Evolve & Inn (U) Security IT – Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  The PKI DBAG (AID1064) and PKI Clearstream (1066) applications are internal Certificate Authorities used to digitally sign certificates for internal applications and servers that are requested by other teams within DBAG and Clearstream legal entities. PKI MSCA (AID1065) is a Certificate Authority used to digitally sign certificates that are requested regarding Skype and Outlook S/MIME  certificates and Microsoft Windows Hello for Business.

During an inspection of the PKI DBAG, PKI Clearstream and PKI MSCA cryptography key management processes primarily managed by Security IT’s - Digitise, Evolve & Innovate (SAO) unit, they referenced an internal operational procedure as “Audit Document” instead of a formally approved procedure. The document didn’t include essential elements (i.e., purpose, scope, management approval) as defined by the overarching Written Rules Framework Guideline. Despite its informal nature and not being published in the central written rules repository, SAO acknowledged the Audit Document was possibly used by multiple IT Operations/Production Support teams as a key reference for the structure of their own key management procedures, to support and further operationalize the requirements laid down in the primary document, the Encryption and Key Management Guideline published centrally by the Chief Risk Officer (FOC) area.

Further inspection of the SAO SharePoint site revealed that 19 out of 37 cryptography-related operating procedures and work instructions had not been reviewed and approved in several years (between 2020-2023) and did not state whether they were active or decommissioned. While a yearly review control exists in a JIRA task (SECPKII-1063), it lacked detailed execution steps, as well as evidence of its performance.

European, German, and Luxembourg regulations require precise and clear procedures manual which is accessible and up to date must be maintained. Business activities are conducted based on organizational guidelines. Related business, control and monitoring documentation should be written in a manner that is readily comprehensible to expert third parties.		 Geoffrey Saint-Alary CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-045_F05 2025 2025-045 Cyber- and Information Security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-045_F05-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S2 Inadequate guidelines on Partner Services as asset type in DBG’s APMS Internal Audit recommends that ICT Risk Framework (KJU):
§ complete the review, approval and publishing of the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.1
§ update the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF) for new asset-type and its control requirements

Internal Audit recommends that IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) -
§ update the ‘APMS_User Manual’ and ‘APMS Process Description’ documents with detailed criteria / guidance and their rollout
§ update APMS application functionality to include new asset type
§ impart awareness across DBG on the new asset type		 Internal Audit recommends that IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) -
§ update the ‘APMS_User Manual’ and ‘APMS Process Description’ documents with detailed criteria / guidance and their rollout
§ update APMS application functionality to include new asset type
§ impart awareness across DBG on the new asset type		 9/8/2025 4/3/2026 4/3/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Anvay Walavalkar Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) IT Governance, Risk and Transforma (Dpt) Boris Link IT Core Process Governance (U) IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  An audit comment 5.3 raised in 2024-063 Technology Governance noted Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) was incomplete regarding external web assets/services, which IA provisionally designated as “Partner Services”. A feasibility assessment about introducing Partner Services as a new asset type was to be completed by December 2024, its definition included within the ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.0 and control requirements established in the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF).

IA noted that DBG’s APMS inventory did not yet include Partner Services. 2nd LoD - ICT Risk Framework (KJU) and 1st LoD - IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) were still developing clear definition, control requirements and process descriptions. KJU plans to put in force a fully revised ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.1, including the definition of Partner Services, by end of Q3 2025.

German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets.		 Sean Mc Taggart BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),JEAN-MARC DI CATO(CBL Luxembourg),JONAS ULLMANN(Eurex Frankfurt AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),PHILIP BROWN(Clearstream Holding AG),PRINZLER RALF(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),SONIA DRIBEK-PFLEGE(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Des. + Control Op. § update APMS application functionality to include new asset type
§ impart awareness across DBG on the new asset type		 Internal Audit recommends that ICT Risk Framework (KJU):
§ complete the review, approval and publishing of the ICT Asset Management Guideline, v1.1
§ update the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF) for new asset-type and its control requirements		 9/8/2025 11/17/2025 11/17/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Anvay Walavalkar Yezad Wadia GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Chief Risk Officer (A) Dominik Schmidt-Kiefer ICT Risk Framework (U) ICT Risk Framework (KJU) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. An audit comment 5.3 raised in 2024-063 Technology Governance noted Deutsche Börse Group’s (DBG) Application Portfolio Management System (APMS) was incomplete regarding external web assets/services, which IA provisionally designated as “Partner Services”. A feasibility assessment about introducing Partner Services as a new asset type was to be completed by December 2024, its definition included within the ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.0 and control requirements established in the Mandatory Control Framework (MCF).

IA noted that DBG’s APMS inventory did not yet include Partner Services. 2nd LoD - ICT Risk Framework (KJU) and 1st LoD - IT Core Process Design & Operations (ÜPÜ) were still developing clear definition, control requirements and process descriptions. KJU plans to put in force a fully revised ICT Asset Management Guideline v1.1, including the definition of Partner Services, by end of Q3 2025.

German and Luxembourg regulations require financial institutions to maintain accurate and complete inventories of IT assets, including third-party related assets. 2025-053_F01 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Incorrect reporting of thresholds for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” The risk metric value for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” reached 20.94% in Q3 2024, which is below the early warning threshold of 21% as reported within the quarterly risk management report for Q3 2024. Upon inquiries with the indicator owner Supervisory Reporting Germany (FCL), it was confirmed that the applicable early warning threshold was 19.44% when the risk metric value for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” reached 20.94%. Therefore, indicator breach did not occur.
Internal Audit (IA) noted that the thresholds were determined by Capital Planning Unit, and they can change over time due to the dynamic nature of certain components of the calculation. However, IA identified that the line of communication between Capital Planning (BLL) and Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) was not clear.
Although the thresholds were updated in Q2 2024, UIY did not reflect the updates in the quarterly risk reports, hence the thresholds used for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” in Q3 2024, Q4 2024 and Q1 2025 quarterly risk reporting were inaccurate.

MaRisk BT 3.1.1 refers that risk reports should be based on complete, precise and current data.		 Establish and maintain a clear line of communication between the responsible units setting the risk appetite thresholds and Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) to ensure alignment and accuracy in the reporting of thresholds. 9/30/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incorrect reporting of thresholds for “Pillar I: Total Capital Ratio” may lead to misinformed risk oversight and decision-making, potentially undermining the accuracy of capital adequacy monitoring. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case there is unclear communication line which can cause incorrect reporting toward Executive Board. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No Yes No No
2025-053_F02 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inconsistencies between the defined and reported Risk Appetite thresholds Internal Audit (IA) reviewed the Risk Appetite Framework, and the thresholds defined for each relevant risk metric. The thresholds set within the Risk Appetite Framework were compared against the thresholds reported within Q1 2025 Risk Management Report (as the Risk Appetite Framework was approved in January 2025). The following inconsistencies were identified:
§ For the Risk Metric "Cover-2 stress test (ST) requirement to Default Fund (in %)" both the Amber Threshold and Red Threshold were presented as ">100%" within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025. Risk Appetite Framework determined the amber threshold level at ">90%". The thresholds reported within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025 were the latest approved thresholds at the time of the reporting. However, those latest approved thresholds were not reflected in the Risk Appetite Framework.
§ For the Risk Metric "Economic Liquidity Ratio", Amber Threshold and Red Thresholds were presented as <180% and <120%, respectively, within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025. The thresholds reported within the quarterly Risk Management Reporting for Q1 2025 were the latest approved thresholds at the time of the reporting. However, those latest approved thresholds were not reflected in the Risk Appetite Framework. Such thresholds per Risk Appetite Framework were determined as <215% and <150%. Such inaccuracy in this ratio applied to all the following risk clusters: Funding/Refinancing Risk, Illiquidity Risk, Intraday Liquidity Risk. Furthermore, for “Economic Liquidity Ratio”, the limits in RAF not only differed from those in Q1 Risk Management Report but also from those in Liquidity Indicator Concept and ILAAP handbook.
§ Red threshold defined in Risk Appetite Framework for Risk Metric "Number of introduced operational tax-relevant products / services / functionalities which were not subject to upfront operational tax analysis" (equal or more than 2 topics identified before launch or 1 topic identified after launched service) was inconsistent with the red threshold defined in Q1 2025 Quarterly Risk Management Reporting for the risk (equal or more than 3 topics identified before launch or 1 topic identified after launched service).

UIY already identified other inconsistencies during the Quarterly Risk Report re-design in Q1 2025 in the transition phase and these were discussed and addressed to the ECAG Chief Risk Officer. However, the abovementioned inconsistencies identified by IA were not captured by UIY.

MaRisk AT 5 explains that the institution must ensure that its business activities are conducted based on organizational guidelines (e.g. manuals, work documentation or workflow procedures).		 Ensure that the thresholds reported to the Executive Board are fully aligned with those defined in the Risk Appetite Framework. In cases where thresholds are revised during the year, promptly update the Risk Appetite Framework to reflect the most current values and maintain consistency across all reporting documents. 9/30/2025 6/15/2026 6/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistencies between the Risk Appetite Framework and the quarterly Risk Management Reports pose a risk of misinformed decision-making, as inaccurate thresholds may lead to incorrect assessments of risk levels, delayed escalation, and potential breaches of the organization's defined risk appetite. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case there is inaccurate information presented to the Executive Board. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Data Quality and IT Infrastructure Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No Yes No No
2025-053_F03 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Inconsistencies in the ECAG ILAAP process documentation Internal Audit (IA) identified the following inconsistencies within ECAG ILAAP Handbook:
§ In Chapter 1.3 “Regulatory Background” reference was made to an outdated version of MaRisk.
§ In Chapter 2.2 “ILAAP Governance and Responsibilities” the responsibility for the Liquidity Stress Test (LST) was wrongly allocated to Risk Analytics (DRA) in Models & Analytics (DCX) Section. As of the beginning of 2025 the responsibility lay with Financial Risk (FRM) Unit in Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) Section.
§ In Chapter 2.6 “ILAAP Documentation Framework” the use of the term “Liquidity Indicator Report” was outdated as it is now the “Liquidity Risk Report”. Furthermore, the Ownership of LST (documentation) was not correct anymore as the ownership was transferred from DCX to UIY at the beginning of 2025 (see above).
§ In Chapter 6.1 “Risk Identification at ECAG”, it was stated that the risk inventory implicitly defines the risk appetite. According to ERM, however, in the Risk Appetite Framework only all the material risk clusters from the Risk Inventory were considered, while no implication regarding the risk appetite per risk cluster was made.
§ In Chapter 7.1 “Funding Plan” the projection of balance sheet items was based on figures from the end of 2022.
§ In the Liquidity Indicator Concept the amber limit of “Own Funds” was defined as EMIR Capital Requirements + SITG + SSITG - 200mn. In Chapter 8.2 of the ECAG ILAAP Handbook, however, it was only stated EMIR Capital Requirements + SITG + SSITG, which is the correct calculation according to UIY. While the ECAG ILAAP Handbook referred to the Liquidity Indicator Concept for the newest limits, it showed the correct limit calculation, and the Liquidity Indicator Concept was outdated.
§ In Chapter 11, the listed monthly Stress Testing Report from DRA was canceled by the end of 2024 and is no longer in place. Information on the LST was now included in the monthly Liquidity Risk Report. Furthermore, within the list the new reporting duty of UIY in form of the quarterly Risk Management Report starting as of beginning of 2025 was missing.

However, UIY confirmed that changes in organizational structure of ECAG would not trigger ad-hoc review of business procedures but would rather trigger qualitative element of assessing if ad-hoc update is necessary.

The information in the ECAG ILAAP Handbook should be complete, up-to-date and correct. The defined regular review and update process, at least on an annual basis, and whenever the circumstances would require should be followed.		 Update the ILAAP Handbook so that it represents all aspects of ECAG’s ILAAP in a clear, up-to-date, and complete way. 9/30/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistencies in the ECAG ILAAP process documentation exposed the company to the risk of operational errors in case of outdated/inaccurate business procedures.
This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions in case policies are not updated swiftly in the event of significant changes.		 Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2025-221_F01 2025 2025-221 Ameli Validation Audit Q2/2025 2025-221_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 EFV_Incomplete design for Access Management controls and processes [Tz 274r, ECC] While performing remediation activities for ECC sub-finding Tz. 274r “Onboard password split”, Internal Audit identified the following weakness in Access Management controls and process.
a) The solution design did not consider the new solution based on the “Azure MFA” application. Instead, it addressed the current solution using the “MobilePass” application. The “Azure MFA” application roll-out is scheduled to be completed by mid of 2026.
b) The interim solution (based on “MobilePass”) did not consider that both parts of an initial password for external employees should not be sent to the respective line manager. However, for internal employees, the credential split was adequately designed within the interim solution.


European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require to protect and transfer credential information in a secure way.		 Internal Audit recommends that Identity & Access Management (ICA):
§ Update the solution design regarding the changes from MobilePass to Azure MFA. The respective closure documents should be updated afterwards.
§ Adjust the credential provisioning process to ensure that line managers must not receive all authentication factors that are necessary for the first login and enrolment to MFA.		 7/16/2025 2/13/2026 2/13/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit Deutsche Börse AG Karl Ulber Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker Identity & Access Management (U) Identity & Access Management (ICA) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete design for Access Management controls and processes, in particular an updated tooling (such as Azure MFA) might imply further process and control changes. Internal Audit’s validation review might become invalid or obsolete due to such significant changes.

Missing initial credential splits for external employees may lead to security breaches through unauthorized access and data breaches due to misuse of the user account of external employees. This may expose the company to minor financial and operational impact.		 Carsten Kreuz CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No No Yes
2025-221_F02 2025 2025-221 Ameli Validation Audit Q2/2025 2025-221_F02-A01 Recommendation Open S2 EFV_Use of outdated and insecure encryption protocol [Tz. 120d, ECAG] While performing remediation activities for ECAG sub-finding Tz. 120d “VPN-Encryption”, Internal Audit identified that the original finding was not yet resolved with respect to upgrading the outdated TLS 1.1 encryption protocol to the current versions TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3.

The workstream responsible for the remediation of this sub-finding could not demonstrate that all measures defined for the remediation have successfully been finalized. The implementation of a safe encryption standard was still under discussion for the client using TLS 1.1.

Additionally, suitable controls to ensure that connections within DBG environment and interconnections with clients are only using safe encryption protocols have not yet been defined and implemented. These controls are required to ensure sustainability of the solution.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require IT systems to ensure data integrity, reliability and authenticity by implementing and updating reliable encryption techniques under consideration of developments in cryptanalysis.		 Internal Audit recommends that Chief Technology Officer (ZJS)

§ Migrate all clients still using TLS 1.1 to an updated safe TLS version (TLS 1.2. or 1.3).

§ Define and implement suitable controls to prevent, or at least detect and alert, the use of outdated encryption protocols for all network connections within DBG and with clients.		 7/16/2025 3/31/2026 3/31/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit Deutsche Börse AG Viswanath Palakkad Swaminathan Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Chief Technology Officer (A) Chief Technology Officer (ZJS) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. The use of outdated and insecure encryption protocols represents a minor breach of regulatory requirements and may impact the integrity, reliability, confidentiality and authenticity of data that is not adequately safeguarded. This may in consequence result in minor financial impact, as well as material regulatory and reputational risk. Sebastian Wedeniwski CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-049_F01 2025 2025-049 OTC Processing (ECAG) 2025-049_F01-A01 Recommendation Open S2 Lack of ongoing Sanctions Screening for OTC Trade Venues Internal Audit identified that OTC Trade Venues used by Eurex Clearing AG (ECAG) were not subject to daily economic and financial sanctions screening.
ECAG had ten OTC Trade Venues onboarded in order to clear Interest Rate Swaps, Overnight Index Swaps, Inflation Swaps and Forward Rate Agreements trades. The designed process did not include process steps and controls to enter the minimum necessary data on these venues (e.g. name, country of origin, address) into any IT application connected to STOP application (AID052).  Therefore, OTC Trade Venues were not subject to daily sanctions screening against up-to-date sanctions lists (e.g. Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC), European Union, United Nations).
The risk is partially mitigated as OTC Clearing Design (OCL) performed a biennially control (AML and Sanctions) over OTC Trade Venues via WebChecks (component within AID052 STOP application) in April 2025 with no triggered alert. Additionally, the number of OTC Trade Venues onboarded was limited and stable to only ten Trade Venues.

DBG Sanctions Policy defined in chapter 3 that DBG has a strict, conservative approach to sanctions compliance and sanctions risks.  DBG and its LEs will not engage in any transactions or dealings that are prohibited under applicable sanctions.		 Internal Audit recommends that OTC Clearing Design (OCL) to:
§ Define in business procedures Access Request Process - Trading Venues for OTC Business and Informal Access Request Process - Trading Venues for OTC Business the process of entering minimum required data regarding OTC Trade Venues in IT application.
§ For existing ten onboarded OTC Trade Venues enter minimum required data in IT application connected to STOP tool (AID052) in order to provide regular (daily) economic and financial sanctions screening.		 7/28/2025 10/15/2025 11/28/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) JENS JANKA Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij OTC Clearing Design (U) OTC Clearing Design (OCL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of ongoing Sanctions Screening for OTC Trade Venues exposed the company to the risk of engaging with the trade venue that was sanctioned. As sanction packages are updated daily by different regulators and regimes, there is a risk that on a certain date a trade venue is added on a sanction list without ECAG being aware and capturing it. This represents a material violation of internal and external provisions and could have material adverse regulatory and reputational impact in case ECAG engages with sanctioned parties. Michael Hildebrand JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG) Inadequate Processes Control Env. + Des. Eff + Op. Eff. Yes Yes Yes No No Yes No
2024-037_F05 2024 2024-037 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2024-037_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Control weaknesses in Risk Services processes The business procedure 8.2.1.4.32 Own Issues required that the related outgoing emails were labelled as confidential due to the information contained. This confidential information was derived from various reports obtained through StatistiX. In that context, Internal Audit noted the following two issues:

The emails/attachments from StatistiX were not visibly labelled, and considered internal, e.g., when forwarding the info.

Email correspondence between Risk Services staff containing the confidential info were labelled internal.

 

8.2.1.4.18 Clearing Member Price Change Monitoring contained explanations related to the use of search terms for identifying Clearing Members. A diligent use of search terms was important to capture the entire company with all margin pools and clearing funds, and therefore for the understanding of the risk situation. The described four-eyes principle control did however not contain any assessment of the adequacy of the used search term by an additional person.

 

The identified issues were caused by poor design and inadequacy of controls.

 

German regulation requires that the IT systems, related IT processes and other components of the information domain ensure the integrity, availability, authenticity and confidentiality of the data. DBG policy requires that all personnel protect information according to its classification level. All information is to be classified based on its criticality level. 		 Internal Audit recommends that Risk Services (DDQ):

analyze and provide StatistiX with information about which data is considered confidential. Implement the requirements by, amongst others, instructing StatistiX to label the confidential data as such, and having the attachments amended accordingly

remind staff about email requirements related to confidentiality and include a check in the four-eyes principle control and/or take samples throughout the year, as deemed required, to ensure the requirements are met

include in the existing four-eyes principle control an assessment by an additional person of the adequacy of the used search term for identifying Clearing Members  		 12/10/2024 2/19/2025 6/30/2026 1 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Randi Montgomery Randi Montgomery THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Clearing (A) Erik Tim Müller Risk Services (U) Risk Services (DDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Control weaknesses in Risk Services processes enhance the risk of data leakage which may have minor financial impact and could cause reputational damage. They may also have a negative operational impact, which could result in financial damage.  Martina Burianova DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) Inadequate Process and/or Controls Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No Yes No No
2024-018_F08 2024 2024-018 CCAG Microsoft Azure & M365 (GITA, DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2024-018_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Deficiencies in Microsoft M365 documentation Internal Audit noted for Microsoft M365 the following documentation deficiencies in the areas of Cryptography, Encryption and Key Management (CEK) and Infrastructure and Virtualisation Security (IVS):
1. CEK: The CEK SOP did not contain the following information (CEK-01-01):
a. Pre-notification periods for manual certificate rotation.
b. Keys rotation schedules for BitLocker Data Recovery Agent (DRA) certificates and Trusted Platform Module (TPM) keys rotation schedule.
c. Requirements or exceptions regarding manual rotated certifications.
Further, the SOP allowed Hash-Based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) with a 112-bit key, which contradicted the online version of the SOP that required a minimum of 128 bits.
2. CEK: The “Fundamentals M365 Security Requirements” SOP required to rotate BitLocker DRA Certificates every 90 days, while the template for creating DRA secrets set the default rotation to 270-days. A changed policy had been implemented by   end of fieldwork (mitigated during the fieldwork). (CEK-03-01)

The identified items were likely caused by a lack of awareness by the Microsoft process owners of financial institutions’ regulatory demands.

External provisions require that the institution shall appropriately manage the risks associated with outsourcing and shall monitor the provision of the outsourced activities and processes in a due and proper manner.
In case of identified IT risks, appropriate monitoring and management processes shall be set up.		 Internal Audit recommends Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) to assess the controls as outlined and implemented by Microsoft’s management response (appendix 6.3), particularly to review the update of the SOPs.

In case of not fully remediated risks, GAL might consider risk measures to manage the residual risk.		 3/26/2025 3/16/2026 3/16/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Yigit Gullu Oliver Wolff CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Corporate IT (A) Lars Bolanca Corporate IT Cloud Operations (Dpt) Corporate IT Cloud Operations (GAL) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Without clear guidelines on rotation of manual certificates, risk exist that certificates expire or being compromised, leaving sensitive data vulnerable to unauthorised access. Missing definitions of rotation schedule for BitLocker DRA certificates could lead to these certificates becoming compromised allowing unauthorised access to encrypted data.
Incomplete or outdated procedures can cause confusion, errors, and inefficiencies, reducing overall productivity and effectiveness.

Overall, this represents a minor risk exposure due to the violation of external provisions. 		 François Leveling CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Repo GmbH),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) External Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No No Yes

(Compliance)_v.1.5_draft_CZ procedure which describes how Value
Added Tax (VAT) and Corporate Income Tax (CIT) are filed for Czech
entities. The following deficiencies were noted:
▪ Business procedure was not approved by the line manager and it
was in a draft form since June 2022.
▪ Outdated 4EP controls: Step 11 of the VAT business procedure and
step 12 of the CIT were still existing in the business procedure.
▪ The business procedure does not mention how or where the
electronic submission of VAT Tax return is performed.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends that International Taxes, Tax Reporting and M&A (ZGY) review and update the description of the website where the final tax report will be filed, ensuring outdated controls are removed.

If the existing RoPA remains valid, IA recommends DEC to update the controller information data within the RoPA ID 908.  5/21/2025 11/19/2025 11/19/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Derivatives Clearing Development (U) Derivatives Clearing Development (DEC) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Incorrect data controller information in RoPA ID 908 represents a minor violation of internal and external provisions. 2025-006_F06 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Imprecise KPIs and non-timely monitoring in context of MA-004371-2017 Internal Audit (IA) assessed the Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that were agreed as part of the SDS MA-004371-2017 between ECAG as outsourcer and EFAG London Branch as insourcer.

 

In context of OTC Product and Business Development two KPIs were agreed, namely KPI 1 “Task Completion” and KPI 2 “Timely Monthly Management Reporting”.

 

KPI 1

IA verified with the out- and insourcer that KPI 1 “Task Completion” was referring to the resource allocation of OTC Product & Clearing Business Development (ZDY) and their task completion. ZDY performed their services entirely for ECAG, hence this KPI would always be met in terms of resource allocation. Thus, IA concluded that this KPI was not meaningful.

KPI 2

According to the SDS, KPI 2 “Timely Monthly Management Reporting” foresees a monthly fulfilment. However, this KPI was tracked only on an annual basis via email confirmation at the beginning of the following year instead of an aligned monthly review to ensure timely monitoring and if necessary, intervention from ECAG. 		 Internal Audit recommends Strategy (DPA) to:

evaluate how to adequately measure the performance of the service provider in quantitative and/or qualitative terms

update the SDS MA-004371-2017 to include the measurable key performance indicators (KPIS) and circulate the SDS through the review cycle

monitor the KPIs timely 		 5/21/2025 11/19/2025 11/19/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Strategy (U) Strategy (DPA) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Imprecise KPIs and non-timely monitoring in context of MA-004371-2017 represent a minor violation of internal and external provisions. It could result in increased operational risk, negligible financial risk and limited reputational damage. It also bears the risk of a limited regulatory impact.   Vasileios Vergotis MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Unawareness/ Unclarity of Reg. Req./Incorrect interpretation Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes Yes No No No
2025-006_F08 2025 2025-006 Product/Service Development (ECAG) 2025-006_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inconsistency between Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162 regarding controllership Internal Audit noted that joint controllership of ECAG and EFAG was incorrectly stated in the Pre-Assessment (Appway ID AN003), whereas only ECAG was correctly indicated as the controller in the RoPA ID 162.   Internal Audit recommends Strategy (DPA) to scrutinise the Pre-Assessment (Appway ID AN003), particularly the controller information and correct the inconsistency between the Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162.  5/21/2025 11/19/2025 11/19/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Eurex Clearing AG Jessica Dominey Jessica Dominey THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Strategy (U) Strategy (DPA) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.  Inconsistency between Pre-Assessment and RoPA ID 162 regarding controllership represents a minor violation of internal and external provisions. 2025-010_F04 2025 2025-010 CCP Regulation (ECAG) 2025-010_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution Planning process Internal Audit (IA) identified weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution planning process, specifically in the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update and Maintenance of Resolution Planning documents subprocesses.
For the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update subprocess, IA noted that:
▪ Section 4.1 “Overview of chapters and owners” of the business procedure was not exhaustive and created confusion regarding the appropriate ownership of chapters and sub-chapters.
▪ The unit maintained a regularly reviewed and updated tracking sheet for the process, which also included the mailing list. Further, the unit also included a detailed overview of chapters and their owners within the business procedure. Comparison on the tracking sheet, business procedure and the overview included in unit’s L1 review email, obtained by IA as sample evidence, revealed several discrepancies. These discrepancies included outdated unit names, chapter owners, and point of contacts. Furthermore, certain chapter owners were missing from the mailing list maintained within the tracking sheet, while some were listed incorrectly.
For the Maintenance of Resolution Planning documents, IA noted that:
▪ The process steps for granting access to new user to the MVP tool for BaFin resolution document submission were currently embedded within the “Reporting and Submission” section of the business procedure. However, during the review of the process, IA noted that these process steps were only performed in case a new user was to be added to the MVP tool for submission.
▪ The business procedure required a review of the resolution planning documents by the Head of Unit of CCP Regulation (CCD), however the evidence of this review was not documented for 2023 and 2024.
European and German regulation require that business activities are conducted based on organisational guidelines. This includes a complete and up-to-date description of processes that clearly define the relevant roles, responsibilities, risks and related controls that are drawn up systematically.		 Internal Audit recommends CCP Regulation (CCD) to:
§ remove Section 4.1 “Overview of chapters and owners” of the business procedure, as Section 4.2 provides the detailed and adequate overview necessary
§ rectify the misalignment between the tracking sheet, business procedure, mailing list and the overview attached in the L1 review email evidence of the samples selected, to ensure accuracy and consistency of ownership and communication throughout the maintained documents
§ create a dedicated and clearly defined section within the business procedure specifically addressing the new user access provisioning to the MVP tool
§ implement a mechanism to document the review of the Head of Unit of CCP Regulation (CCD), such as documented email confirmation. Ensure all reviews are consistently documented going forward		 5/16/2025 11/12/2025 11/12/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Aditi Singh Aditi Singh THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) MATTHIAS GRAULICH Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij CCP Regulation (U) CCP Regulation (CCD) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Internal Audit (IA) identified weaknesses in the Recovery & Resolution planning process, specifically in the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update and Maintenance of Resolution Planning documents subprocesses.

For the Recovery Plan Maintenance & Update subprocess, IA noted that:
§ Section 4.1 “Overview of chapters and owners” of the business procedure was not exhaustive and created confusion regarding the appropriate ownership of chapters and sub-chapters.
§ The unit maintained a regularly reviewed and updated tracking sheet for the process, which also included the mailing list. Further, the unit also included a detailed overview of chapters and their owners within the business procedure. Comparison on the tracking sheet, business procedure and the overview included in unit’s L1 review email, obtained by IA as sample evidence, revealed several discrepancies. These discrepancies included outdated unit names, chapter owners, and point of contacts. Furthermore, certain chapter owners were missing from the mailing list maintained within the tracking sheet, while some were listed incorrectly.
