2025-030_F01 2025 2025-030 Risk Model Development (ECAG) 2025-030_F01-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Insufficiently documented controls 2025-030_F01-A01: Internal Audit recommends the control activities to be performed in accordance with the Model Change Framework and/or related process documentation to ensure consistent and effective application of the controls. If additional approvals are required on an ongoing basis, they should be documented accordingly.

2025-030_F01-A02: Internal Audit recommends that the control description for subprocess  SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development in the RCM be updated to reference the Model Change Framework in its entirety.		 Recommendation 1: Internal Audit recommends the control activities to be performed in accordance with the Model Change Framework and/or related process documentation to ensure consistent and effective application of the controls. If additional approvals are required on an ongoing basis, they should be documented accordingly.

Recommendation 2: Internal Audit recommends that the control description for subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development in the RCM be updated to reference the Model Change Framework in its entirety.		 6/25/2025 12/31/2025 12/31/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Models & Analytics (S) Management Response 1: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.

Management Response 2: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.		 Internal Audit observed that a control activity within the Risk Model Development process was not formally documented. Prior to the launch of a model change, internal approval of setup notes was obtained. However, this control activity was not defined within the Model Change Framework and related process documents. Currently setup notes were only referenced as part of implementation documentation within Model Change & Product Introduction Process.

Furthermore, control description within the Risk Control Matrix (RCM) for the subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development reflects only the key first line and second line controls. The actual control extends beyond what is currently documented, including approvals that must be obtained from internal and regulatory bodies.

MaRisk AT 4.3.1 requires that processes as well as the related tasks, competencies, responsibilities, controls and reporting channels shall be clearly defined and coordinated. Additionally, MaRisk AT 6 stipulates that documentation related to business, control and monitoring shall be kept up to date and complete. 2025-030_F02 2025 2025-030 Risk Model Development (ECAG) 2025-030_F02-A01 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in General Controls 2025-030_F02-A01: Internal Audit recommends that all Risk Model Development related documentation, including but not limited to the documents highlighted above in the finding, be reviewed and updated to ensure consistency, accuracy, and alignment with current internal frameworks and external regulatory requirements.

2025-030_F02-A02: Internal Audit recommends reviewing and updating the Legal Inventory to ensure accurate mapping of all relevant legal and regulatory requirements to the applicable subprocesses.		 Recommendation 1: Internal Audit recommends that all Risk Model Development related documentation, including but not limited to the documents highlighted above in the finding, be reviewed and updated to ensure consistency, accuracy, and alignment with current internal frameworks and external regulatory requirements.

Recommendation 2: Internal Audit recommends reviewing and updating the Legal Inventory to ensure accurate mapping of all relevant legal and regulatory requirements to the applicable subprocesses.		 6/25/2025 12/31/2025 12/31/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Emirhan Uysal Markus Messerer THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Models & Analytics (S) Management Response 1: Management agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation.

Management Response 2: The management agrees with the recommendation and is already acting upon it. The respective entries in Legal Inventory are being updated.		 Internal Audit (IA) noted following weaknesses in the general controls:
 
1. Inconsistent references in documentation
IA identified inconsistencies and outdated references across several documents.

1.1 Model Development Framework v4.0
• Footnote 2 refers to the 2023 version of the CCP Model Risk Management Policy.
• Both the CCP Model Development Framework v4.0 and CCP Model Change Framework v1.4 still refer to MaRisk 09/2017.

1.2 Model Development Guidelines – Margin Models v2.0
• On page 7, an error message appears under Chapter 2.2 Data quality: “Fehler! Verweisquelle konnte nicht gefunden werden”.

1.3 Model Change & Product Introduction Process v1.1
• References for sections 2, 3 and 4 on page 4/15 are inaccurate.
• References to sections 3.2.1, 3.2.2, and 3.3 on page 9/15 are inaccurate.
• References to sections 3.3 on page 10/15 and section 3.1 on page 11/15 are inaccurate.
• Following discrepancies are identified in Section 2.3.1:
(i) New Product Committee is not referenced as an approver, although it is included in the Model Change Framework as a required approver,
(ii) Process document states that a non-objection from BaFin will be sought, whereas the Model Change Framework requires formal approval from BaFin.

According to Section 25 (a) of the German Banking Act (KWG), business activities should be conducted based on organizational guidelines.

Additionally, according to MaRisk AT 5 and AT 6, the institution shall ensure that business activities are conducted on the basis of organizational guidelines (e.g., manuals, work instructions or workflow descriptions). The guidelines shall be swiftly amended in the event of changes to the activities and processes. Business, control and monitoring documentation shall be systematic and written in a manner that is readily comprehensible for expert third parties.


2. Legal Inventory
IA identified deficiencies in the Legal Inventory maintained within the Regulatory Monitoring Dashboard:

• The subprocess SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development is not linked to Articles 40 (Valuing Collateral) and 41 (Haircuts) of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 153/2013, although these articles are relevant to the Risk Model Development Process,
• An obsolete subprocess, SP_ECAG_CO_12.1_product introduction in risk framework, which was merged into SP_ECAG_CO_12.2_Model Change & Development in October 2022, is still linked to Legal Inventory entries LIE-1418, LIE-1415, LIE-1414, LIE-1413.

According to AT 4.4.2 MaRisk No 1 “each institution shall have a compliance function in place in order to counteract the risks that may arise from non-compliance with legal rules and regulations. The compliance function shall ensure the implementation of effective procedures for complying with the legal rules and regulations that are material to the institution, and of corresponding controls.” No 2 states that “The compliance function shall regularly identify the material legal rules and regulations, non-compliance with which might jeopardize the institution's assets, in the light of risk factors.” 

The DBG Group Compliance MaRisk Compliance Monitoring Handbook Chapter 2 explains that notwithstanding the duties of the Compliance function, the management board members and the business areas remain fully responsible for complying with laws and regulations.

According to Chapter 6.3 of DBG Group Guideline on enabling compliance with material laws and regulations, the business areas are;

• Required to conduct the analysis on new and/ or amended laws and regulations as communicated and requested by Group Compliance and provide feedback regarding the applicability, risk of non-compliance and implementation by mapping of processes or other forms of documented measures,
• Responsible to ensure that all laws and regulations applicable to their service provision are mapped in a sufficient and granular way in the Legal Inventory. Subsequently, the business Area should proactively add missing laws and regulations to the Legal Inventory when becoming aware of any laws and regulations not mapped in the Legal Inventory.		 Adam Olszewski DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No Yes No No
2025-048_F06 2025 2025-048 IT Network Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-048_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Operating of end-of-support network devices Internal Audit (IA) identified that two out of the twelve Cisco network models were out of vendor support. Throughout this audit, one of the Cisco models was fully decommissioned.

 

The remaining one, which was used internally for management purposes, was scheduled for decommissioning by the end of 2025. As a result of this audit, a risk was recorded in the VMT security risk inventory.

 

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require that organizations maintain up-to-date and supported network infrastructure to ensure effective cybersecurity, minimize vulnerabilities and comply with operational resilience and risk management obligations. 		 Internal Audit (IA) identified that two out of the twelve Cisco network models were out of vendor support. Throughout this audit, one of the Cisco models was fully decommissioned.

The remaining one, which was used internally for management purposes, was scheduled for decommissioning by the end of 2025. As a result of this audit, a risk was recorded in the VMT security risk inventory.

European, German and Luxembourg regulations require that organizations maintain up-to-date and supported network infrastructure to ensure effective cybersecurity, minimize vulnerabilities and comply with operational resilience and risk management obligations.		 6/25/2025 1/16/2026 1/16/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Volker Scheer Hernani Filipe Costa Ribeiro CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Network Security & Services (U) Network Security & Services (INN) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Operating of end-of-support network devices carries the risk that, in the event of a security incident, no patches will be provided to address vulnerabilities. However, this risk is mitigated as the respective devices are located in a segregated Network Operations Center management network secured by firewalls and with very restricted access. This situation constitutes a minor non-compliance with both internal and external requirements. Constantin Pop CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MATTHIAS GRAULICH(Eurex Clearing AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Obsolete - Complexity/ Volume of operations/ Pressure Control Env. + Control Op.Eff. 2025-032_F03 2025 2025-032 Member & Exposure Monitoring (ECAG) 2025-032_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of business description of the quarterly credit benchmarking process The quarterly credit benchmarking process was conducted in collaboration with the Credit Risk Monitoring Unit – CBL until Q1 2025. Following this period, the process was decommissioned and transitioned to be performed directly by the Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) team, utilizing input from external data sources. However, Internal Audit (IA) observed that no formal business procedure has been established to define the new methodology for executing this process. 

As described in the MAN60 Member Monitoring Manual (Section 3.5), the purpose of the quarterly credit benchmarking is to compare Eurex Clearing’s internal credit ratings with external benchmark ratings. Discrepancies greater than two notches must be reviewed by Credit Analysts to assess whether internal ratings require adjustment. For example, if a counterparty is rated A- internally but external benchmark data indicates a BBB- rating, this three-notch difference would trigger a review to determine whether the internal rating remains appropriate or needs to be revised based on updated financials or market signals.
This process is essential for maintaining the quality, consistency, and credibility of internal credit assessments and supports the integrity of the credit risk framework.		 Internal Audit (IA) recommends Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) to formally document a business procedure for the revised quarterly credit benchmarking process. This should include a clear description of the methodology, data sources, execution steps, control points, and responsible functions.  7/31/2025 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Praveen Venkatachalam Praveen Venkatachalam THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Reporting & Data Quality Management (U) Reporting & Data Quality Management (RDQ) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement/ the recommendation.  Lack of business description of the quarterly credit benchmarking process leads to operational errors and minor violation of internal provisions that may lead to negligible regulatory and/or financial impacts.   Peter Linß DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No

However, this process continues to be referenced in the operational risk scenario 50000284_EFAG_002 – Clearing Risk Sys. O., where it remains relevant due to its associated risk exposure.

The absence of this process from the ICS process map results in a misalignment between the internal control system and the operational risk framework. This may lead to incomplete control documentation and reduced transparency regarding the control environment for risk-relevant processes. 2025-037_F06 2025 2025-037 Corporate Tax (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-037_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of documented decision on non-execution of EU VAT refund process Internal Audit (IA) identified that the EU VAT refund process for Clearstream legal entities in Luxembourg was initiated but not finalized as per the documented procedure. Although recurring cost-benefit assessments indicated limited justification for pursuing refunds, no formal decision was taken to classify the process as dormant. Nonetheless, it remained dormant within the Clearstream process landscape.

A similar issue was observed for EU VAT refund process applicable to German entities in addition to a lack of process description.

In accordance with European, German, and Luxembourg regulatory requirements, financial institutions are expected to establish and maintain a clearly defined process landscape that outlines the roles and responsibilities of each functional unit. This process landscape must be regularly reviewed and promptly updated to reflect any organizational changes or decisions impacting process execution.		 Internal Audit recommends that Group Tax (ZFC):
§ Conduct a one-off comprehensive cost-benefit analysis of the EU VAT refund process to determine whether EU VAT refund process should be continued or formally discontinued.
§ Ensure that the decision is properly documented with clear rationale and supporting evidence.
§ Assess whether Group Tax holds the authority to make this decision independently or if escalation to a higher governance level (e.g., DBAG Executive Board) is necessary.
§ Following the decision, update the Luxembourg and German process landscapes to accurately reflect the current execution status.		 8/28/2025 3/27/2026 3/27/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Séverine Michel-Degueurce Elena Krause GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Group Tax (A) Nancy Eva Schanda Group Tax (A) Group Tax (ZFC) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Lack of documented decision on non-execution of EU VAT refund process leads to an inaccurate representation of active processes. This might result in a minor violation of internal and external provisions, such as negligible breach of regulatory requirements. Nancy Eva Schanda ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ARMIN BORRIES(CS Luxembourg),DIRK LOSCHER(Clearstream Banking AG),DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),ROBBERT BOOIJ(Eurex Frankfurt AG),SAMUEL RILEY(Clearstream Holding AG) Missing/Lack of understanding/Inadequate Strategy Control Des. + Control Op. 2025-042_F06 2025 2025-042 Trading (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-042_F06-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Insufficient documentation for the Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367) Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367) includes several independent sub-tools used for daily supervision of trading activity. An Excel-based documentation exists where functionalities and criticality ratings are expected to be outlined for all sub-tools.

Internal Audit identified the following deficiencies in the current documentation practices:
- Criticality Assessments were not documented for 3 out of the 18 sub-tools.
- Functionality details were absent for 6 out of the 18 sub-tools.
- Criticality Assessments were inconsistent for 4 out of the 15 sub-tools with available criticality ratings. The final assigned rating did not align with the highest CIAA (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability, and Authenticity) score.

Regulation requires all relevant processes and decisions to be documented in a way that is comprehensible and traceable.		 Internal Audit recommends Xetra/Eurex Data Warehouse, eListing & Reporting (PLY) to:
- develop and maintain comprehensive functionality description for all sub-tools used within the Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367)
- develop and describe a consistent calculation approach/ methodology for overall criticality of each sub-tool used within the Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367)
- align with business owners for the missing criticality ratings of the respective three sub-tools
- consider the need to reassess the criticalities of remaining sub-tools with business owners, if applicable
- consider if changes are required in the Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367) criticality assessment or composition		 8/19/2025 11/14/2025 11/14/2025 0 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG Deutsche Börse AG Özge Gültekin Arslan Andreas Seifert CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Derivatives & Cash Trading IT (Dpt) Quinten Koekenbier Xetra/Eurex Data Warehouse, eListing (S) Xetra/Eurex Data Warehouse, eListing & Reporting (PLY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Insufficient documentation of the Market Supervision Toolset (AID 367) may hinder oversight, reduce audit readiness, and weaken confidence in internal controls with the impact of negligible breach of regulatory requirements, Florian Gattung CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG) Inadequate Data Quality and IT Infrastructure Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-046_F08 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in Accounts Payables process and control documentation Internal Audit (IA) identified the following weaknesses in the Accounts Payables process:
§ Control C_DBAG_MA_3.2.1_OneStep Approval Workflow listed in ICS GRC’s control view lacked corresponding risk entries in the risk view.
§ The following documented controls showed traceability issues due to mismatched control IDs between the documented processes and ICS-GRC reports:
- C_DBAG_MA_3.9.1_Monthly AB run
- C_DBAG_MA_3.9.1_StandingOrder
- C_DBAG_MA_3.9.1_CreditorDebitor

In addition, the names used in the Organization and Process Structure Report for the “P_DBAG_MA_3.2_Purchase to Pay COP” process and “SP_DBAG_MA_3.2.1_Accounts Payable COP” sub-process were outdated and no longer reflected the current organizational structure. The entity has been renamed to DBAG Branch Prague, and the relevant documentation and process maps had not been updated accordingly.

IA also noted that four procedures out of seven reviewed lacked approval evidence and one document (i.e. Creation of Vendor WF) had not been reviewed since 2023:
§ Vendor Invoice Management (VIM) procedure
§ Guidance Prepaid Expenses and Deferred Charges Lux. Entities
§ Creditors with Debit Accounts
§ Creation of Vendor WF

In line with external regulations and internal policies, management is required to ensure that process documentation is complete, accurate and up to date, and appropriately approved.		 Internal Audit recommends that Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) undertake a comprehensive review of all relevant documents, including process documentation, ICS GRC RCM and process maps. Where gaps or inconsistencies are identified (e.g., outdated control IDs, prior organization structure references, missing approval evidence, inconsistencies between the ICS GRC reports) documents should be updated to accurately reflect the current process, controls and risks. All updated documents should be clearly versioned and approved by responsible management. 8/15/2025 11/11/2025 11/11/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Ourania Androulaki Denise Weigelt GREGOR POTTMEYER(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Pr (U) Vendor Invoice Management & Asset Processing (ZCE) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Accounts Payables process and control documentation may lead to uncertainty or misunderstanding regarding current procedures’ validity, reduce accountability, and pose a risk of inconsistent process execution or non-compliance with internal control standards. This may expose the company to limited adverse financial or reputational impact. 2025-046_F13 2025 2025-046 Financial Accounting (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL) 2025-046_F13-A02 Multi-Recommendation Open S1 Missing APMS registration of legal entities using PwC Connect (AID1053) PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) used a PwC IT solution (PwC Connect, AID1053) for a secure exchange of data with customers, particularly for the annual audit process. Thus, this external tool was used by almost all DBG legal entities. 

Internal Audit identified the in-scope legal entities were not listed as users in the APMS IT asset management system, except LuxCSD. The missing registration through the local IT coordinators resulted in incomplete information security risk assessment and information classification by the legal entity information owners.

According to the external and internal requirements, the organization must have an overview of IT assets and include them in the regular risk management process.		 Internal Audit recommends that General Manager Eurex Repo (GME) perform the IT application onboarding for PwC Connect (AID1053) for ExR as using legal entity including the information classification. 8/15/2025 11/28/2025 11/28/2025 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,Group IT Audit Eurex Repo GmbH Aleksandra Galaganova Denise Weigelt CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) FRANK GAST Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij General Manager Eurex Repo General Manager Eurex Repo (GME) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation.  Missing APMS registration of legal entities using PwC Connect (AID1053) leads to gaps in the organization’s IT asset management and identification of each legal entity’s IT risks. 2025-033_F14 2025 2025-033 Outsourcing and Contract Management (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-033_F14-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inconsistent terminology and documentation in Exit Action Plan Internal Audit (IA) noted that DBG's Exit Action Plan (EAP) template included the topics required under 'Exit Strategy' as per the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA). However, the template did not explicitly reference the term 'Exit Strategy'. The elements of the 'Exit Strategy' (e.g., contractual transfer information, impacted business areas, exit options) were included within the EAP's 'Exit Plan' section, and the 'Action Plan' section contained implementation details that align with DORA's understanding of an 'Exit Plan'. The exclusion of the term ‘Exit Strategy’ could lead regulators to believe that DBG lacks such a strategy.

IA also observed documentation inconsistencies. Appway referred to 'Exit Strategy', but its content corresponded to the information in the EAP's 'Exit Plan' section. This inconsistency could create confusion during regulatory reviews and audits. The inconsistency further contributed to broader issues in mapping information between the procedures, Appway, and the Register of Information. IA required several interactions to understand and map this information, highlighting the difficulty a third party would face.

As per DORA, ‘For ICT services supporting critical or important functions, financial entities shall put in place exit strategies’.		 Add an explanation to the Exit Action Plan template demonstrating how DBG's current template addresses the DORA exit strategy requirement, mapping existing practices to specific DORA elements for clarity during regulatory reviews and audits. 9/30/2025 4/15/2026 4/15/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Sakshi Shanavaspur Ashok Desiree Ramirez HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG) HEIKE ECKERT People, Risk & Compliance (Div) Governance & Organizational Servic (Dpt) Sabina Salkic Third Party Risk Management (U) Third Party Risk Management (ROM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inconsistent Terminology and Documentation in Exit Action Plan might lead to misinterpretation by regulators regarding the existence of such a strategy within DBG. Inconsistencies between procedural documents and the Appway system could further complicate the clear understanding of this area during regulatory reviews. This might expose the company to limited regulatory or operational risk. Faina West-Friesen ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(CBL Luxembourg),ANNE-PASCALE MALRÉCHAUFFÉ(Clearstream Holding AG),BOGLARKA BARTHA(CS Luxembourg),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK ODENDALL(Eurex Repo GmbH),HEIKE ECKERT(Deutsche Börse AG),JENS JANKA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),MARCO STEEG(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MELANIE DANNHEIMER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),UDO HENKELMANN(Clearstream Banking AG) Human Error/ Omission Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No Yes No
2025-045_F08 2025 2025-045 Cyber- and Information Security (DBAG, ECAG, CBF, CBL, CFCL) 2025-045_F08-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Lack of details in vulnerability management procedures in respect to timelines of involved teams Internal Audit recommends that Plan & Design Services (VLM) propose an adequate solution agreed between relevant stakeholders and implemented in related procedures. Internal Audit recommends that Plan & Design Services (VLM) propose an adequate solution agreed between relevant stakeholders and implemented in related procedures. 9/8/2025 2/18/2026 2/18/2026 0 CBL Luxembourg,CI Luxembourg,CS Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Fund CentreSA,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Eurex Frankfurt AG,Eurex Repo GmbH,European Energy Exchange,Group IT Audit,LUXCSD Deutsche Börse AG Milos Medrik Yezad Wadia CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Group Security (Dpt) Hinrich Völcker VM - Plan & Design Services (U) Plan & Design Services (VLM) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. When assessing DBG’s vulnerability management solution Rapid7 Nexpose (NXP), Internal Audit (IA) identified around 2500 NXP tickets with status ‘Fix Claimed’ that were overdue, out of which 45 were critical or high. Addressing vulnerabilities until closure is the IT Asset Owner’s/Application Owner’s (IT teams) responsibility, and the vulnerability management team – Plan & Design Services (VLM) – acts as a control function, by confirming/rejecting the IT teams ‘Fix claimed’ and ‘False Positive’ status claims. Such tickets statuses are being reported as part of the Digital Security Committee (DSC) KPIs, however these should have been treated and set to ‘close’ by the VLM team or by the automated re-test.

Deadlines for treatment of vulnerabilities are set in the ICT Patch and Vulnerabilities Management Guideline, however multiple teams need to be involved – teams treating the fix (IT teams) and validating the fix (VLM), who all need a certain time to perform their tasks. The underlying procedures were not detailed enough to be able to respect jointly the timelines set by the guidelines. In case the IT team submitted the ticket as ‘Fix Claimed’ just before the overall deadline, the ticket was already in ‘overdue’ status when treated by VLM.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation requires organizations to establish a structured process for identifying, assessing, remediating, and reporting vulnerabilities.		 Rahul Choubey CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(CS Luxembourg),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),FABRICE TOMENKO(CI Luxembourg),FRANK GAST(Eurex Repo GmbH),KEVIN HAYES(Clearstream Fund CentreSA),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),MARCO CALIGARIS(LUXCSD),QUINTEN KOEKENBIER(Eurex Frankfurt AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),RICK JENS(European Energy Exchange),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Des. + Control Op. Eff. No Yes Yes No No No Yes
2025-053_F04 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F04-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Inadequate explanation of the risk materiality assessment Internal Audit (IA) noted, based on the explanation provided by the Enterprise Risk Management (UIY), that although the gross approach was applied in the determination of risk materiality for Wrong-Way Credit Risk, the explanation as provided within the Risk Materiality Assessment was not clear enough for an independent eye as it referred to mitigating factors which could be perceived as “net approach”.
Namely, IA noted that the qualitative materiality assessment carried out for Wrong-Way Credit Risk was referring to strong concentration and wrong way risk policies as mitigating factors for the risk, with the help of various limits which are continuously monitored and reported by the first line of defense.
Auditees also explained that the materiality assessment carried out for Wrong-Way Credit Risk stemmed from the “Additionally Monitored Risk Framework”, which essentially lays out Eurex Clearing’s framework to identify, assess, monitor, mitigate and report credit concentration and wrong way risks.
Upon inquiries, it was confirmed by the auditees that the Wrong-Way Credit Risk is already prevented at the level of 1st Line of Defense, given there is no appetite for taking the Wrong-Way Credit Risk. Therefore, by nature, mitigating factors were not considered in the materiality assessment for such risk.

DBG Group Risk Management Procedure notes that the materiality assessment should be performed on the gross approach. Therefore, risk mitigating measures should not be considered when assessing the materiality of the Risk Cluster. Application of gross approach is also explained within ECB Guide to the ICAAP as follows: “Under the gross approach, risks are first identified without considering specific techniques designed to mitigate them. A risk could be regarded as material if its materialization, omission or misstatement would significantly change or influence the capital adequacy, profitability, or continuity of the institution from an economic perspective, irrespective of the accounting treatment applied.”		 Update the qualitative materiality assessment to remove references to mitigating measures, ensuring it clearly reflects that the assessment is based on the gross approach. 9/30/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Emirhan Uysal Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UYI) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Inadequate explanation of the risk materiality assessment may convey a misleading message, potentially resulting in the incorrect application of DBG Group Risk Management Procedure and the ECB Guide to the ICAAP. This represents a minor violation of internal provisions in case of insufficiently documenting the risk assessments. Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Operating Effectiveness No No Yes No Yes No No
2025-053_F05 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F05-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Incomplete ILAAP documentation of compliance with MaRisk requirements Although ILAAP is mostly in line with regulatory requirements, some MaRisk requirements have not been fully met.
In MaRisk BTR 3.1, paragraph 8, the determination of a survival horizon for stress scenarios was explicitly required. ECAG did not explicitly report the expected survival horizon, but it was indirectly calculated as part of the Liquidity Stress Testing application. All stress scenarios had a maximum forecast horizon of 6 days aligned with the duration of ECAG's Default Management process (maximum Margin Period of Risk (MPOR) = five plus one day as some liquidity flows would be due on the morning after the last day of the MPOR). As ECAG was not exposed to additional material risks from term-transformations, ECAG assumed the survival horizon was infinite in all cases where liquidity was sufficient to survive the first six days after a Clearing Member default. In the (theoretical) case that a stress testing scenario would result in a liquidity shortfall, the expected survival horizon was the first day within the six-day forecast horizon where the liquidity balance of his scenario sheet would show a gap. 
However, the aforementioned considerations regarding compliance with the regulatory requirements of MaRisk were not documented or formally recorded. Furthermore, although the information on the survival horizon could be derived and reported from the stress testing scenario output data, this was not done yet.		 Update documentation so that all considerations regarding compliance with the regulatory requirements of MaRisk are recorded. 9/30/2025 1/15/2026 1/15/2026 0 Eurex Clearing AG Eurex Clearing AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic THOMAS BOOK(Deutsche Börse AG) DMITRIJ SENKO Trading & Clearing (Div) Financial Derivatives (A) Robbert Booij Enterprise Risk Management (S) Enterprise Risk Management (UIY) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Incomplete ILAAP documentation of compliance with MaRisk requirements exposed the company to the risk of inability to show compliance with regulatory requirements in case compliance was not formally documented.
This represents a minor violation of internal or external provisions in case business procedures are not updated to formally regulatory requirements.		 Cesar Matos DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2025-053_F07 2025 2025-053 ICAAP and ILAAP (DBAG, ECAG) 2025-053_F07-A01 Recommendation Open S1 Weaknesses in Pillar 3 Disclosure Policy Internal Audit (IA) identified that the ECAG Pillar 3 Disclosure Report Policy did not reference the new EU banking package (CRR3/CRD6), specifically EU Regulation 2024/1623, which introduces significant changes to Pillar 3 Disclosure requirements on January 1, 2025 (the disclosure of environmental, social and government risks).

MaRisk AT 5 requirements as well as 2.4.1 Procedure – Guideline Anweisungswesen (Organizational Instructions) in part 2.7 defines that the line manager ensures that in accordance with MaRisk AT 5 paragraph 2 the policies and procedures are swiftly amended in the event of changes to the activities and processes.		 Define in Pillar 3 Discloser Policy new EU banking package (CRR3/CRD6), specifically EU Regulation 2024/1623. 9/30/2025 12/15/2025 12/15/2025 0 Deutsche Börse AG,Eurex Clearing AG Deutsche Börse AG Vladan Simunovic Vladan Simunovic JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) GREGOR POTTMEYER CFO (Div) Financial Accounting & Controlling (A) Jörg Pietzner Supervisory Reporting Germany (U) Supervisory Reporting Germany (FCL) agrees with the finding and recommendation, and will implement the recommendation. Weaknesses in Pillar 3 Disclosure Policy exposed the company to the risk of setting unclear instructions and expectations before process started. However, the risk is partially mitigated as ECAG Executive Board was notified of the regulation change.
This represents a minor violation of internal or external provisions in case policies were not updated swiftly in the event of significant changes.		 Andreas Gerhard Florenz Schulte DMITRIJ SENKO(Eurex Clearing AG),JENS SCHULTE(Deutsche Börse AG) Insufficient policies, procedures and guidelines Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No Yes No No
2025-221_F03 2025 2025-221 Ameli Validation Audit Q2/2025 2025-221_F03-A01 Recommendation Open S1 EFV_Insufficient KPI for Authentication Bypass profiles [Tz. 120e, ECAG; Tz. 121d, CBF/CH] This finding is concerning the ECAG sub-finding Tz. 120e and CBF/CH sub-finding Tz. 121d “Web Proxy”, both of which have a closure date of 31 December 2026. The sub-finding was managed within the Ameli SAFE-2 package.

The solution design outlined so-called “Authentication Bypass” profiles for printer authentication to the network. Although a KPI was implemented to monitor the number of Authentication Bypass profiles, it did not include a maximum threshold.

During fieldwork, a threshold of max. 10 Authentication Bypass profiles was defined and implemented. Formal agreement of the KPI with affected Legal Entities was still outstanding.

European, German and Luxembourg regulation and guidance require metrics to monitor and manage IT-related risks. This involves tracking the effectiveness of risk mitigation strategies and ensuring compliance with relevant standards and regulations.		 Internal Audit recommends that Network Engineering non-Trading (NEN):
§ Define and implement a threshold for the Authentication Bypass profile KPI
§ Update the respective MAB procedure documentation including approvals for the KPI threshold setting.		 7/16/2025 11/15/2025 11/15/2025 1 CBL Luxembourg,Clearstream Banking AG,Clearstream Holding AG,Deutsche Börse AG,ECC AG,Eurex Clearing AG,Group IT Audit Deutsche Börse AG Viswanath Palakkad Swaminathan Anvay Walavalkar CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG) CHRISTOPH BÖHM CIO / COO (Div) Chief Technology Officer (A) Sebastian Wedeniwski Network Engineering non-Trading (U) Network Engineering non-Trading (NEN) agrees with the finding and recommendation and will implement the recommendation. Insufficiently defined KPIs and missing threshold value may lead to different interpretation of acceptable numbers of Authentication Bypass profiles and in consequence reduced oversight and control on authentication of network devices. Authentication Bypass profiles not receiving the necessary attention and counteraction could lead to increased risk of unauthorized or malicious devices being connected to the network without being detected and blocked. This represents a minor gap in internal provisions with limited regulatory impact. Patrick Mayer CHRISTOPH BÖHM(Deutsche Börse AG),DANIEL BESSE(Clearstream Holding AG),MANFRED MATUSZA(Eurex Clearing AG),RICK JENS(ECC AG),VOLKER RIEBESELL(Clearstream Banking AG),YANNICK GOINEAU(CBL Luxembourg) Inefficient/Inadequate Controls Control Design Effectiveness No Yes No No No No Yes
